PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RYAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 1,096 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the projected repeal by the Queensland State Government of the Aborigines Act 1971-1979 and the Torres Strait Islander Act 1971-1979 will almost certainly lead to the degazettal of all Aboriginal reserves in Queensland, as happened with Aurukun and Mornington Island.

That, if the Aboriginal communities from these reserves are placed under similar shire council legislation on fifty year leases they will be exposed to serious encroachment on their land by mining and tourist interests.

That, on past evidence, these interests will clearly have the full backing of the Queensland Government and the rights of Aboriginal people to land rights and self-management will not be granted by that Government.

That the Commonwealth Government has the constitutional power to legislate and acquire land for Aboriginal people since the amendments to the Constitution in 1967, but it is your Petitioners' sincere belief that it has already failed in its duty before the people of Aurukun and Mornington Island.
That the Aboriginal people of Queensland have stated that they want land rights and self-management.

Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should make use of its constitutional and legislative powers to grant full land rights and self-management to the Aboriginal people of Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHILDS

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 22 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. As this area is on the Register of the National Estate it is therefore of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to conduct a Senate Inquiry into South West Tasmania. A Federal Inquiry has been recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South West of Tasmania but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioner Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That it is clearly apparent that Australian society is becoming more polarised-that the rich at home and abroad are becoming richer profiting from Australia's mineral wealth, whilst pensioners and the disadvantaged, some three million people, are becoming a race apart.

That, of necessity, the Federal Government take action that all Australians share the wealth of their country by the transfer of resources to income security, health care and housing, therefore your petitioners urge that:
1. All pensions and benefits be raised to at least 30 per cent of the National Average Weekly Male Earnings seasonally adjusted.
2. Removal of the means/income test on the Pensioner Health Benefit imposed by Federal legislation 1973. Re-introduction of Medibank in so doing restore all Australians to equality of citizenship.

3. To alleviate Australia's shortage of housing stock within the capacity of people to pay (rental and ownership) the Federal Government inject $200m into State Housing Authorities, which will, in addition, alleviate unemployment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Trans Australia Airlines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans Australia Airlines within four years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans Australia Airlines would inevitably result in-
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans Australia Airlines.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tasmanian Wilderness Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. As this area is on the Register of the National Estate it is therefore of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to support a Federal inquiry into South West Tasmania as recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate funds nor allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South West of Tasmania but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That leave be granted to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Customs Act 1901 to provide for approval by Parliament of the export of minerals extracted from sand from a prescribed place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister whether it is a fact that no implementation details have yet been decided, nor any effects calculated, of the Prime Minister's announced decision of 12 August to drop the 'Buy Australian' policy in government purchasing. How does the Government reconcile this decision with its frequent advocacy of development of high technology industries in Australia, such as the computer industry which was specifically referred to as an example in a speech by the Minister for Science and Technology in July. Does the United States, by contrast, apply a 50 per cent national duty on all imported high technology bought by the United States Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that in fact the Government has stated that its announced policy would have only marginal influence on the overall question of purchases and that financially the effect would be very limited. I will get the actual figures and let the Senate have them. The aim of this Government is to encourage the growth of industries in high technology by higher productivity and by lower inflation in Australia. That is why our thrust is towards beating inflation and getting industries efficient by world standards. For the first time in many years we are capable of trading outwards in effective competition with the world outside. It is present Government policies that have done that.

ANSWER.PARA: This is a relatively minor matter. Nothing can compare with the decision in 1974-75 of the then Labor Government to cut tariffs by 25 per cent across the board-a blunt instrument which exposed the manufacturing industries of Australia to a violent cold air. In fact in the space of one year directly as a result of that decision 130,000 people lost their jobs. One must get these things into perspective. The really blunt instruments are those which Labor has used in the past. The fine honing which leads to more efficient industries and greater employment, as is being evidenced today, is being done by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I ask the Minister whether, in checking the facts so that he can provide an answer to this question, he will check also whether it is not a fact that Telecom Australia is the largest purchaser of high technology equipment in Australia and that that organisation has a policy, or has had a policy, of buying up to 80 per cent Australian technology.
—I will be happy to look at the matter and give whatever information is available to Senator Button.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the Minister aware that the milk factory in Phnom Penh, Kampuchea, has closed because of a breakdown in the machinery used to operate this plant and the fact that certain spare parts required to repair and get the plant operational are not readily available? Will the Minister investigate this matter with a view to Australia providing these essential items of machinery so that this factory can again operate and provide sustenance for countless starving children in that country? Perhaps the Minister will consider providing these components through one of the international aid organisations such as Freedom From Hunger, the International Red Cross or World Vision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not aware of the matter that has been raised by Senator Bonner and I do not know whether the Minister for Foreign Affairs is aware of it. I will refer the question to him and also give him the suggestion made by Senator Bonner that Australia should compassionately consider giving whatever assistance may be possible to assist in this apparently urgent circumstance. I will see that early advice is given to Senator Bonner on the matter.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to a question I asked on 4 June this year in relation to invalid pension appeals. I also refer to a letter which the Minister subsequently wrote to me confirming that where an invalid pension is terminated three months notice of termination is given. I ask: If an appeal is still pending at the expiration of those three months, is the invalid pension still terminated? If so, is it just that a pension should be terminated before the Social Security Appeals Tribunal has made a decision on the pensioner's appeal?

—Senator Colston has asked me a series of questions about invalid pension appeals. Only yesterday I signed a letter advising him that I had just received advice from the Minister for Health, Mr MacKellar, with respect to the delays in medical assessments, about which Senator Colston has expressed concern. The Minister advised me that with changes in staffing arrangements medical assessments have been brought right up to date and are being done on the same day as the applications are received. I am very pleased to advise the honourable senator publicly on that aspect of the matters he has been raising with me. He correctly stated, in terms of my earlier response, that where an invalid pension is terminated a period of grace of three months is permitted in which an appeal can be heard. Quite frankly, I am not aware whether, after three months, if the appeal is still pending, the invalid pension is continued or there is a move to sickness benefit. I should have that information but I do not. I will get it for the honourable senator as soon as possible. The point I am making is that there is a continuing right to benefit. I am not sure whether it continues as an invalid pension or sickness benefit in the circumstances he has outlined, but I will check that and give him a firm reply, if possible during today's Question Time.

—I address my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Will he indicate the present and future prospects of the phosphate mining industry in Australia? To what extent may taxation or other incentives be necessary to produce the contribution that will be needed in this field in the grazing and agricultural industries in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will know that Australia is fortunate in having large phosphate rock deposits in north-western Queensland. However, only a small proportion is of direct shipping grade. In the past, one of the problems was that those who produce superphosphate for use in Australia argued that it was not suitable for milling and crushing by existing plants. The Western Mining Corporation, which now controls the Duchess deposits, announced recently that its subsidiary, Queensland Phosphate Ltd, will recommence mining on a small scale, at the rate of, as I understand it, 200,000 wet tonnes per annum. This is an important step in re-establishing the presence of Duchess rock in both local and overseas markets. Now that these deposits are to be reopened I believe it is particularly important for continuing progress to be made in developing the lower grade rock, which makes up the bulk of these deposits, as it could give Australia the opportunity to become self-sufficient in time by utilising our known reserves. An acceptable basis for beneficiation on a large scale has yet to be proven up, and field testing of the economics of upgrading techniques is expected in the near future.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Scott referred to the matter of Government assistance. It is my understanding that the Western Mining Corporation is looking to develop the deposits on a commercial basis. Nevertheless, the Government will be looking at this matter continuously. The Government wants to be sure that Australia has, for the long term future, a source of rock for its phosphate industry so that agriculture can have an abundance of the basis for superphosphate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under Standing Order 98, I direct a question to Senator Haines. I ask: Can she give the Senate an estimate of the cost to revenue of her private member's Bill which seeks to exempt from taxable income the first $1,000 of interest paid on savings bank and building society deposits? Is that estimate, if there is one, compatible with an estimate costing the proposal at $900m per annum? Would an enforced reduction of revenue of that magnitude constitute messing around or meddling with the Budget?

—The answer to the first question is no, but I will undertake to supply Senator Walsh with the information. The answer to the last question is no, because we are going about this proposal through a legislative procedure outside the Budget Bills.

—My question is actually addressed to a Minister of the Government, the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. I refer the Minister to my question without notice of 2 June 1981 concerning the prolonged delay experienced in waiting for the Federal and Queensland governments to reach agreement on the boundaries of the Cairns section of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. Given that the delay in declaring the section now stretches to more than eight months, I ask the Minister: Firstly, what reasons can be given for the prolonged delay in declaring the Cairns section? Secondly, is one of the prime reasons for the delay the dissatisfaction of the Queensland Government with the boundaries proposed by the Federal Government? Thirdly, when will the reconstituted Commonwealth-State Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council meet to discuss the boundaries of the Cairns section? Fourthly, will the Minister assure the Senate that consideration will be given by the Government to using the powers vested in it under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act so as to expedite the development of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Missen's question is in four parts. I can answer some of it but I do not think I can answer the last part. I remind the Senate that the Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council meeting that was scheduled for 7 November 1980, was postponed because the Queensland election was pending. Since that time, because of the new Queensland Government it has been necessary to take the steps required to reconvene the Council. I am advised that since that time Queensland has nominated its members to the Ministerial Council. I understand that they are to be the Honourable M. J. Ahern and the Honourable J. A. Elliott and that, in fact, steps have now been taken to reconvene the Ministerial Council. Mr Wilson, the Minister whom I represent in the Senate, as convener of the Council has recently had consultations with the Minister for Science and Technology and with the Queensland Ministers. The fourth meeting of the Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council is to be held in the very near future, I think some time during or towards the end of September.

ANSWER.PARA: So I can say that those are the reasons for the prolonged delay. I do not know that one of the reasons is any dissatisfaction by the Queensland Government with the boundaries proposed. I do not think that has come into it. I think I have answered the third part of the question. I have given an indication of when the reconstituted Ministerial Council will meet. I think the fourth part of the question asked by the honourable senator, about the use of Commonwealth powers, may be premature at this stage and is certainly premature until the Ministerial Council has met and attempted to reach agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of the fact that needless economic hardship is being caused to many couples because the Taxation Office takes a different moral attitude to de facto relationships from that held by other government departments, most notably the Department of Social Security? Is the Minister aware of the fact that, because section 159J (3) (c) of the Income Tax Assessment Act defines a 'spouse of the taxpayer' as a person 'married to the taxpayer', the Commissioner of Taxation is able to, if not actually forced to, penalise individuals who are in receipt of married benefits or pensions from the Department of Social Security-a department which pays the unemployment benefit, for example, at the married rate regardless of whether the relationship is a bona fide de facto one or an allegedly legal married one? Finally, will the Minister undertake to seek to remove this anomaly, by which one government department is able to give while another one takes away, by amending the relevant section of the taxation Act to allow for a spouse rebate for people in de facto relationships?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Treasurer is aware that there are different requirements in the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Social Services Act with regard to marital status. I do not believe that the Treasurer or the Minister for Social Security would regard the differences as being related to moral judgments that might be made. This question has arisen on a number of occasions. It is not a question that can be answered as simply as might be suggested in the last part of Senator Haines's question. There are different requirements. I notice that she has suggested removing the anomaly in a certain way. Other people make other suggestions. However, to change the Income Tax Assessment Act in the way in which she has suggested would involve considerable cost. On the other hand, those who suggest that the Social Services Act ought to be changed to bring it into line with the Income Tax Assessment Act would also realise that there are social consequences attached to that. This is not a new matter. It has had some consideration. But I have no statement to make on it at present.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Although I hesitate to ask a question about Telecom Australia, I feel I should. When increased telephone charges for public phones were being considered was any thought given to increasing the charge to 15c rather than to 20c, which would be more in keeping with public telephone costs in other countries? Was the increase to 20c chosen because the Japanese-made green telephone machines can take only 10c or 20c coins? I think I have seen some that take 50c coins in some areas. Will certain of the public phones that are now being used be made obsolete by this increase? Will the 20c charge mean that we will perhaps see more public phones throughout this country? Finally, has Telecom examined the possibility of producing and installing a less expensive type of public telephone, as is done in many other countries, particularly the United States of America and Canada, so that we can have more public phones throughout this country?

—The provision of public telephones, of course, is something which is regarded very highly by people who need the communication facility and who do not have their own telephone. It is some years since the cost of making a public call was last increased. I think that if that period is any indication it may well be some time before the cost is increased again. This increase may carry us over a fairly long period. I am not able to advise the honourable senator whether any requirement within the equipment itself-I take it that that is what he was asking-was a factor in the level of charge being set as it was. I will put that question to my colleague, the Minister whom I represent. I will also put to him the other questions which relate in a more technical fashion to matters of design and choice of equipment for public telephone services. I will make that information available to the honourable senator.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. It relates to the Nabarlek mishap and pollution of the Alligator Rivers system. In view of what is said on page 25 of the first report from the Supervising Scientist, where he conveyed the impression that he could not predict what was likely to happen with unauthorised water releases, will the Minister consider two proposals? The first is that the Supervising Scientist and the managing director of Nabarlek be brought before the Bar of the Senate. If that is too utopian an idea to the Minister's mind, will he make arrangements and delegate any necessary authority so that the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment can be sent to Darwin, with the authority of the Senate, and have both those gentlemen appear before it to indicate what was inadequate in the legislation, which we were told was to be the best in the world and would avoid the very thing that happened? Finally, will the Minister give me an assurance that there have been no other sneak releases of polluted water?

—My understanding is that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, having become aware of the events at Nabarlek, has asked that a report be given to him setting out all the details, including the circumstances, as well as answers to questions similar to those asked by Senator Mulvihill. The honourable senator asked whether we think his suggestions might be too utopian. I think that is the wrong adjective. I think his suggestions might be too draconian at this moment. I suggest that a more appropriate course is that the contents of the honourable senator's question be made known to the Minister, and that we await the completion of the Minister's own inquiries and any statement he might wish to make. At that stage it may be appropriate to pursue the matter further if there are matters remaining unresolved. I will also put to the Minister the other question asked by Senator Mulvihill concerning whether there have been any other unauthorised releases of water. My understanding is that there have not been. I will put that question to the Minister.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question about the precedent relating to people appearing before the Bar of the Senate. Will the Minister convey to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment the fact that the Khemlani incident was a precedent. If we are talking about evil and guilty men, I would equate the conduct of the Nabarlek company with that incident.

—I do not want to be reminded of the previous appearance of people before the Bar of the Senate. I remember that on the instructions of the government of the day such persons did not answer a single question. I would hope that we could do better if ever such a circumstance became necessary again.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask whether the Minister is aware of an article which appeared in the July 1981 edition of the Australian Industries Development Association bulletin which, with reference to the Government's May 1978 policy of naturalisation or Australianisation of companies with substantial levels of overseas ownership and control, stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Several major companies are in serious discussions with the Government and are considering early initiatives in this direction.

Can the Minister say how many companies additional to those which have gained such status are presently engaged in discussions with the Government aimed at achieving either naturalised or naturalising status? Of those companies, can the Minister indicate how many are resource or energy companies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have some information on that matter. I understand that at present three companies are seeking either naturalised or naturalising status. Both of the companies which have been granted naturalising status are involved in the resources sector. I am advised that three companies have been granted naturalised status and one of these is in the resources sector.
—What about the names of the companies, please?
— I do not have that information. If there is any further information I can get on this matter I will be pleased to do so and I will see that Senator Hill is advised.

—I ask the Minister for Social Security to enlarge upon a reference to crisis accommodation for families contained in his statement of 18 August, in which he said that he 'in association with the Minister for Housing will be taking up with the States the development of a special program', for which I believe there was an allocation of $2m. Is it intended that this special program will cater for families in the narrow and nuclear sense, or will it embrace all groups which include dependants, such as those currently sheltered in women's refuges? In view of the attitude of the Western Australian Government to refuge funding, as exemplified by this week's news of the arbitrary cessation of financial assistance to the Emmaus refuge, will the Minister seriously reconsider the pre-Budget request from a wide range of organisations to retain Federal management of such funds under a special women's services program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not heard of the Emmaus refuge matter to which the honourable senator refers. With respect to the particular matters raised in her question, I say that the Budget included a commitment to allocate the first moneys to a program of crisis accommodation for families. That followed an election commitment to do something in that area in conjunction with the States. Since the transfer to the States of the funds of the Community Health Program, under which women's refuges were funded, the responsibility for the funding of such refuges has shifted to the States. Previously the program was funded jointly by the Commonwealth and the States. In light of the variety of programs which relate to emergency accommodation, the Government believes that in the course of implementing its commitment to do something about crisis accommodation for families it should examine the range of crisis accommodation programs to see whether there would be value in having a more integrated program.

ANSWER.PARA: If one examines what exists at the moment around Australia one finds that a substantial contribution to crisis accommodation is made by State housing authorities. A relatively small contribution is made through the family support services. Those elements of crisis accommodation tend to be available both to what I think were referred to by the honourable senator as families in the narrow nuclear sense and to single parent families. There are also elements of crisis accommodation in the Youth Services Scheme, a joint Commonwealth-State arrangement which is aimed specifically at providing crisis accommodation for the young. Elements of crisis accommodation are provided also under the Commonwealth's Homeless Persons Assistance Act program, which provides funds generally to voluntary organisations over quite a wide range. In that regard, major organisations such as the Salvation Army and St Vincent de Paul are prominent, as are many other private organisations.

With respect to women's refuges, substantial representations were made following the transfer to the States of the Community Health Program. The Prime Minister met a number of delegations. I saw various representatives of the refuge groups and Mr MacKellar, the Minister for Health, who had been responsible for the funding of the Program, also saw representatives of those groups. The net result of all that was that the Prime Minister indicated that our discussions with respect to crisis accommodation generally would encompass that area as well as other areas of crisis accommodation with a view to ascertaining whether an integrated program could be devised.

With respect to the matter raised by the honourable senator, I would not expect any change in the attitude of the Commonwealth to the funding of women's refuges in advance of the discussions that I have indicated. There has been no argument about the value of, and need for, women's refuges. The funds available for that purpose have not been cut. In fact, they have been transferred to the States and I have little or no doubt that continued funding of those refuges will be provided by the States. I would not expect to be able to answer in the Senate specific questions with respect to problems that relate to particular refuges. They were never within the administration of my Department. They were within the administration of the Department of Health. In any event, they will not be within the direct administrative responsibility of any Commonwealth department.

I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that from time to time in the course of the development of women's refuges there have been difficulties with respect to the funding of particular refuges. These have sometimes arisen from the attitude of refuges to government supervision of the expenditure of funds. Disputes have arisen, for example, in Victoria about whether refuges should disclose their whereabouts and so on. I undertake to refer matters raised in this manner to the appropriate State department for reply direct to the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Communications whether he is aware of concern being expressed in the Point Lonsdale and Queenscliff areas of Victoria about the possibility that the Queenscliff post office might be closed. Is the Minister aware that many residents of that area depend upon the full range of postal facilities at Queenscliff and in fact use that post office for all their postal business? Is the Minister aware that a large number of retired people live in the area and have difficulty in getting to Geelong for their postal business? Is he aware that Queenscliff is a coastal town with a significant resort function and is remarkably self-sufficient? Is he further aware that the first Queenscliff postmaster, Mr Charles Dod, was appointed in 1853 and his appointment was not to an office of profit? Can the Minister give us an assurance that Australia Post will not close the post office at Queenscliff and in fact will retain a full postal service there?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must confess that I was not familiar with the history of Queenscliff, nor was I familiar with the first incumbent postmaster; but I am now quite attracted to visiting Queenscliff following Senator Lewis's enthusiastic endorsement of the district. I believe that at the end of July an item appeared in a Melbourne newspaper in which the Victorian State Secretary of the Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union was reported as saying that Australia Post intended to close some 70 post offices throughout Victoria in the next 18 months. I understand that the names of the post offices were listed and I can only presume that the post office to which the honourable senator now refers was included in that list, and that that gave rise to some concern within the area-as I understand it, Geelong too far away.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a fact that the recent decision of the committee on the Review of Commonwealth Functions is that contracting is to be further extended to the private sector where practical. It is true also that there have been staff ceiling reductions in staffing available for the Australian Postal Commission in anticipation that some of those reductions will take place. However, I am advised that Australia Post does not intend closing the post offices mentioned in that article. If the Queenscliff post office was one mentioned in that article, I can say that I am advised that Australia Post does not intend to close it. It is considering only a change in the method of operation, changing some of the post offices from official to non-official status. It has been put to me that some economies can be achieved by operating small post offices under non-official conditions rather than as official post offices. It may be confusion on this point which has given rise to concern. I hope that we can allay that concern of the constituents whom Senator Lewis so ably represents.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that the document read from by the Minister be tabled.
—That will be done.

—I ask the Minister for Social Security: Why, amongst all the aspects of the new health scheme which can be criticised as far as public availability of knowledge is concerned, is the Government deliberately not publicising the fact that an applicant has the right to request that additional health cards be issued to his or her spouse and children instead of having only a single card for the whole family? Why does an applicant, having gone through all the hurdles of finding out about the scheme and completing an application form, knowing that he can request multiple cards for the whole family, then have to justify that request?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There seems to be a bit of internal inconsistency in the question asked by Senator Coates. He started off by saying that the cards are available and asked why we are not publicising the fact. He then suggested that there is some hurdle in the way of getting them. I do not have an instant recall on all the material which has been put out with respect to the health scheme. I suppose that the more detail one includes the more criticism one is going to attract for not having information which is clear and concise. Certainly I have not understood it to be any secret that cards are available to dependants of people who are entitled to cards. I will examine the material available to see whether reference is made to that. It is certainly a matter which has been drawn to my attention on frequent occasions and has been very evident to me. I was not under any impression that it was not evident to members of the public who might be interested.

ANSWER.PARA: The reference to hurdles by Senator Coates is part of a series of complaints which have been made by the Opposition about this scheme. I remind the Senate that we are replacing a scheme which depends upon the individual judgment of doctors-a judgment which, from the complaints I have received over the years, varies considerably from doctor to doctor-with a scheme where people who are entitled will know that they are entitled and will have something which is clear and demonstrable. The bulk of the people who are entitled will receive without any effort at all a clear indication of their entitlement. The existing pensioner health beneficiaries have always had to apply for their cards, and I have never heard of any great complaints about that being such a problem. Indeed, the main problem with respect to the pensioner health card, as far as I can tell from the representations I receive, is that everybody would like one. So I am not quite sure what is deficient about the pensioner health card. It seems to be very popular.

We are now ensuring that the unemployed, the new migrants, and so on, will automatically receive a similar card. I have no doubt that that will be a valued thing as far as they are concerned. It is only with respect to those Australians who are on low incomes, within the benefits which have been set, that there is a requirement that they apply. The scheme is geared so that if those people neglect to apply-we expect that a substantial proportion will do so, for the simple reason that often those people are the last to take advantage of the provisions which are available to them-they will be able to get ex post facto entitlement to a card. It will be possible for them to get the card to cover a period for which they have not had cover because they have not made an application. Despite the rather carping criticisms which have been made by the Opposition, I believe the new scheme is one which will ensure that a larger number of Australians will have a sense of security in this area than was previously the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister answer that part of my question asking why somebody who requests multiple cards for the whole family has to justify that request?
—I would have thought that was no more than a sensible control over the total number of cards which will be available. I would not have thought it presented any great hurdle.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lajovic Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. On 24 August 1981, in an article entitled 'Move for more apprenticeships', the Sydney Morning Herald stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The Metal Trades' Industry Association has applied to the Arbitration Commission to abolish the age barrier applying to metal industry apprenticeships in a move to overcome a national shortage of metal and electrical tradesmen.

Will the Minister ask the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs, firstly, to support the move by the MTIA and, secondly, to initiate similar action in regard to all those restrictions still existing in order to enable all those who failed to gain apprenticeships, because of age limitations or other restrictions, to join the skilled trade work force, which is in such a great demand by Australian industry at present and will be in even greater demand in the near future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have not seen the article referred to by Senator Lajovic. I am not aware of the context in which the statements to which he referred were written. It is a fact that there are requirements for skilled tradesmen in this country, and will be in the foreseeable future, and it is also a fact that both State and Commonwealth governments have been interested in enhancing opportunities for apprenticeships to the greatest degree possible. I will refer to the Minister the statements and the question posed by Senator Lajovic to see whether his proposition would benefit those seeking to join the skilled labour force. If there is some information that I can gain for him, I will see that he is advised of it.

—I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the decision in last week's Budget to amend the sales tax Acts and to place glace fruits in the schedule of items attracting a 17 1/2 per cent tax to correct a so-called anomaly or inconsistency. Is it true that in general foodstuffs are exempt from sales tax and that on page 19 of the Budget Speech the Treasurer specifically excluded food from the new imposition? Does the Government decision therefore create and not correct an inconsistency? Is it true that this decision was taken without industry consultation or advice? Is it also true that appeal provisions under the sales tax legislation will not operate before 1 January 1982 although the increased taxes operate immediately, ensuring that effective relief may not be available to this industry and others until it is too late? Since the industry is vital to South Australia's Barossa Valley and Murray River areas, and since such a hefty tax increase will have disastrous effects on sales and the demand for both fruit and labour in an industry which is worth $3.5m to the South Australian economy, will the Government undertake to reconsider these two ill-considered decisions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Bolkus has raised a number of matters with regard to sales tax. I note his reference to page 19 of the Budget Speech. He asked also whether this decision was taken without consultation or advice. I think it is fair to say a lot of advising and consultation take place prior to the Budget. I am not aware of what consultation takes place with appropriate Ministers in regard to individual items. I will check with the Treasurer in relation to the effect of the appeal provisions in this matter. I will also hand to the Treasurer the representations made through the question of Senator Bolkus and seek a response from him on that.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources. Recently attempts have been made by unions and union leaders bearing the anti-uranium flag to disrupt shipments of uranium from Darwin. These attempts have disrupted jobs of the people of the Northern Territory and the economy, in which uranium exports play an increasingly important part. Can the Minister advise whether disruption is still occurring or whether the matter been resolved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I indicated that one of the major effects of attempts to stop the flow of uranium ore from Australia would be that many countries in the free world would not be able to get an energy balance and that there would be a shrinking of living standards which would lead to a threat not only to economic stability but also to political stability. The International Energy Agency has made it clear that the world cannot get an energy balance without significant resort to uranium. So, those who seek to stop the flow of uranium to other countries, under the strongest safeguards there are for peacetime use, must take the heavy responsibility for saying to the world outside: 'Go about your business. You can go without the energy which is necessary to maintain your living standards'.

ANSWER.PARA: There has been some difficulty in shipping uranium out of Darwin. Members of the Seamen's Union of Australia and the Waterside Workers Federation sought to frustrate the export of uranium. As honourable senators will know, a shipment of uranium did leave Darwin in early July. Let me make it clear that the Government's firm commitment is to the mining and export of uranium. We make this commitment quite clearly on the understanding that the world outside will need uranium in order to get its electric power.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would export anything.

—If those who seek to interject oppose this action they are taking the stance that they are willing to deny to the world a source of energy for which there is no alternative-none at all. When the Government decided in 1977 to permit the development of the uranium industry it did so in the light of a balanced evaluation of all these factors. The Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry made clear that it would be safe to proceed with the mining and milling of uranium and that the generation of electric power by this means was quite within the safeguards provisions. Hundreds of millions of dollars have been spent and there are thousands of people currently employed directly or indirectly in the uranium industry. We have in Australia a handful of militants seeking to deny jobs to Australians and to deny energy to the world. This is a very serious situation.

ANSWER.PARA: There is talk, of course, of the dangers with regard to uranium, and so there are if the appropriate safeguards are not undertaken. But those who raise this aspect never query the even greater danger of threat to health if this world is polluted by immense expansion of the use of coal. Country after country today is facing the situation that the use of coal will create an acid rain. That would bring about a change in the ecology of this world and have a profound effect upon the health of the people. It is ideological and not rational to choose one against the other. It is the ideology of the Left that is bringing about this situation.

I repeat that the International Energy Agency has made it abundantly clear that there can be no energy balance in this world unless there is a significant and growing contribution by nuclear power to peacetime electricity generation. Therefore, those who oppose this action are saying that they are quite willing for the outside world to have less and less energy and therefore lower living standards. I have never heard the Opposition raise the question of pollution from other resources, particularly coal. It is using ideology rather than reason and in doing so is seriously damaging the future stability of other countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to ask a question at this stage but I seek to have tabled the paper from which the Minister read. I also seek to move that the Senate take note of his answer.
—I have in fact two sheets of paper. They are a uranium brief. I used only the figures in the first paragraph. I spoke impromptu as all honourable senators would know.
—That was obvious.

—It was obvious that I was stating the expert view of the International Energy Agency and it was obvious from the interjections by members of the Labor Party that it prefers ideology to rational statement. It is a matter for the Senate to take note of the statement. I am perfectly happy for that to happen.
—I will so move at the completion of Question Time.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the Minister aware of the directive issued by the Minister she represents that the film On Sacred Ground is not to be distributed through Australian overseas posts? The Minister apparently feels-and I quote his statement-'that considerable harm could be done to Australia's image' if the film is distributed overseas. I make the point, very briefly, that the film was viewed by a fairly large audience in Parliament House last night and was extremely well received. It is a documentary on factual lifestyles of Aboriginal people in Western Australia and was produced to promote interracial understanding. In view of the interest already shown-I understand that requests have been received at three of our embassies already-will the Minister review the directive given and allow this very worthwhile, well-produced and well-documented film to be distributed in the usual manner through the Australian embassies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will refer to the Minister for Foreign Affairs the request that he review the directive relating to the film On Sacred Ground and seek his reaction to that suggestion.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Health whether it is a fact that in Tasmania Medibank Private failed to abide by Commonwealth legislation and released its new hospital and medical rates prior to approval by the Government. Is it also a fact that the Government told Medibank Private that it would have to increase its rates by $1 because, as Senator Coates said, its rates were too competitive and that $8.90 a week would undercut other private insurers in Tasmania? Can the Minister say whether it would be more accurate to say that the Government has access to all aspects of finances of all private funds to protect the public from a fund going broke, as in the case of the recent collapse of the Druids Hospital and Medical Benefits Fund in Tasmania, and to stop unrealistic rates being struck the Government approves rates of all hospital funds? Can the Minister say how much taxpayers have already subsidised Medibank since its inception?

—It is a fact that there have been some fund failures throughout Australia and that this is due at least sometimes to the level of rates not being adequate to cover the obligations which those funds incur by way of claims. A report in a newspaper-I do not know which newspaper it was-asserted the facts that have been mentioned by the honourable senator. I presume that the facts are as they appeared in the newspaper and as they were stated, but I have no particular knowledge of that matter. I am aware from memory that over the years the Government has funded Medibank Private with, I think, an establishment grant of some $10m and I think a year or so after that, to bail Medibank out of some trouble, with another $10m grant. So there has been a considerable input of funds. I do know that there is a registration board which is authorised under the National Health Act to approve applications for rate variations by medical benefit funds. This board consists of a Commonwealth actuary and two members of the Department of Health. Its brief, as one would expect, is to protect the interests of the contributors who subscribe to the funds in good faith so that those funds will be able to meet their obligations when their contributors make a claim. To ensure the viability of the funds is clearly to the benefit of contributors. This registration board receives applications from funds for variations in their contribution rates. It then considers the financial position, the membership structure and operating expenses of the funds and then approves appropriate levels of rates. I think it would be most unfortunate, with this system in place, if any fund chose to announce its rates without going through this procedure. The only possible losers could be the contributors. With the experience we have had and with the amount of extra funding Medibank Private has required, I think it is appropriate that it should use this procedure as set down.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I ask: Is it a fact that the term of Mr Bob Somervaille as Chairman of Telecom Australia expired 14 months ago? Is it also a fact that the General Manager of Telecom, Mr Curtis, resigned after the Government bungled the recent Telecom dispute? Is it a fact that neither of these positions has been filled? Why has such time been taken to fill these positions? Is the delay directed at weakening Telecom so that the Government may more easily be able to sell off the profitable parts of Telecom to private industry?

—I think it is quite wrong for Senator Button to make the imputations which are contained in the question. The Government has no desire to proceed in the way in which he suggested. As to the facts concerning the dates of resignation of the two officers he mentioned and the question of their replacement, I will seek information for him.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy, follows a question asked recently by Senator Kilgariff. Is it a fact that trade union movements in the United Kingdom, France and West Germany, and possibly in other countries where trade unions are permitted to operate, actively promote the use of nuclear energy? Is it a fact that those unions campaign against activists who seek to bring the Western world to its knees by denying it cheap, safe energy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation is that for the past 25 years in quite a number of countries, in both the Western world and behind the Iron Curtain, nuclear power has been a significant and growing source of electric power generation. Indeed, some 400 or more nuclear power plants are working throughout the Western world and some hundreds more are under construction or contemplation. So the world has had some decades of experience, and indeed some decades of support by the trade union movements of the countries involved. I will repeat what I have said; that is, that the 21 main nations of the Western world which are participating members of the International Energy Agency have indicated unanimously that in order to maintain an energy balance and, therefore, to maintain the living standards of this world in the years and decades ahead, it will be absolutely vital that nuclear energy shall take a larger and very significant part in providing that energy. They have indicated that no substitution by alternatives is capable of filling that void. No one has suggested that it is. They have also indicated the contending dangers of pollution from other orthodox means of power generation. Indeed, if the Senate so desires we can provide the technical papers on pollution by alternatives.

ANSWER.PARA: Whereas the trade union movements throughout the world have worked and co-operated in the development of these nuclear power plants because they know it is in the interests of the living standards of their people to do so, we have a division in Australia. For example, trade union leaders in such unions as the Australian Workers Union-I think Senator Gietzelt would agree-and the Federated Miscellaneous Workers Union of Australia have a viewpoint in support of uranium. So leaders of the trade union movement are earnestly working towards the development of the industry. There are ideological approaches to deny it. I simply say that it is a great pity that political ideologies in Australia are taking the place of the complete compassion necessary to provide the world outside with a source of electric power, a lack of which would cause very severe hardship to the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Social Security make available to the Senate the guidelines put to officers of his Department for the availability of the issue of multiple health cards and disadvantaged cards to families, and the guidelines given to those operating the hot line service, so that we can know just what information they are told to give to families in these circumstances?

—It is my desire to make guidelines available wherever they are relevant to the interests of beneficiaries. I will examine the request in light of the fact that with respect to an earlier request from the honourable senator regarding guidelines I drew attention to the fact that in part guidelines also relate to measures which are aimed at preventing abuse of systems. Therefore, there may be parts of the guidelines which ought not necessarily be made available. Subject to that caveat, I will examine the question and make information available to the honourable senator.

Owing to the shortage of time and the significant potential from public subscription, will the Minister expedite a favourable decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

I can understand the matter being urgent in the minds of Senator MacGibbon and those who are supporting the Commonwealth Games in Queensland. I will see whether some early response can be given.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry been drawn to a report in the Courier-Mail claiming that the Queensland State member for Lytton, Mr Tom Burns, had taken photographs of approximately 2,500 cartons of kangaroo meat at a Brisbane abattoir? Because of the seriousness of the claims in the report, will the Minister include that matter in any investigation he is undertaking?

—I did not see the report in the Courier-Mail referred to by the honourable senator in his question. I have little doubt, however, that an allegation of that nature being made by Mr Burns would have come to the attention of the authorities, if indeed it was not directly drawn to their attention by Mr Burns. I will ensure that the Minister for Primary Industry is aware of the matter, as I was not. I have no doubt that it will be followed up in the way suggested by the honourable senator.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that further questions be placed on notice. While I am on my feet, to facilitate a motion that I think Senator Georges is contemplating moving, may I have leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard the text of the document that was tabled from which Senator Georges derived his particular interest.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
URANIUM SHIPMENTS FROM DARWIN

Yes-There has been some difficulty in shipping uranium out of Darwin. Members of the Seamen's Union and The Waterside Workers' Federation there sought to frustrate the export of uranium, but as honourable senators will know, a shipment of uranium did leave Darwin on 10th July.

Let me make quite clear the Government's firm commitment to the mining and export of uranium. When the Australian Government decided in 1977 to permit the development of the uranium industry it did so in the light of a balanced evaluation of environmental, Aboriginal, non-proliferation and health and safety issues. The decision has wide public support and has been confirmed at two successive Federal elections.

Hundreds of millions of dollars have been spent and thousands are currently employed directly and indirectly because of the uranium industry. Contracts already concluded for uranium sales will lead to thousands of millions of dollars in export income flowing into Australia. If anyone doubts that the uranium industry is a viable and profitable industry for Australia, this week's press announcements should remove those doubts. QML has posted a profit in excess of $44m in its first 18 months and even the MKU result would have been encouraging except for two major non-recurring adjustments.

The attitudes of a militant minority cannot be allowed to frustrate these developments. There is no industrial basis for the actions of this minority. They are playing politics and disregarding entirely the interests of thousands of their fellow Australians who rely on the uranium industry for their livelihood.

Australians generally will deplore efforts to override the carefully-considered decisions of the elected Government. I am sure, also, that the great majority of Northern Territory citizens share my disappointment at the attempts by a minority to disrupt the jobs of the people of the Territory, and the Territory economy, in which the uranium industry plays an increasingly important role. In their attempts to stop such shipments, this minority is also damaging other thriving Northern Territory business concerns.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the answer given to Senator Thomas's question, which also related to uranium.
—It will be in Hansard.
—It is an answer to a question.
—I meant the paper from which the Minister read in answer to Senator Thomas's question. I seek leave to have that paper incorporated in Hansard.
—There was no paper. The only thing was two pencilled notes on a notepad. I answered entirely spontaneously.
—I seek leave to move that the Senate take note of Senator Carrick's answer.
—I ask Senator Georges to defer that motion for a moment. I think that one or two Ministers have indicated that they wish to respond to questions which have been asked.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave of the Senate to have incorporated in Hansard the document tabled by Senator Baume which he used as a basis for his answer to a question asked by Senator Lewis.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
SUBJECT: Union Reaction to Alleged Post Office Closures in Victoria
BACKGROUND

An item appeared in the Melbourne Sun Newspaper of 29 July 1981 in which the Victorian State Secretary of the Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union was reported as saying that Australia Post intended closing 70 post offices throughout Victoria in the next 18 months.

The names of 116 post offices were listed, from which it was alleged 70 would close. It was also mentioned that the closure would have a very serious effect on the postal services available to the residents in the areas concerned.

The item also stated that postal workers would be asked to urge their local communities to write to their Members of Parliament and Australia Post for an assurance that their post offices would not close.
INTRODUCTION
This issue must be understood within the context of:
(i) the Government RCF decision that contracting is to be further extended to the private sector where practical;

(ii) the setting by the Government of an interim provisional staff ceiling for the Australian Postal Commission for 1982, at a level which would represent a 5 per cent reduction on the level of Australia Post's estimated staffing requirements as based on predicted business volumes. In addition, the Government has decided that Australia Post should work at achieving a further 2 per cent reduction in staff numbers over the period to June 1983;
(iii) Australia Post does not intend closing the post offices mentioned. It is considering only a change in their method of operation;
(iv) it is more economical to operate small post offices under non-official conditions than under official conditions.
GENERAL

Under the Postal Services Act, Australia Post is obliged to meet all of its operating costs and at least 50 per cent of its capital expenditure. It is also required to operate its service efficiently and economically.

Australia Post's services and facilities policies are framed in accordance with its statutory obligations and with the objective of meeting the reasonable postal needs of all sections of the community. These policies are reviewed continually in the light of changing community needs.
COMMENT

On 7 May 1981, advice was given by Australia Post management to union representatives at a meeting of the Postal Consultative Council, that Australia Post proposed reviewing the basis for the provision of post office counter outlets and other facilities and the conditions under which post offices may operate.

The unions were informed also that, in accordance with normal consultative processes, no change would be made to post office provision, withdrawal or conversion policies, without proper consultation with the unions concerned.
The changes to policy currently being considered are:
(i) Official post offices be provided when there is sufficient work to employ three people full-time (with a workload below that level, the method of operation would be non-official.)
Currently the criterion is for a workload for two people full-time.
(ii) Official post offices be converted to non-official operation when there is no longer sufficient work for two people full-time.
Currently the criterion relates to a workload for one person full-time
NOTE: At this stage, no decisions have been made on this matter.

As a temporary measure, pending finalisation of the current review of post office facilities policies, vacancies of Postmaster Grades 1 and 2 will not be filled on a permanent basis. In the Bendigo area, there are only two such vacancies-at Ouyen and Charlton offices.

Any changes which may eventually be made to the existing facilities policies will be managed sensibly, with full consideration given to the suitable re-location of staff wherever necessary. Full implementation of any changes could be expected to take three years or even longer.

Changes to the method of operating post offices do not affect the range or standard of postal services provided to customers. The main difference is that non-official post offices are operated under an agency arrangement, usually by a local business person, and not by employees of Australia Post. At 30 June 1981, 3,635 post offices in Australia were operated on the non-official basis and 1,422 by Australia Post employees.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator CHANEY

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to give an answer to Senator Button. In light of the inanity of the Opposition, I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

On 19 August 1981 Senator Button asked me a question without notice in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce relating to the inclusion in the Budget Papers of proposed new works for the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, and the recent sale of a lathe by the factory.
The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Items totalling $695,000 have been listed in the Civil Works Program as 'proposed New Works' at the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo including, as the honourable senator has pointed out, a new electroplating building for $480,000.

The Government has offered the Ordnance Factory for sale as a going concern; no final decision as to its disposal will be taken until all offers received have been fully evaluated. The inclusion in the Budget of provision for these works is quite consistent with the 'going concern' approach; retention in the program is contingent upon the progress of plans to dispose of the factory. No commitments have been entered into.

As regards the sale of a lathe from the factory, this lathe was purchased second-hand in 1943. It had become progressively less accurate and was declared surplus to requirements in July 1980. It was offered to other Government departments and authorities, but was not suitable for them and was sold in June 1981 by public tender for $22,800, the highest offer.
There was a newspaper report that the purchaser hoped to obtain a price of $165,000 on resale, after he had transported the lathe to Sydney and undertaken extensive, and costly, rehabilitation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Chaney is going to get smart we can develop his approach over the next couple of weeks. I seek leave to move that the Senate take note of Senator Carrick's answer on the question concerning uranium.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer.

I have moved the motion to put this matter on the Notice Paper and so that we can debate the subject matter of the answer and some of the misinformation that Senator Carrick gave during that answer. It is possible for us to enter into a debate right now on this motion but it is not my intention to do so. I merely seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 27 August 1981, from Senator Walsh:

INTERJECT.PARA: Dear Mr President,
Pursuant to Sessional Order, I give notice that today I propose to move-
''That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:
The damaging effect on economic activity in general, and on housing in particular of the sustained record interest rates.''
Yours sincerely, Peter Walsh Senator for Western Australia
Is the motion supported?
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:
The damaging effect on economic activity in general, and on housing in particular of the sustained record interest rates.

For almost a year interest rates have been at all time record levels. There is no indication that they will fall in the foreseeable future. There is a soundly based expectation that further rises will occur. Record interest rates have been partly caused by the previous Government's incompetence and political opportunism, which can not be retrospectively corrected. They also reflect deliberate Government policy-a policy of hosing down economic growth and, the Government believes, inflation with a credit squeeze. The two objectives of the credit squeeze are to hose down economic growth and to hose down inflation. It certainly will not hose down inflation. The estimates of inflation given in the Budget Papers of 10.75 per cent for the year-this is not widely known-is the average increase in prices in this fiscal year over the previous fiscal year. The Treasury estimate, which has not been disclosed, for the June quarter 1982 over the June quarter for 1981 is 12 per cent. I invite the Minister to comment on that and to confirm that that in fact, is the Treasury inflation estimate for June quarter 1982 on June quarter 1981. While on that subject I add that the estimated 0.75 per cent increase to the consumer price index arising from the sales tax impost announced in the Budget is again an average whole fiscal year figure. In fact, by the end of this financial year the CPI will have been boosted by about 1.1 per cent because of the sales tax increases.

Despite the Government's failure in controlling inflation, the credit squeeze policy has already been successful in hosing down economic growth. In the economy generally negative growth was reported in the June quarter. As usual the tailspin is most pronounced in residential building. The latest available figures show that in May 1980 2,591 loans were approved for the purchase of newly erected dwellings. In May 1981 only 2,004 loans were approved. That represents a drop of more than 20 per cent. In permanent building society loans, a component of that larger figure, the decline was even more pronounced. In May of last year 822 such loans were approved and in May of this year 427 were approved. They almost halved. Those figures are not a single month aberration, they are consistent with the figures recorded in the previous month and may be compared with the figures for recent whole years, when total approvals under this category varied between 31,000 and 36,000. At present rates, of course, the figure will be below 25,000. The effect of that downturn in loan approvals does not show up immediately in actual building activity and employment within the industry, although there are clear indications that it is beginning to show now.

So much for the macro-economic effect of the Government's high interest rate, de facto credit squeeze policy. A 3 per cent rise in interest rates, which is the order of magnitude we have seen over the last couple of years, forces the typical family buying a home to pay an extra $65 a month. Of course, taking such a large bite out of otherwise disposable household income is inevitably having a macro-economic feedback. It is adversely affecting total demand and reinforcing the initial suppression of economic activity caused by the interest rates themselves. The previously large proportion of the population with incomes that are inadequate to obtain a building society loan has risen significantly. I seek leave to incorporate a table, which I regret I have not yet been able to show to the Minister. Incorporation is subject to his perusal.
Leave granted.
