TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The table shows that whereas, with an interest rate of 11 1/2 per cent, some 73 per cent of people have inadequate income to obtain a loan, with interest at 13 1/2 per cent the figure rises to 82 1/2 per cent. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) continually defends Government policy on the ground that if interest rates do not rise no money will be available for housing loans. Although there is doubtless some truth in that assertion, taken in isolation, the problem is rather being solved at the other end. Supply and demand are being brought into balance not by more funds being made available but by fewer people being in a position to borrow the money for the building that they want to undertake. Virtually four-fifths of the population cannot now afford housing loans. This situation was not unavoidable, but even if it had been its effects could have been substantially mitigated if the Government had committed more funds to public housing for low income earners. However, in the first three years in office the Fraser Government reduced steadily the percentage of Budget funds being devoted to public housing, which have fallen from almost 4 per cent in 1974-75 to 1.1 per cent in 1979-80, 0.9 per cent in 1980-81 and an estimated one per cent this year. Thus, at a time when there is a clear need, a very much greater demand, for funds for public housing, the response of the Fraser Government, consistent with its actions in so many other areas, has been to reduce drastically the proportion of Government funds devoted to this area, and then hold that reduction. It is ironic to recall the following words of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in November 1977.

SPEECH.PARA: Interest rates over the coming year will fall by 2 per cent. It is a target that can and will be met.

Interest rates did fall for a few months after that promise was given because the money market, foolishly, chose in the short term to believe the Prime Minister. Of couse it no longer does, nor does anyone else. Interest rates than began to rise and they have risen consisently ever since. They are now between 3 per cent and 4 per cent higher than they were when the Prime Minister made that promise. That false promise is itself a principal cause of the increase. Nobody believes what the Government says about interest rates. There is no reason why anybody should believe anything the Government says about interest rates. There are a vast number of reasons why people should not believe anything that the Government says.

The false promise delivered in 1977 has been compounded in the last three financial years by very substantial overruns of the Government's announced monetary growth target. There have been overruns in M3 of the order of 2 per cent to 3 per cent in each year. If one looks at a broader definition of money supply in the last financial year, M4, the increase was in fact 16 per cent as against 12.7 per cent in M3. That figure is not widely published but it is known to people in the capital market who influence interest rates. Government policy on interest rates, and on finance generally, has been marked by vacillation, wishful thinking, electoral expediency of the most shameful type towards the end of last year, contortions and contradictions, all to accommodate the redneck economics of the National Country Party.

Just one year after the Prime Minister gave his promise, we saw the first instalment of the Government's policy. The record wheat crop would impose a huge liability on the Reserve Bank of Australia if the Reserve Bank were to fund entirely the first advance, as it did in previous years. That would add to the money supply. For the benefit of Government members who have an interest in this subject, even though they do not know anything about it, money advanced from the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank in that way is conceptually identical to printing bank notes. The Government says it is averse to printing bank notes. As the wheat crop was very much larger than anticipated, the money supply was likely to blow out by about 1 1/2 per cent. The Government, instead of acting forthrightly as it should have done and instructing the Australian Wheat Board to go to the capital market to borrow the additional requirement, vacillated for six weeks to accommodate the eccentricities of the redneck economists of the National Country Party. It lost credibility in the money market through that vacillation and it has never regained it.

The excuse repeatedly used by the Treasurer for allowing increases in regulated interest rates has been that if increases are not permitted in a competitive market no funds will be available for lending in those areas. There may be some truth in that argument. However, the Treasurer, and his representative in this House, failed or refused to answer this question. In some areas interest rates are still regulated at well below prevailing market rates. For example, the interest rate on bank overdrafts for people in declared drought areas is supposed to be pegged at 10 1/2 per cent whereas for everyone else it is 12 1/2 per cent. If no money will come into the housing sector if interest rates are controlled or administered at below market levels, will the Treasurer or his representative explain how funds will be made available to people in drought affected areas for small overdrafts at a rate of interest 2 per cent below the market rate? If it can be done for the friends of the National Country Party, why cannot it be done for people who are borrowing money to build houses?

What does that sort of inconsistency do for the Government's credibility in the money market? We see incompetence and deceit and rising interest rate expectations. We hear a lot about rising inflation expectations but we do not hear as much about rising interest rate expectations which have been induced by the actions of this Government. Of course, the controlling of a substantial area of interest rates in this situation has contributed greatly to the present problem.

The higher interest rates do, of course, have other causes. A major cause is the record foreign capital inflow which the Government refuses to control. Last year the figure was $6.5 billion. Other things being equal, because this adds to the supply of funds and might be expected to reduce interest rates, other things do not remain equal. Most of the capital which has been coming in is speculative. That in itself is likely to exert upward pressure on interest rates. A speculative boom is always likely to exert upward pressure on interest rates. The other credit squeeze policies which the Government adopts in order to overcome what it sees to be the otherwise damaging effects of this enormous volume of capital inflow force interest rates up in other ways. The major expansion in private sector demand for investment funds over the last year-an expansion in real terms of 20 per cent-has also put pressure on the capital market and forced rises in interest rates.

A major expansion in capital investment is desirable but the spontaneous demand of the last 12 months has been artificially and substantially boosted by a series of Government taxation policies-the notorious 20 per cent investment allowance and an assortment of investment tax dodges which distort efficient resource allocation, as well as forcing up interest rates unnecessarily. All of the tax dodges, other than the 20 per cent investment allowance, are less than 18 months old. They were produced by the Government in a period when there were already strong pressures in the capital market from growing investment. The most outrageous of all the tax investment rorts-the film industry tax haven which effectively pays subsidies of up to 120 per cent, believe it or not, of the cost of producing a film-is only three months old. Like all the other investment tax dodges, that was a policy produced straight off the top of the Prime Minister's head in the lead up to an election, evidently at the bidding of a television make-up girl.

Instead of recognising these realities and, to the extent to which it is still possible, mitigating them, the Government has floated the furphy that the cause of these highly undesirable increases in interest rates is the rapacious borrowing demands of the public sector, that public sector borrowing has forced interest rates up. That is a hypothesis which is supported by the stoneage ideologues of the Treasury. In fact, public sector borrowing requirements as a proportion of gross domestic product have fallen steadily in every year since 1977-78 and are now at about half of their level in 1977-78. The assortment of primitives and deficit fetishists who populate the Government benches comfort themselves with the belief that as long as they can get rid of the deficit, inflation and interest rates will come down. That article of faith cannot be shaken by any amount of contradictory empirical evidence, and there is an abundance of that. Meanwhile, the people continue to suffer unnecessarily because of the previous opportunism, deceit and incompetence of the Government in this area and its continuing refusal to rectify past mistakes or adopt more appropriate policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh has moved an urgency motion on the following matter:

SPEECH.PARA: The damaging effect on economic activity in general, and on housing in particular, of the sustained record interest rates.

This is an important matter and the Government welcomes the opportunity to debate the issue. I think it is fair to say that nobody likes rising interest rates, nobody likes taxes, and nobody likes rising inflation. We do not like a lot of things, but we have to look at the realities. We might not like rising interest rates, but nobody likes a government which fails to manage the economy. I think Opposition senators and members can attest to the validity of that proposition. Economic management is quite fundamental to a government's responsibility, and we can claim to have carried that out effectively. Anyone listening to Senator Walsh would not think that Australia is one of the most healthy economies in the world. I believe Australia can justly claim that it is one of the most healthy economies in the Western world today, despite the things that Senator Walsh has said. We have reached this position because of our responsible approach to economic management. It is not a position that is reached easily, and sometimes difficult decisions need to be taken. There needs to be political will if a country is to have sound economic management, and I suggest that that is one of the responsibilities we have accepted. We have accepted that as part of the overall responsibility of government, we have not taken the selective, easy options that some people suggest are available to us.

I have to suggest that some of Senator Walsh's forecasts on economic activity need to be treated with considerable caution. Most of us can remember very easily the comments of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and his colleagues after last year's Budget. They were busily knocking the economy. As I remember the comments made last year, they seemed to be that the Government was driving the economy through the floor. Instead of that, at the time we brought down this Budget we were able to show that all of the Oppositions' forecasts with regard to the outcome of the economy were dead wrong. We were able to show that during the past year there had been a record of remarkable economic management and growth.

I think Senator Walsh's predictions on interest rates and their effect on the economy are of no greater worth than some of the comments that were made by the Leader of the Opposition last year, and indeed this year. Perhaps we could talk about that matter, as Senator Walsh has raised the subject. The question is: Why are interest rates rising? Anyone would acknowledge that the main reason they have been rising so strongly recently is that there has been a sharp increase in the aggregate demand for money in this country. Senator Walsh's motion speaks about the damaging effect on economic activity. He seems to have some problem with causes and effects. We have seen a staggering increase in the demand by the private sector for funds. Total State and semi-government requirements have risen appreciably.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said that.
— I am saying that too. Let us agree that there has been a remarkably strong demand for funds.
—Stupidly boosted by tax rorts that are less than 18 months old.

— Senator Walsh has made his speech; he should not try to make mine too. He has done his bit. In a year when most industrialised countries are experiencing a recession, Australia's economy is close to the top of the growth league. Maybe Senator Walsh does not like to have that acknowledged, but it is a fact. It is a matter of record. The Australian economy has a strength that few other countries can boast when looked at in terms of economic trends, employment trends, the growth of gross domestic product, and rising real incomes. All of these factors are measurable and sustainable.

SPEECH.PARA: However, notwithstanding the increases in interest rates that have occurred in Australia in recent months, the overall demand for finance is still very strong in this country. This reflects the improvement in the general level of economic activity. This strong demand for finance is evidenced by the fact that during the 12 months to May-the last month for which data is available-net loans outstanding from all major financial institutions increased by no less than 16.4 per cent. I think Senator Walsh incorporated a table relating to the period to May, and I assume he was using the same figures that are available to me. Recent lending figures for certain financial institutions confirm that this strong demand for finance is still evident. Notwithstanding the increases in interest rates during 1980-81, business fixed investment grew in real terms during that year by a noteworthy 21 per cent. Again, that is a fact. The rise in business fixed investment last year was 21 per cent. No one could suggest that that indicates an unhealthy economy. Investment anticipation data suggest further strong growth in real terms in 1981-82 of between 10 per cent and 15 per cent.

As was indicated in the Budget documents, prospects for growth in overall economic activity in 1981-82 are also buoyant. Non-farm product growth of 3 per cent to 3.5 per cent in real terms is forecast, following a 4 per cent growth in 1980-81-the strongest growth since 1973-74. Clearly, whilst the increases in interest rates over the last 12 months have been a necessary part of the Government's anti-inflationary policy, economic activity continues to grow at a very satisfactory rate. In the context of the figures I have just quoted, it is little less than astonishing that Senator Walsh can come into this chamber and try to write down the Australian economy. Apparently the Australian Labor Party is worried less about interest rates than about the fact that this Government is presiding over one of the world's healthier economies. In fact, it is right at the top of the growth rates and any other measurements that one wishes to relate to a healthy economy. Perhaps the electoral consequences of that fact and the promises for the future are all too apparent to Senator Walsh and his colleagues. Perhaps that is why he has brought forward this motion and has talked in the way he has today.

The Budget before the Parliament was framed against the background of concern throughout the Australian economy about the effects of rising interest rates. In developing a strategy for the recent Budget the Government was concerned to do everything possible to bring about a reduction in the upward pressure on the level of interest rates. The high level of interest rates is a consequence of the very high level of demand for funds in the Australian economy. Government must be prepared to make a contribution towards reducing that demand, and that is what it did in the recent Budget. It made a significant contribution towards easing the pressure on interest rates by the virtual elimination of the Budget deficit. The best contribution governments can make towards restraining interest rates is to reduce their own borrowing demands. I do not think it should be argued otherwise. The Commonwealth Government has done its part by reducing its need for new borrowings this year. The domestic Budget deficit was reduced steadily from $2,451m in 1977-78 to $567m in 1979-80, and in 1980-81 the Government achieved a domestic Budget surplus of about $400m. This reduction in the need for Commonwealth borrowing considerably reduced pressure on the capital market and prevented interest rates from rising more than they have.

The Commonwealth Government also acted to restrain the borrowing requirement of the public sector through the Loan Council. Maybe some of those decisions were not easy to take, but they were necessary. As has already been announced, new loan programs scheduled for 1981-82 will be about 4 per cent less in real terms than they were last year. Despite what I am saying about reducing the level of demand by governments on the loan market, we hear from Senator Walsh that we ought to be putting more money into this, that and the other. It may be that people might ask for additional funds from the Government for this program or that program. If they are to be put in at the cost of higher interest rates for everyone then I would have to argue that that is not sound economic management.

TALK.START.PARA: —Market forces are one thing; market forces modified by mad mullahs like Fraser are another.

— What do Senator Walsh and the Labor Party want to do about rising interest rates? In 1972-75, the Labor Party had no success in dealing with interest rates in the way in which it seems to want to deal with them today. It appears that the Labor Party has learnt nothing about interest rates, and brings forward the same prescription again. Last Tuesday Mr Hayden prescribed a return to Budget deficits. His high tax, high deficit and high cost prescriptions are exactly the same proposals as were advocated before. Members of the Labor Party have to answer the question: 'How do we finance these things? Do we print money, do we raise taxes or do we raise borrowings?' The effects of all these courses would be predictable-more inflation and ultimately higher interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party argues for controls on overseas capital. As the Treasurer (Mr Howard) said recently in the other place, the Government has a preference in the present situation for relying on more general policy responses, including, of course, a reduction in the size of its demands on the loan markets. It is not possible for the Government to guarantee to home buyers or to any other group that they will always be able to borrow funds at rates of interest that are significantly lower than market rates. For those who can obtain loans at concessional rates of interest, artificially low rates are of course a boon. That is if they can get them. If people can get a concessional rate of interest that is artificially low it might be a boon for them. But those who are selected and obtain loans at low rates do so at the expense of many others who are not able to obtain a loan at all. That is the reality of that sort of proposal.

What happens if we try artificially to hold down the price of money? The lending institutions have trouble attracting deposits. It does not take much sense to know that if they can lend only at low interest rates they can afford only to offer even lower rates to their depositors, and the result will be a drying up of funds that are available for lending. A study that was done recently for the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System claimed that trying to hold down interest rates on housing loans did not just fail to help low income earners get a housing loan. It also resulted in their being the very group which suffered financially. Low income earners were worse off because low income households, particularly those in the older age groups, hold a very high proportion of their assets in savings accounts. I would have to argue that there is no purpose in what Senator Walsh and his colleagues are pretending to do in suggesting that there is a simple solution to the problem of rising interest rates in Australia at present.

For all the reasons that I have stated, the Government had no alternative but to allow interest rates to increase, and on the basis of an extension of the understanding reached with the banks last December, the increase in the overdraft rate will not apply to farmers and others adversely affected by drought in drought declared areas for the duration of the drought. Senator Walsh seemed to take some exception to assistance being made available to farmers in drought affected areas for the duration of the drought. The information given to me with regard to the drought loans that have been made is that only a comparatively small number of loans have been granted to farmers in the drought affected areas for the period of the drought, and this would hardly distort the competitive market in which others may wish to borrow funds.

If the Government had not allowed bank interest rates to increase the result would have been a further reduction in the availability of bank funds to those very groups that the interest rate controls are designed to assist. Although there has been some slowing down in lending for housing by the major housing finance institutions during 1980-81, the overall level of housing construction activity was very high indeed. During 1980-81 private investment in dwellings grew by a remarkable 10 per cent to 11 per cent in real terms. There has not been such a high level of growth in housing activity since the last housing boom in the early 1970s. There was quite clearly a very adequate supply of housing finance available during the period that has just passed.

I think the motion we are debating was treated in a fairly lacklustre way by Senator Walsh. It was he who brought forward the matter of urgency with regard to the damaging effect on economic activity and on housing and the sustained record interest rates that are prevalent at persent. I do not think that what was brought forward by Senator Walsh showed that there was any policy that would provide a solution. As I have said, the management of the economy at present and the level of interest rates result from the fact that the current level of demand for money in the community considerably exceeds its availability. This principle of supply and demand is inescapable in most of the activities that we need to undertake. In these circumstances, interest rates rises are unavoidable unless the Government increases the availability of money, which course would have inflationary consequences. If interest rates in certain areas, for example housing, are held down too far and for too long, investors will take their dollars away from institutions which traditionally lend for housing and the capacity of those institutions to provide housing loans will be reduced. The deposit experience of savings banks and the permanent building societies bears testimony to this fact.

I thought we had discussed the matter of interest rates, the availability of finance and the demands on the capital market on a number of occasions. Those discussions have shown that at present the level of interest rates results from the factors I have mentioned. The availability of money in the community for housing or for any other activity that we support depends on factors which have been outlined by me. I therefore suggest that those who look at the case that has been made by the Opposition in support of its matter of urgency relating to what it calls the damaging effect of the sustained record interest rates would have to reject the motion. I commend to them the strategy of the Government in its present Budget, the outline that has been given by the Treasurer and the forecasts of our economy for the forthcoming year and into the future, and suggest that they look to this Government to continue its sound economic policies to provide benefits for all Australians in all the areas that we hold as important.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: -Mr Deputy President, I believe this is the first time I have had the floor while you have been in the chair. Therefore I take this opportunity to congratulate you on achieving your position.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased today to support Senator Walsh's motion regarding the urgent need we have to consider the damaging effect on economic activity in general and on housing in particular of the sustained record interest rates. This matter comes forward a little more than a week after the introduction of the Australian Democrats' legislative initiative aimed at curbing the economic damage in this area. I hope that it is an indication that the Australian Labor Party is planning to support the Bill I introduced last week. If it is not, I would like it to give me some indication at some time whether it will ignore it or oppose it completely.

Before I go any further may I remind honourable senators of what I introduced last week. In the second reading speech, which was brought on somewhat precipitately on the second day of this session, presumably because there was an intention to prove that the Australian Democrats were ill-prepared to go ahead with the initiatives I had given notice of the previous day, I indicated that the purpose of the Bill to amend the Banking Act 1959 was to ensure, firstly, that regulations are made under the principal Act for the control of increases in interest rates; secondly, that those regulations grant relief from increases in interest rates to families borrowing funds for the purchase of their first home; and thirdly, that Parliament would have control of increases in interest rates of more than 0.5 per cent. It was, as I said, some small attempt at alleviating the housing repayment burden which is rapidly becoming intolerable, particularly to people in the lower economic brackets in the community. I hope, therefore, that this motion from the ALP indicates its intention to support perhaps the bringing forward of debate on that amendment Bill. The situation is urgent. Fewer and fewer home loans are available for the people who need them most. I refer honourable senators to some statistics provided in the annual review of the residential property market by the Real Estate Institute of Australia. On page 12 it makes this statement:

The sales market in 1980-81 was characterised both by dwelling sale price rises of higher magnitude than in the previous financial year, and by buoyant markets in most of the surveyed cities up to Christmas 1980. The major hindrance to continued buoyancy in these surveyed sales markets was the severe tightening of housing finance, particularly between January and June 1981.
The review goes on to state:

The year 1980-81 was marked by a tightening in the availability of housing finance. . . . in some cities housing finance began to tighten in late 1980; in others this did not occur until the beginning of 1981. Nevertheless, the finance problem has affected, to varying degrees, activity in all surveyed sales markets.

I do not think anybody in the community would not put that factor down to the constant and large increases in interest rates that the Australian community has had to sustain in the last 12 months, and particularly in the last six months. As a corollary to the fact that fewer and fewer home loans are available, rentals are becoming harder to acquire. Those that are acquirable are dearer. Again referring to that same document, I point out to honourable senators what the Real Estate Institute of Australia has to say on the matter. On page 6 it makes the point:

Private rental markets tightened considerably in all surveyed cities during the year. The vacancy rate (the percentage of surveyed dwellings unlet at the end of each month) decreased by over half in most surveyed capitals between July 1980 and June 1981.

It goes on a page or two later to point out that there has been a general increase in rental prices in all capital cities. The Institute said that in Brisbane in the last 12 months the rent for a two-bedroom furnished unit has risen from $55 a week to $60 a week, and for a three-bedroom unfurnished house the rent has risen from $60 a week to $70 a week. It also said that as the private rental market in Perth tightened in the beginning of 1981 the rent levels rose. Of course, that is an inevitable fact of life. Landlords either have their own mortgage with a rising interest rate and therefore have to put up rentals to manage to meet their repayments to the bank or, being in the business of making money, they are aware that the supply is far outstripped by the demand and put rentals up on that basis alone. There was also an increase in rental rates in Canberra of about $10 a week. This increase is pretty well consistent with what is happening across Australia.

The ultimate result of the fact that people are finding it harder to meet their mortgage repayments is an increasing number of mortgagee sales across the country. However, before people are prepared to resort to selling the roof over their heads, they try to cut back on other measures. Obviously, they start to cut back on the household bills which are easiest to pare; that is food and clothing. Of course this does nothing for their health, their standard of living or for the small business areas around them. The local delicatessen, the local draper and the small businessman are going to be the first hit after householders start to cut back on expenditure. When that saving fails to cover the bills the householders have to resort to selling their homes. In the meantime, and because of the tightness of their finances, they have also been precluded from spending money on things which perhaps are luxuries but which to most people are a way of life, a part of their existence, like a new car, a new washing machine or a new refrigerator. They are putting up with their old ones far longer than they perhaps would in other circumstances. This must have an effect on the white goods and other industries.

Last week a woman, who would not give me her name-after she finished telling me the story I understood why-telephoned my office. I am sure she is only one of a vast number in her predicament. She is a widow of some five years with only one 10-year old daughter who needs not only to be fed, clothed and housed but also to be educated. When she spoke to me over the telephone she was distraught because she said that if she wanted to maintain her home she had no alternative left to her-she is on a pension-than to seek employment under an assumed name. She said that she had already sold her rings and her late husband's watch in order to continue to meet her $40 a week mortgage repayments. She is on a pension of a little in excess of $80 a week. She maintained that the strain that was being placed on her was causing her to become a criminal in that in order to supplement her income she had to seek employment, but in order not to have the pension cut back she would have to seek it under an assumed name.

How do we solve the problem inherent in the pressure which is constantly being brought to bear on people by increasing interest rates? The Australian Labor Party sought to solve the problem when it was in power by introducing a limited tax deduction on interest rates. As I indicated in my speech last week, if one or two problems inherent in this area can be overcome, I would be very prepared to support the introduction of something similar. Of course, the major problem is that the income cut-off point Labor introduced was an unreasonable one. It did not catch all the people who needed help. If a tax deduction scheme is introduced, it must have a reasonable or a realistic means test limit. Furthermore, it must be organised well enough to take into consideration the varying house price averages across the country. Sydney's average house price is something like $78,000, whereas that for Adelaide is almost half that figure. It would be grossly unfair to introduce some sort of scheme which captured only those people living in capital cities whose option for buying homes was limited to an average price of $35,000 or less, as occurs in Adelaide or Perth, leaving the people in Canberra, Sydney and Melbourne hanging out to dry.

The second alternative is to do as I suggested last week in my Bill; to introduce a moratorium on interest rate rises for those most in need-that is, couples or individuals buying their first home and their principal place of residence. That alternative is not without its problems because it leaves out of contention people who are equally in need of help, but it is a start. The only other alternative to either of those is for the Government to continue increasing funds for welfare housing. As Senator Walsh pointed out, not only is the Government not doing that, but also it is actually cutting back. The use of either a tax deduction scheme or increased funding for welfare housing would cost the Government-that is the taxpayer-money; not that that in itself is necessarily anything to worry about. But it does avoid placing the problem anywhere within the realms of the institutions which ought to face up to the responsibility-that is, the lending institutions.

It is for that reason that I and, I gather, the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Wran, have opted for the moratorium system. This forces the banks, and to a lesser extent the building societies, to face their responsibilities with regard to the community and home loan borrowers in particular and to use some of their record profits in facing their responsibilities. Taken in conjunction with the amendment I have suggested to the Income Tax Assessment Act this would have the effect of placing the responsibilities squarely where they should be placed, that is, conjointly between the lending authorities and the Government. I support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the final speaker for the Government I have a responsibility to refute the arguments put forward by the Opposition and by Senator Haines. I found that Senator Walsh's outburst indicated that a lot of the present trouble is due to the incompetence of previous governments. If he were referring to the Whitlam Government I would heartily agree. He referred also to our Government's attitude towards hosing down inflation. I do not like the use of the terms 'hosing down' and 'hosing down expenditure'. Senator Walsh always appears to me as a free trader. Adopting this sort of philosophy I am rather surprised that in the ambit of his arguments he failed to link Australia with part of a wider world economic system. There was a lack of comment for instance in relating the Australian events with what is taking place overseas, particularly in the United States of America. Unfortunately, all the palliatives he suggested were fairly short term expedients rather than long term solutions.

SPEECH.PARA: We must be very careful that we do not fall into a situation such as that which President Carter found himself in, when he took a short term view and allowed the economic problems to accumulate. Former President Carter then found himself in the unenviable situation of having to react too late. This had drastic and painful effects. Therefore, we must be careful to avoid a policy of total containment. The Budget does recognise a need to quieten down somewhat inflationary symptoms. If we want further information I suggest that we look at page 49 of Budget Paper No. 1.

Senator Walsh throughout his speech tended to state that there were some overruns in money supply targets. But he failed to recognise that under the Whitlam Government no money supply targets were set, and consequently we had a disastrous situation with a money supply running at something like 26 per cent. The inevitable consequence of interest rates rises followed. Senator Walsh also failed to recognise that there is a link between the rate of inflation and interest rates. In the early 1960s when the inflation rate was about 4 per cent it was considered proper to control interest rates. But as the inflation rate has tended to rise around the world appropriate techniques for the new situation have had to be adopted; that is to control the money supply. Hence on our side of politics we are emphasising the need to control the money supply growth. The Government is taking the right measures to try to control money supply growth and hence keep inflation down. We are not short terms operators; we implement long term solutions. Opposition speakers really failed to link Australia with the rest of the world. We are a major trading nation. Australia cannot isolate itself from world affairs. The hard fact is that 70 per cent of Australia's overseas transactions are carried out in terms of United States dollars. This happens regardless of the origin of the transaction, be it Japan or some other country. The simple fact is that those transactions are ultimately reflected in United States dollars. So what is happening in the United States must inevitably flow to Australia. Also United States trade represents something like 36 per cent of trade in the free world. This is further evidence that we cannot isolate ourselves from happenings in the United States.

There are certain dangers of having uncontrolled money supply growth. We must therefore endeavour to lower the rate of inflation. We must attempt to control the money supply growth and, in so doing, we will keep the lid on interest rates. If we do not do that interest rates will go through the roof. Instead of having an inflation rate of between 8 per cent and 10 per cent we could well envisage, if schemes advocated by the Labor Party were adopted, an inflation rate of 30 per cent. We on this side of the chamber are quite sympathetic to all those home borrowers who have become locked into a situation of having to pay the higher mortgage interest rates. I was quite interested in the views put forward by Senator Haines. I believe she was the only speaker who attempted to put forward solutions.

If we in the Senate are to make any contribution to thinking on important matters of our day I think we have an opporunity to be a little innovative. As Opposition senators did not make any innovative suggestions and as Senator Haines was fairly limited in her approach to the matter, I will take a little time in putting a few perhaps novel ideas so that we can at least expand our thinking on this issue. I wish to remind honourable senators that on this side of the chamber we recognise the importance of the problems encountered by many families. It grieves me when people tell me that they have to sell their house. I am looking for solutions. At the same time I am not prepared to put up with a situation in which we allow the inflation rate to rise, which in its wake will lift interest rates. What is the lesser of the two evils? This is really what we have to look at. It is unfortunate that interest rates have to rise but we have to recognise the difference between the two evils. Therefore, I think it is essential that we provide some innovative thinking in this area.

Senator Haines mentioned the need to maintain a moratorium on interest rate growth. A moratorium can cause problems. How many honourable senators opposite would be prepared to put money in the bank earning interest at a rate of 8 per cent so that home owners can borrow money at, say, 9 per cent? We all tend to follow market forces in our investment decision. That is what ordinary people in Australia are doing. Senator Haines submitted that the banks use some of their profits to reduce interest rates. However, profit in relation to an individual transaction is quite small. I do not think that that would be a satisfactory solution. Many of us are a little concerned that there is evidence of a build-up in inflationary pressure which essentially is coming from the wages area. The consequence will be pressure on wages generally, a squeeze on profits and companies will have to examine their cash flow situation. There will be a fairly strong demand for funds, and borrowing will be needed. Therefore I am not anticipating any short term reduction in interest rates. However, we are creating the environment in which the economy will not get out of hand. This is essentially the difference between the Government and Opposition.

Let us look into the future. In line with our Budget strategy this coming year we are going to import more than we are going to export. On current account about $6.5 billion will go on deficit. Therefore, to correct the situation and taking into account the domestic surplus it will be necessary to have an inflow of capital of about $7 billion. This is a necessary anti-inflationary move. We must have an environment in which overseas money can profitably be invested. The Foreign Investment Review Board guidelines ensure that overseas investors do not take us to the cleaners.

Senator Carrick, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and others time and time again have refuted the sorts of arguments used in the rhetoric of Senator Walsh. Let me use the limited time available to be innovative. First, there is room through credit unions or building societies for the self-help scheme under which people could invest at, say, 10 per cent for a certain time before they take out their loan, which they would then receive at a moderate rate of interest. I believe that building societies particularly have an opportunity to be more innovative in their rate structure. For example, building societies could have a scheme under which borrowers could pay back only interest for five years and after that period make some repayment of capital plus interest. It would certainly help the home buyer who is locked into a difficult situation. I therefore applaud some New South Wales building societies for being innovative in this way. We should also examine the possibility of allowing tax deductibility on interest rates in respect of people under a certain age buying their first home. It may be that such a scheme would have to be limited to, say, people 35 years of age and under and to loans of less than $45,000.

We have reduced the deficit. I think that possibly there is a need to put a bit of a clamp on public utility borrowings such as by Telecom Australia. We have a situation in the semi-government area in which the tail is wagging the dog. Is it more important that we have new automatic telephone exchanges in country areas or lower interest rates for home buyers? Perhaps we should look at our priorities. There is so much pressure from the semi-government area that I believe maybe we should selectively borrow abroad for some of the new development projects. Maybe we have to try despite some exchange risks but we would hedge against such a situation. I believe there should be a greater requirement for overseas people investing in resource development more to provide a greater degree of infrastructure finance. This would then take the pressure off the Australian borrowing program for local government, state and semi-government finance.

In conclusion, I want to refer to a comment that was made by Billy Wentworth, a distinguished former member of the other House. He believed that penalties or taxes should be placed on multinationals borrowing in the domestic market since they were taking advantage of Australian interest rates being lower than overseas. He believed that this would relieve pressure within Australia. I have very much more to say. However, unfortunately my time has run out. I move:
That the question be now put.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Original question put:
That the motion (Senator Walsh's) be agreed to.

I merely want to make a brief comment in relation to the report. I will make more extensive comments later in relation to the minority statement. The report itself seems to fulfil, in a formal sense, the brief given to the Commonwealth Schools Commission by the Minister for Education (Mr Fife). In particular, although it comments on the differential between government and non-government schools, it makes no point about the divisiveness of that particular recommendation or advice. I believe that within the community at large the major issue that confronts schools, both government and non-government, is the wedge that is being driven between supporters of government schools and supporters of non-government schools. Indeed, I have suggested in a number of places that it might be well for the States to declare their entire school systems private because they would be in a much better position to apply for Commonwealth grants, which are much more lavish than the States can offer to their own schools.

The directions given the Commission by the Minister are included in the report. That is right and proper, but unfortunately there has been a failure to include the minority statement, which is next in the list of papers presented by the Minister. From all my knowledge of education reports this is the first time that I have seen a minority report not bound in with and presented with a major report. Those dissenters on the Commission were making a valid point in relation to the items raised by the Minister in his brief to the Commission. However, the Commission has seen fit to leave aside that minority view and have it published elsewhere. I assume that now many people will acquire the main report and not know of the existence of the minority report, which makes extremely important statements in relation to the main report. The Commission has limited itself to becoming merely an arm of the Department of Education. It no longer fulfils its function as a critical element within the education structure-to provide not only what is requested of it by the Minister but also to point out directly that when these policies are followed by the Government certain consequences will flow from them. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Minority Statement on the Report for 1982

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I believe that the minority report of the Commonwealth Schools Commission makes excellent reading for those who are concerned about education in Australia, particularly at the school level. As I said in speaking on the main report of the Commonwealth Schools Commission, the Commission has now taken a role which is similar to that of the Department of Education-that is, it acts at the behest of the Minister for Education (Mr Fife), fulfilling his wishes without making any critical comment whatever. The minority report makes some telling points that should not escape the notice of the Senate. First, the Commission has a duty to alert the Government and the Parliament to the divisive effects of the guidelines that have been put down by the Minister. It needs to make clear that government policy is a major contributing factor to the divisions which currently occur within the education community in Australia. Probably it would be easy to be cynical on this issue-I would not wish to be-and assert that this was a deliberate attempt on the part of the Government to divide the education lobby in this country. The Government made a promise to non-government schools and has fulfilled that promise. However, what it did not tell the electorate at the time was that the Government schools would have to pay for the promise made to non-government schools.

We have a varied system of education in this community. That has been pointed out in the report itself. The Australian Democrats support the continuation of the private school system but our policy states clearly that we believe that government schools ought to be made so good that no one would want to go to a private school. At the moment the Government has set in motion a self-fulfilling phophecy in relation to schools. Non-government schools, by being deprived of funds, increasingly are becoming unable to cope with the strains placed upon them in the community. Consequently, parents are withdrawing their children from government schools and sending them to non-government schools. Now that that has occurred the Government is saying: 'People are moving. They are voting with their feet. They are going from government schools to non-government schools'. I believe that that is one of the most blatant results of the Government's lack of regard for non-government schools. It has so deprived them of funds that they are no longer able to compete. If the Government wishes to have free enterprise within the education sector it ought to set to work immediately to boost the only competitor to private schools, that is, the schools of the government sector.

One conclusion of the minority statement that I wish to emphasise is that successive annual guidelines have moved funds away from government schools. Government schools fulfil functions that are not performed by the non-government schools. If one looks at the total range of educational services which are provided one will discover a number of things. The last time I taught in a school I taught, amongst other classes, an industrial class at the grade 10 level. I had in my class of 32 four pupils who had been expelled from a private school. As a teacher in a government school I was expected to teach those children. They were a major cause of disruption within the class and a major reason for my not being able to give adequate educational attention to the other children in that class whose parents had chosen to send to a government school.

Government schools pick up so many of our social problems that they need a differential over and above any adequate attention that is being paid to government or non-government schools. They have to pick up the handicapped in much larger numbers than the private schools do. They have to pick up far higher percentages of first year teachers than the non-government schools do. They have to provide services in remote areas, which services are incredibly expensive. Private schools do not have to do that. There is a whole range of issues but I do not want to enter a general debate on government and non-government schools. I confine myself to the fact that government schools need additional funds. They need additional funds to carry out the task, I suggest, that this society wishes to be carried out by our schools, and that is all. All that the teachers and the parents of pupils at government schools are asking for is that these schools be equipped to carry out the task imposed on them by the governments of this country. They are not asking for any special favours or any special handouts. They are not attacking the right of parents to place their children in non-government schools. They merely ask to be treated as equal citizens in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak only briefly because I believe that if there is to be an immediate response on this subject from one senator there also ought to be an opportunity for a Government senator to make a couple of comments and in due course to expand his remarks when the subject matter comes up for full debate. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard pages 261 and 262 from the 1982-84 triennial report of the Schools Commission, which was put down in this chamber in March 1981. I have asked the shadow Attorney-General to view those two pages.
