TALK.START.PARA: —I want to reflect upon that table only briefly as it relates to the minority report that has been tabled here today and the remarks that Senator Macklin has just directed to that report. The first point is that the great majority of independent or non-government schools are in the lowest resource level, according to the categories laid down by the School Commission. That level is 70 per cent of the resources of government schools. They are of a lower resource level than the government schools that Senator Macklin has sought to defend. As a Liberal, I believe that it is important that the community should make available to children adequate educational resources even if they are attending independent schools that have a lower educational resource level than government schools do.

SPEECH.PARA: My second point is that these tables give a comparison between funding to non-government schools and funding to government schools over the last four years. I ask honourable senators to give attention to the two pages I have incorporated in the Hansard record. They show that over four years State governments-some are of a Liberal persuasion and some are of a Labor persuasion-have increased recurrent support to government schools by 23.3 per cent and that support for non-government schools increased by 31.8 per cent. In other words, the need is so real that in recurrent terms greater support has been given by the States to non-government schools. The drop in State government funding for government schools over the four-year period was 35.9 per cent and the drop in Commonwealth funding was 32.5 per cent. But there was also a similar drop in capital expenditure on non-government schools. That drop amounted to 32.1 per cent. All of that contribution came from the Commonwealth because the States did not contribute anything at all in those years. So all States over the four-year period had a decrease of approximately 32 per cent in capital resources, irrespective of whether they were provided by this Government or by the Liberal and the Labor governments in the States. In any event, over the four-year period the net total increase in funding for state schools was 10.5 per cent. That is clearly set out on page 261 of the Schools Commission report. The increased funding for an independent school place is a fixed percentage of the cost of providing a state school place. So if funding for an independent school place increases it can be taken that expenditure for a state school has increased by a greater amount.

I do not welcome the minority report on this matter, especially the way in which on the final page an attempt has been made to blame this Government's so-called discrimination or divisive policy of taking money away from the state school system to give it to the independent school system. The facts of the matter are that there has been a rush of new enrolments in independent schools and this has led to a change in the emphasis of resource allocation from the government school sector to the non-government school sector. In my State of South Australia there has been a 1 per cent increase in the number of non-government school places each year for the last 10 years, and this trend will continue for the next five years because parents with their freedom of choice are deciding that that is where their children will go. The result will be reflected in terms of the financial resources that go to that sector of the community whose children are in independent schools. I bring to the Senate's attention that it is appropriate that provision be made for that group of schools at level 3 of the Schools Commission categories, those with the lowest educational resources. As a Liberal I believe we should provide those schools with something near the resources that are made available through the Commonwealth and the States to state schools.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Teague was really saying that the Government is doing pretty well. I have news for him. Hundreds of thousands of parents and teachers throughout Australia do not think so, and increasingly they are thinking this Government is doing worse and worse in respect of educational expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: There are one or two matters specifically in the minority statement on the Commonwealth Schools Commission report which I think are worthy of some comment. First, the minority report is significant because it is only the second time in the history of the Schools Commission that a minority report has been issued. The Schools Commission, by and large, when it was an independent advisory body to government, was a consensus body because when it was first established and for some period after it was the body which was recognised as changing the face of education in Australia and raising standards throughout this country. It concentrated the minds of educationists and politicians alike on the problems of the Australian schools system and on some of the solutions which could be advanced in respect of those problems. Now, under growing pressure from the present Government, the Schools Commission no longer exercises that optimistic and forward-looking function that it exercised in the past. I refer honourable senators to a couple of points in the minority report which illustrate the point I am trying to make. Page one of that report states:
The Commission Act also allows the Commission to draw attention to the effects of directives given to it and to evaluate those effects in terms of this Act.
Our disagreement with the present report is not with the advice given in relation to the former requirement but in the decision not to refer to the latter in the context of this report.
The report continues:

Guidelines to the Commission have become increasingly detailed and specific, over-riding its proposals on program policy and structure, and reducing its ability to exercise its own judgment on their implementation. This is a matter of concern for us.

I interpolate there that that should be a matter of concern to everybody interested in education in Australia. What the minority report is stating there is that the Schools Commission is no longer an independent advisory body, not even to the extent that it can discuss in its report directives given to it by government. That is shameful. That is the sort of thing which one might expect would emanate from a department headed by Dr Goebbels rather than from an instrumentality headed by Professor Tannock.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't the great majority of the Schools Commission members agree with that?
—I will come to that. They did, in the triennial report of the Schools Commission.
—They didn't agree in the minority report which is before us.
—What I am saying is that the majority of members of the Schools Commission have become ciphers and men and women of straw.
—You mean that they don't agree with you?
—No, I do not mean that. If Senator Martyr would listen a minute he might understand a little better. The point is, if I can explain it for Senator Martyr with very simple monosyllabic expressions-
—Very simple.

—It will need to be; I understand that. The point is that what the report states is that this Government issues directives to the Schools Commission, as it has done for a number of years, but now the Commission is not allowed to comment upon those directives. If Senator Martyr thinks it is a good thing for a body which is set up under a statute to be an independent advisory body to government not to be allowed to comment upon government directives, I hope he will get up in the Senate and say so because if he did that we could have a debate about the matter. But I do not think he will do so because I am sure he does not agree that we should have an independent advisory body to government which is not even able to comment on government directives to it. That is an absurd situation. The minority report went on:

SPEECH.PARA: The recent Review of Commonwealth Functions and the cumulative effects of annual guidelines have removed some discretionary powers from the Commission, endangering its ability to act as a statutory body, and suggest a view of the Commission as a department of Government.
For Senator Martyr's benefit, I stress that it suggested a view of the Commission as a department of the Government, not an independent advisory body to the Government.

I refer again to the razor gang decisions to which the report refers. We have said in the Senate on numerous occasions, and I will say it again, that the razor gang made decisions about education which will have an effect on access to education in this country, not only now but also for the remaining years of this century. These decisions concern fundamental aspects of education policy which should not have been decided upon by four Ministers-four toadies of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser)-making ideological decisions about money. They should have been decided in the context of education policy. The present Minister for Education (Mr Fife) was probably the last to hear about them and the last to have an input into any decision on what this Government feels about access to education by Australian kids and access to tertiary education by people generally. Those are important matters about which the razor gang should have had nothing to say. It was none of the razor gang's business. It is the business of education policy planners to determine what the future of present Australian children will be and what the future of children, yet unborn, will be in terms of their rights to go to school and their access to education. It was no business of the razor gang, and this minority report is quite right to say so. Later in the report reference is made to the reductions in general levels of funding for government schools over the five year period. We have talked enough about that in this chamber.

There are one or two points which I want to draw from this minority report and which ought to be of concern in any education debate. In the March 1981 triennial report of the Commonwealth Schools Commission, to which Senator Teague referred, considerable willingness was shown on all sides to compromise in the interests of community consensus, especially in regard to government and non-government schools. That was reflected in the 1981 triennial report. It was the last vestige of an effort to dampen down, as it were, the State aid debate which divided this society throughout the 1960s. The professional politicians on the other side of the chamber, who spend their time denigrating the Whitlam Government in the same way as we spend our time denigrating them, should be big enough in moments of great charity or alcoholism to acknowledge the fact that the Whitlam Government ended that State aid debate in Australian society with the establishment of the Schools Commission. The more the independence of the Schools Commission is eroded, as this Government is now doing with razor gang decisions and the sorts of things referred to in the minority report, the more some elements in this society, which I personally would not encourage, are induced to get back into that divisive State aid debate. That is something I would have thought we did not want in a society presided over by a Prime Minister who pledged himself to govern for all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't that the whole purpose of the minority report, to raise those issues you have just been talking about?

—I reckon Senator Martyr should read the minority report and then we can have an intelligent discussion on it. What I am concerned about-it is not just a concern of the minority but, I hope, also the concern of people such as Senator Martyr-is the fact that there is a danger that that consensus will now be broken, that it will be shattered. That will be the cumulative effect of what has been happening.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to refer in slightly greater detail to one section of the minority report, and that concerns the School to Work Transition Program which the report deals with. Honourable senators will remember that the School to Work Transition Program was introduced off the top of the head of a Minister of this Government. If any honourable senators have any doubts about the validity of that expression they have only to ask the Catholic education authorities in the various States, or the departments of education in the various States. They had 10 days notice prior to the introduction of the School to Work Transition Program. They were told: 'We are going to give you this money. Can you work out how you can possibly spend it?' The reason for that was that the Government had been criticised a lot about youth unemployment in Australia and felt that it had to put on a demonstration. It appropriated money for the purpose and then asked education departments in the States and the Catholic education authorities to dream up programs in order that the Government could look good. I suppose an election was looming at the time. That was what happened and most of the State education departments responded and said: 'Thank you very much. We already have our own programs going. They are going pretty well. Can we have some of the money to extend them?' The Government replied: 'No, we want new programs introduced, not programs that you have been working successfully for years. We want new programs introduced under the School to Work Transition Program'. So right from the beginning the program got away to a bad start with a lot of scepticism about it in education circles and a lot of concern about it in the Catholic education system and in the various State education systems.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the States approved the programs and got on with it.
—Yes, Senator, until the financial position was made clear.
—That is the point. In other words, the programs are good but the finances are bad.

—If I may, I will come to the point. The minority report referred to the decision to earmark substantial sums from the government schools' general recurrent and capital grants as an alternative source of funds as representing a new and serious departure in Commonwealth-State relations in education. The Fraser Government has said to the States: 'You accept our School to Work Transition Program'-a program about which the States have had very grave doubts for a long time-'and you put money into it, otherwise we will knock off money from you for the general recurrent expenditure'. I take it that this is an example of the new federalism at work-co-operative federalism, as it is sometimes called. It is politics with a bludgeon-stand and deliver.

SPEECH.PARA: In a minute I will tell Senator Teague what some of the State Ministers have had to say about this approach. It is much more important than an education issue. It is important in the education context but it is important in relation to the whole question of Commonwealth-State relations. If a Commonwealth government can say to a State government: 'Do as we tell you or we will take some money away from you somewhere else' then it indicates the end of any notion of federalism as it is properly understood in Australia. Under section 96 of the Constitution the Commonwealth can say to a State: 'We will make money available provided you spend it for certain purposes'. A State government can say to the Commonwealth: 'You keep your money; we do not want it'. As I recall, Mr Bjelke-Petersen said that to the Labor Government. Under section 96 of the Constitution a State can knock back Commonwealth money which is tied in terms of its purpose but, under this procedure of the Fraser Government, it cannot knock it back because it will lose the amount somehow anyway. Let me refer to the passages from the triennial report which deal with this question. Senator Teague will be interested in this because he referred to that report. In its minority report the Commission stated:

The Commission has been unwilling to divert part of the General Recurrent Grants Program to finance other priorities, however important they may be. To do so would be to involve States in a disruptive upheaval of ongoing programs. Severe personnel deployment problems would arise if funds diminished and the hard-won achievements in quality and in standards would be generally jeopardised. Community confidence would be shaken and much of the in-built flexibility available to States to respond to the particular needs of individual schools would be lost.

That comment was endorsed by Mr Mossenson, the Director-General of the Department of Education in Western Australia. Since then his Minister, Mr Grayden, has been highly critical of the Commonwealth Government. Mr Mossenson still signed the majority report and ignored the minority report, which Senator Martyr-I notice that he has left the chamber-has said does not have much credibility. I think it is Mr Mossenson who does not have much credibility. Senator Martyr ought to take the matter up with him when he goes back west. What did Mr Hunt, the Minister of Education in Victoria, have to say about the proposal of earmarking, as it is called; that is, putting a gun at the head of the States and telling them that they will have to do what the Commonwealth wants or they will not get any further money? I wish to refer to a few passages in a statement made by Mr Hunt dated 3 August 1981 which is called 'Resolving the Transition Fiasco'. In that document Mr Hunt set out a policy which was, he said, embarked on without regard to the views of the States or to their lack of financial capacity. It is a policy which, he said, will act to the detriment of existing State policies and programs. Mr Hunt said:
All Ministers pointed out-
That is, at the Australian Education Council meeting-

that in the financial situation which the States were facing, their education budgets were constrained and that the request to provide additional funds from State sources could only be met by dropping other valuable programmes or distorting existing priorities which they were not prepared to do. The Commonwealth accepted that situation.

At the meeting of Ministers which was held in Melbourne last year the Commonwealth accepted that situation. Mr Hunt further said that the Commonwealth had completely changed its attitude. It has embarked upon a scheme which provides for a completely arbitrary division of the funds between the TAFE sector and the school sector which is extremely difficult for the State education departments to administer and it is not necessarily relevant to the sort of strictures which they have in each of the different States. Mr Hunt went on at great length to discuss the difficulties. It is the constitutional point which I want to stress as most important.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you support the transition programs themselves? The Opposition is not against those programs?

—We have qualifications about them. I do not think one can say that one supports all the transition programs. Some of them are good; some of them are not. In relation to the Victorian Government's stand on the transition programs, Mr Hunt stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Despite this stand, it should be noted that many educationalists and community leaders have doubts about the program on a number of grounds. Firstly, some consider that the Commonwealth seems to believe it has discovered the concept, whilst the States have in fact been giving effect to it for a great many years! Secondly, they point out that the Commonwealth's contribution in the field has largely been to date by way of high sounding policies oft repeated, rather than substantial effort.

I recall that the School to Work Transition Program was introduced as a new initiative of the Fraser Government on seven different occasions. Every time the Minister went anywhere he kept introducing it as a new initiative. It was like Mussolini's Air Force: It turned up in all sorts of places but it comprised the same planes. Mussolini thought he had an enormous air force but he had only six planes. That is what the School to Work Transition Program has been like. It was introduced, on my count, seven times as a new initiative. Mr Hunt, the Liberal Minister of Education in Victoria, described it in terms of high sounding and oft repeated policies of the Commonwealth rather than substantial effort. He may be a bit of a cynic about that-I do not know-but that is his view. He went on to say:
Its financial contribution-
That is, the Commonwealth's-

so far has been marginal by comparison with that of the States. Thirdly, some people believe that there has been an undue degree of ''scape-goating'' in the exercise! Some Federal politicians have seemed to use it as an answer to unemployment or as an attempt to throw the blame for unemployment onto education systems rather than the state of the economy and the absence of employment opportunities for the young.

That is one of the matters with which I agree. I agree with the Liberal Minister of Education in Victoria about that. Some Federal politicians have used references to the School to Work Transition Program in an attempt to throw the blame for unemployment on the education systems and in an attempt to explain away youth unemployment when, in fact, there are no jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I haven't done that.

—No. I am not accusing Senator Teague of that. If he wishes, I could reel off the names of about 35 of his colleagues who have done that. That is the point about which the States properly objected. Mr Hunt continued:

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to these three criticisms three new ones have now emerged on the new basis of funding proposed by the Commonwealth . . . it is virtually impossible for the States to comply with the financial requirements and the strictures and rigidities which the Commonwealth seeks to impose. To do so would in any event seriously distort State priorities and erode existing programmes of established value.
He further stated that it was a three-card trick and finally said:
. . . the Constitutional implications of the approach which has been adopted by the Commonwealth are horrendous. It could lead to ''New Centralism'' in place of New Federalism.
He made the point that if the principle were to be applied in areas other than education the new centralism would be complete and new federalism would have gone by the board forever.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a big if.
—Of course it is a big if, but there are always big ifs. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a statement by the Victorian Minister for Education, Mr Hunt, dated 3 August 1981.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
3rd August, 1981
Victorian Education Minister Mr. A. J. Hunt
RESOLVING THE TRANSITION FIASCO

The Commonwealth's ''offer'' to the States on transition education for the year 1982 is unacceptable to every State. It is not an offer at all: it is an attempt to impose a Commonwealth policy on States and to force them to contribute equally with the Commonwealth to the implementation of that policy, without regard to their views or to the lack of financial capacity in the States to take that course without detriment to existing State policies and programmes.
In other words, the States must forego their own programmes for the sake of implementing a Commonwealth programme under pain of financial disability if they fail to do so.

The guidelines give the impression that the Commonwealth is providing $75m. in 1982 for transition education. In fact, the Commonwealth is providing only $27m. (i.e. $4m more than in 1981) to Government schools for this purpose. $2m. is being provided to non Government schools. The States are being required to provide a matching $27m from their own funds and if they fail to do so their general recurrent grants will be docked accordingly. This is called ''ear marking'', and is a way of reminding the States that the Commonwealth collects the revenues and can call the shots. In other words, if the States do not participate at all their general recurrent grants will be reduced by $27m anyway! If they find only $13 1/2m their general recurrent grants will be reduced by $13m.

In addition, the States are being required to find $19m. from their building programmes-which have already been seriously depleted as a result of Commonwealth Loan Council restraints-and to apply this sum towards capital works or equipment which will assist in transition and to do so regardless of the urgency and priority of other building projects. Again, the ''ear marking'' approach is used to enforce compliance.
Thus, the so-called $75m for transition is made up as follows:
$m Commonwealth Transition Funds 27 Contribution by States to programmes enforced by 'ear marking' 27 Similar re-direction of State Capital funds 19 Commonwealth funds for non-Government schools 2
Total 75
Seen in this light, the offer is hardly as magnanimous as may have first appeared.

The concept of forcing the States in this way is absolutely new in Federal/State relations. When a tied grant is offered under Section 96 of the Constitution (whether or not subject to equal or percentage matching by the State) the State has the right to accept or reject it. In this case the State is being given no opportunity even to reject-for if a State says that it is financially unable to participate because of its existing priorities, it loses funds equal to that which the Commonwealth desires it to spend. This is worse than blackmail: it is plain extortion. It is contrary to the concept of the Constitution and of a Federal compact, contrary to the whole course of past financial relationships between the Commonwealth and the States and completely contrary to the objectives of the New Federalism policies upon which the Fraser Government came into office.

It appears to be a new Treasury device now tried for the first time in the education field which, if accepted or accomplished, would quickly spread to other fields. It could clearly be applied across the whole gamut of State responsibilities to impose the views and policies of the Commonwealth Government of the day upon the States and to enforce the implementation of its policies by the States, regardless of the results of their own Elections and of the policies and priorities of their Governments.

The course being taken is all the more astonishing in view of the results of a meeting of the Australian Education Council (comprising Education Ministers of the Commonwealth and all States) held in Melbourne last year. At that meeting all States advised the Commonwealth that they welcomed the injection of additional Federal funds into the education system to be used specifically for improving programmes to prepare young people for the workplace and life after leaving school. The States all informed the Commonwealth that they already undertook considerable work and expended substantial funds in this area and could not afford further contributions from their own resources. Thus, only the funds provided by the Commonwealth could enable extra effort in this field and those funds could not be wholly or partly matched by the States. All ministers pointed out that in the financial situation which the States were facing, their education budgets were constrained and that the request to provide additional funds from State sources could only be met by dropping other valuable programmes or distorting existing priorities which they were not prepared to do. The Commonwealth accepted that situation.
The stance now adopted by the Commonwealth reneges completely on last year's accord.

Furthermore the scheme as now proposed by the Commonwealth is hedged in with conditions that make it an administrative nightmare or perhaps impossibility. Half must be spent in TAFE and half in schools-a completely arbitrary division which will create serious inflexibilities. It does not recognise the different ways in which the Education Departments of the different States have evolved to meet their respective and differing needs. It does not recognise the system of secondary technical education which is unique to Victoria and which undertakes a very great deal of work entrusted to TAFE in other States.

Then again, one-third of the $27m. envisaged by way of expenditure in the State school sector must be by way of cash grants to individual schools at the rate of $10 per pupil. This creates serious inflexibility and disregards both the concept of need and the nature and value of the programme in the individual school. To date, transition programmes have been developed for the purposes for which the funds were originally envisaged, viz., to assist those young people who are most likely to be at risk. This has meant that programmes have largely been developed in the areas of greatest deprivation and greatest youth unemployment. They have been specifically designed to assist young people in those areas to seek a place in the workforce and to remedy some of the disadvantage which they suffer as compared with young people in more affluent areas, whom the records show have greater prospects of employment. Furthermore, local and regional committees have co-operated to ensure that of the many submissions made, the programmes adopted and implemented have been those of greatest value to those most in need. No programme has been adopted simply to spend funds; but this will inevitably occur, at least in some cases, in the event of automatic payments to schools.

The inflexibility in State educational building programmes which is already of great concern in all States, will now become horrific. Commonwealth control of State borrowings for capital works through the Loan Council has meant progressively less to the States in real terms throughout the last five years. The States' capacities to undertake capital works programmes over that period have been virtually halved. In the education field this has been compounded by a reduction in real terms in the capital funds available to State education from the Commonwealth. The result has been that the State efforts in the capital field have of necessity been increasingly directed to the provision of new pupil places in areas where these are most urgently needed. The progress of major maintenance and the upgrading of old and sometimes sub-standard schools, has already been seriously retarded. The provision of desirable facilities such as libraries, home economics rooms, assembly halls, gymnasiums and activity centres, has been set back.

All States have found that commitments made in good faith on the basis of past funding, cannot-on the basis of capital funding which now applies-be provided for a considerable time or even in the foreseeable future. The re-direction of $19m. in capital to transition projects will further distort these programmes and further postpone essential works, even where there have been firm commitments. Community expectations may as a result be shattered without any guarantee of corresponding advantage to the same or any other community, or to its youth! And the States rather than the Commonwealth will get the blame! No reason whatever has even been advanced by the Commonwealth for this strange and unnecessary requirement.

Furthermore, the Commonwealth clearly still fails to recognise the extent of the very substantial State contributions to transition education in the sense of education for working life. In Victoria, the whole of the apprenticeship programme and the greater part of the work of secondary technical schools are directed to this end, as are substantial programmes in high schools and the majority of TAFE programmes. Victoria now has careers teachers and career education programmes throughout is high and technical schools and conducts a highly successful Work Experience programme as well as Link Courses and Shared Resources programmes. In addition the Victorian Institute of Secondary Education is devoted entirely to facilitating the movement of students from school to work or for further study.

The cost of the unique Victorian technical school system-which is almost entirely devoted to transition education-is $270m., whilst the cost of the other activities mentioned takes the direct and indirect expenditure of Victoria on transition to roughly $300m. This surely makes the $7.4m. now offered by the Commonwealth to Victoria look miniscule by comparison and the strictures accompanying it somewhat petty and ridiculous.

In 1981 Victoria is due to receive $6.7m. from the Commonwealth for transition, unmatched by the State except of course as to the substantial effort mentioned above. In 1982, under the Commonwealth's proposals, Victoria should receive $7.4m. in Commonwealth funds for the same purpose-an increase of $700,000. In return the State must provide $6m. from its depleted capital works programme for transition works or equipment and $7.4m. contribution towards transition programmes, in addition to meeting the increased costs arising from inflation in respect of the substantial existing effort already described. We simply cannot afford to do this.

The Victorian Government fully recognises the vital importance of education for the workplace and for life after leaving school. As it has already demonstrated, it is willing to assist in the Commonwealth's policy of further upgrading effort in this field through the most effective expenditure of additional Commonwealth funds available. Victoria simply seeks the capacity to do so, without shackles that make the task impossible.

Despite this stand, it should be noted that many educationists and community leaders have doubts about the programme on a number of grounds. Firstly, some consider that the Commonwealth seems to believe it has discovered the concept, whilst the States have in fact been giving effect to it for a great many years! Secondly, they point out that the Commonwealth's contribution in the field has largely been to date by way of high sounding policies oft repeated, rather than substantial effort. Its financial contribution so far has been marginal by comparison with that of the States. Thirdly, some people believe that there has been an undue degree of ''scape-goating'' in the exercise. Some Federal politicians have seemed to use it as an answer to unemployment, or as an attempt to throw the blame for unemployment onto education systems rather than the state of the economy and the absence of employment opportunities for the young.

In addition to these three criticisms, three new ones have now emerged on the new basis of funding proposed by the Commonwealth: fourthly it is virtually impossible for the States to comply with the financial requirements and the strictures and rigidities which the Commonwealth seeks to impose. To do so would in any event seriously distort State priorities and erode existing programmes of established value. Fifthly, the financing is a three card trick upon the States and misleads the public as to the extent of the Commonwealth effort. As seen, Victoria must find an additional $13.4m. to get $7.4m.-or more correctly, to get a mere $700,000 more from the Commonwealth than it received in 1981. Sixthly, the Constitutional implications of the approach which has been adopted by the Commonwealth are horrendous. It could lead to ''New Centralism'' in place of New Federalism.

The unnecessary and unreasonable inflexibilities inherent in the proposal must be removed, and the requirement for further payment by the States, regardless of their existing effort, must be abandoned as agreed last year. When that occurs, the programme will operate in its true perspective as an effort by the Commonwealth to contribute in a modest way to the achievement of further results in this field. Until that does occur, no State can afford to accept the ''offer''.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minority statement concludes with a statement of commitment to principles, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . COMPELS US TO:
(a) alert the Government to the divisive effects of the Guidelines and the resurgence of the State Aid debate . . .
I concur; the Opposition has concurred with that view for some time. The statement continues:
(b) state that a major contributing factor to that is the decision of the Government not to adopt the recommendations of the last two triennial reports.
That is a matter for debate. It goes on:

(c) point out that successive annual Guidelines have provided increased levels of funding to non-government schools while depleting the funding of government schools for which, according to the Act, the Government (and the Commission) have a primary obligation.
(d) draw attention to the dislocation which will occur within government school systems by funding the Transition Education Program, from earmarked general purpose funds.

That is an observation with which we in the Opposition certainly concur. In paragraph (e) they ask the Government to reconsider its decision in relation to two matters involving the level and assessment of funding.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Australian delegation to the Inter-Parliamentary Union for 1980 for the Spring meeting in Oslo and the sixty-seventh conference in East Berlin.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Last year I and the then Senator the Honourable Justin O'Byrne were representatives from this chamber at the Inter-parliamentary Union Conference in East Berlin. One gains many impressions at conferences such as that, and one of the main impressions I came away with was the high standing in which Australia is held at such an international forum. I think it fair to say that that is a reflection on the delegations that have represented Australia. For the past three years Dr Harry Edwards has been the leader of the delegation and the Honourable C. K. Jones the deputy leader. They are held in high regard because of the way they handle the delegation and put Australia's case. Of course, they do not always agree in that forum. It was quite interesting to note how some of the countries looked aghast at the Australian delegation when the leader got up and put one case and the deputy leader got up and put a contrary case. They could not understand that at the end of the day we were still all basically good friends. Such is the calibre of our leader and deputy leader that Australia's standing there is very high. That is one of the major impressions I received.

SPEECH.PARA: My position was on the political committee, which dealt with three major matters. The first was the occupation by Russia of Afghanistan. It was interesting that, although we were literally in the front yard of the Eastern bloc, there was no support for Russia's operation other than from its own cohorts. The Third World was quite trenchant in its denunciation of the invasion of Afghanistan. It was quite an interesting battle of tactics because we knew, and the whole world knew, our position and the position of the Western bloc. So the focus of attention was on the delegations from the Third World countries. Because obviously we did not want the Third World countries to appear to be operating in cohesion with us, we literally sat back and noted the position they took. The Third World took a very positive position on this unwarranted invasion. As was the case in this House, even though we had our differences over that invasion, there was a general consensus at the IPU about the condemnation of such an action. As I said before, it was interesting to see how trenchant the Third World was in its denunciation of that action.

We were asked to come up with a declaration on a zone of peace for the Indian Ocean. I confess that I tried to get out of being on the drafting committee but, as I indicated before, Australia is held in high regard so we were drafted on to that committee. Being on that committee was an interesting experience for me. We formed a small sub-committee of nine members to come up with a form of words with which all people could agree. Recognising the problems that existed, recognising that at that time Iran was holding the American diplomats, recognising that India had exploded a nuclear bomb and that Pakistan appeared to be on the way to doing so, yet we were able to come up with an agreed form of words on a zone of peace in the Indian Ocean. To complicate matters, while we were there Iraq and Iran, which up to that stage were arguing, actually broke out into active hostilities. It was felt that we could not come away from such a Union meeting without making reference to that. Of course, that was early days and we did not set out, with the information we had, to apportion blame. The Australian delegation was asked to come up with a resolution-we had quite a few co-sponsors-and the resolution was put to the full plenary session and carried. As I said, we did not apportion blame. Rather, we wanted to acknowledge that there was a conflict between two states, one a member of the IPU, and point out that they should solve their disputes by other than hostile means.

In conclusion, I place on record my appreciation of the two officers who served us. Mr Bert Nicholls, from the Department of the Senate, has concluded his work with the IPU delegation. Miss Sue Boyd, a parliamentary liaison officer with the Department of Foreign Affairs, will conclude her work at the end of the forthcoming meeting in Cuba. Both officers have served us very well. Mr Nicholls, with his unique ability in administration and knowledge of proceedings, saw that everything was done well. Miss Boyd had a great knowledge of Australia's attitude on many issues that arose. More particularly, her ability to speak four languages came in very handy. At one stage when I was in the political committee meeting she was able to converse in French with the Algerians on our left and in German with the Austrians on our right. It certainly made negotiations a lot easier when we were drafting resolutions. As a back-up, Sue also speaks Portuguese, which meant that we had entree to South American delegations when that was needed. I think that should be on record. I place on record my appreciation and, I am sure, the appreciation of all those members who have been a part of the IPU delegations in years past, of both Mr Bert Nicholls and Miss Sue Boyd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Honourable senators have shown keen interest in scientific work which the Government has commissioned in an effort to answer some of the questions being asked by Australian veterans about the relationship of service in Vietnam to their state of health. At an early stage of these parliamentary sittings I would therefore like to give the Senate a brief progress report. As is well known, the Commonwealth Institute of Health in Sydney has carried out a considerable amount of work in preparation for a major epidemiological survey. An essential precursor to any such survey is a pilot study to assess the feasibility of gathering medical and other information from both Vietnam veteran and control groups, the relative merits of different data collection methods and administrative procedures. The Institute's basic data collection and coding work for the pilot study is at an advanced stage. The response from veterans is considered to have been very good, particularly in the case of the telephone and home interviews. The next phase of the pilot study involves several months analysis before a report assessing the various approaches can be made.

SPEECH.PARA: The question continues to be posed from some quarters as to why the Government will not be making public the analyses made in the pilot study. For the sake of clarity, let me repeat the reason: The pilot study involves a sample of only 300 veterans who served in Vietnam and 300 who did not. Scientifically valid results could simply not be expected from such a small sample. Some of the information from the Institute's work which will be able to be made public is that which emerges from the mortality study. It is expected that results from this study, which will analyse the causes and rates of death in veterans, should be available before the middle of next year. The Government has been conscious of the need to try to get some additional information on matters of acute concern to the community, particularly since it is likely that most other results from a major epidemiological study would not be available before 1983. After detailed consultation with its scientific advisers, it has identified a possible new line of approach in an area which is perhaps the one of the greatest single worry to veterans and their families, that of birth defects. I have now asked the Commonwealth Institute of Health to explore urgently the feasibility of a study of congenital anomalies diagnosed at birth, by means of a case-control study in which the Institute would hope to have the cooperation of major obstetric hospitals in Australia. If, as I hope, this project proves to be realisable, it will represent a valid, economical and relatively quick means of obtaining guidance on whether service in the Australian Army in Vietnam is associated with an increased risk of birth defects. While continuing work on the projects already announced, the Government will be examining the possibility of initiating any other studies which have the prospect of answering questions about the relationship of veterans' health to their Vietnam service. Along with the array of measures available under the repatriation system, and the newly announced counselling service, this scientific work is seen as an integral part of the Government's total effort to help in the resolution of veterans' problems.
I seek leave to move that the Senate take note of the statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome at least some statement from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) in relation to Vietnam veterans. Veterans in Australia have now been told that they must wait until at least 1983 for anything to come from the study being undertaken by the Commonwealth Institute of Health. It seems at least that the Government has recognised the inadequacy of the study currently under way and is seeking to rectify that mistake by engaging in other studies which are more relevant to the veterans themselves. I have previously characterised as a confidence trick, the start of this study last year for the 45,000 or so veterans of the Vietnam war. I do not withdraw that because I believe that that study, in pure research terms, cannot be substantiated. Nor is it possible that that study will help individual veterans unless the repatriation tribunals accept the results as applying to individuals. As honourable senators will know, any statistical study refers only to the totality and not to the individual.

SPEECH.PARA: But there is an even more important problem with the study, and I refer to the control group. As honourable senators are well aware, Australia makes great use of the types of chemicals which were used in Vietnam. Indeed, in my own State we dip our oranges in them in response to a recommendation from the Department of Primary Industry. But where precisely are there, even in a pilot study, 300 people who have not been exposed to these chemicals? The whole point of a control group, as anybody who has undertaken any research will know, is to get a group of people who are not subject to the variety of effects that one is attempting to study. How precisely-we are not told in the Minister's statement although we have asked time and again-are the research people undertaking to get a group of people who have not been exposed either to 2, 4, 5-T or 2, 4-D? Where do they exist in Australia and how do we know they have not been exposed? Unless we can get that control group we will not be able to get an effective statistical study.

The latest figures that I have available indicate that we use somewhere in the order of 2,000 tonnes of 2, 4-D and 300 tonnes of 2, 4, 5-T annually in this country for a variety of agricultural purposes and for a variety of cleansing operations. It may very well be that even in the centre of Sydney we could pick a group of people who could be affected by a number of these chemicals. This is of extreme concern, I would suggest, not so much to honourable senators here, who are not affected by this problem, but to the veterans and their families. They cannot wait until 1983 for the results of the study. I have met a number of them and I am sure the Minister has also. The personal problems of those families are enormous. There is the problem of the breadwinner not being able to control his temper and the effect that that has on his wife and children. There is the problem of constant rashes and itches and the problem of not being able to concentrate. Those problems affect not only the veterans but also their parents, families and friends. It is their friends who see, as I have seen, a mother become insane because she blamed herself for the death of her child. That happened before she knew that the child's death may have been due to other causes.

I appeal to the Minister and to the Government to put aside this particular study and wait no longer to assist those veterans; to accept now that we have sufficient evidence that they are being affected by the things that occurred in Vietnam. If it turns out in 1983 that we were wrong, that money still will have been well spent on them. What does it matter? I am sure nobody in Australia would begrudge the expenditure of that amount of money on our veterans, on those types of people who are quite willing to go along with the Government and the Government's policy and to fight for this country in a war which many other senators and I opposed. Nevertheless, although I was opposed to that war I am not opposed to the veterans. I am not opposed to those people who felt it was their duty to serve. I am not opposed to spending money-and neither is anybody else in this country-to assist those people in their hour of need. Their hour of need is now. It is not 1983.

I suggest that the Government no longer seek to continue this study as a mechanism whereby in 1983 we will be able to say that statistically our veterans have a range of problems not of the same order as found within the rest of the population of the country. We already know that. I would much prefer that the Minister put his energies into those other matters which he mentioned within the statement and looked and moved urgently to assist those veterans and their families. He should accept without further study the problems they have and give the Vietnam veterans in this country the type of support and assistance that every senator knows they are appealing to us for every day whether it be personally, by letter or by telephone. If the Minister has not received those requests I am quite willing to supply him with them.

DEBATE.TITLE: QUEENSLAND ABORIGINALS AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDERS (SELF-MANAGEMENT AND LAND RIGHTS) BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Ryan) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act providing for the granting of self-management and traditional land in Queensland for the benefit of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders and for other purposes.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Before I commence the second reading speech I point out to honourable senators that the copy of the second reading speech which has been circulated has a mistake in the page order. Pages 4 and 5 should be reversed and they will be reversed in subsequent printing of this speech.

I introduce this Bill as a private member, but with the full support of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party and of the Australian Democrats. I am happy to acknowledge the support and co-operation of the Australian Democrats, in particular of the spokesman on Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Macklin.
Description of the Bill

This legislation is specifically designed to respond to the announced intention of the Queensland Government to abolish Aboriginal reserves in Queensland. It will make possible the granting of freehold title to Aboriginals for land which constituted Aboriginal reserves as at 31 March 1978. The major provisions of the Bill are: An optional system of self-management which will not be able to be circumvented by the Queensland Government; the ability to make a land rights claim in respect of the reserves; power for the Federal Minister to acquire the claimed land from the Queensland Government under the Lands Acquisition Act 1955; the setting up of an Aboriginal land trust in respect of each reserve acquired; minerals to remain the property of the State but mining to be allowed only if either the land trust agrees or where both Houses of the national Parliament pass a resolution that mining must go ahead in the national interest; and where mining does proceed the Aboriginal owners of the land to be entitled to compensation.

I point out to the Senate that none of the principles of this Bill is radical or new. They have all been espoused in legislation enacted by the Parliament; that is, in the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 or in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders (Queensland Reserves and Committees Self-management Act) 1978. The course of action set out in the Bill was recommended by the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitution and Legal Affairs, November 1978. The principles upon which this Act is based were also reaffirmed by the Senate when it passed on 20 February 1975 the following motion moved by Senator Bonner:

The Senate accepts the fact that . . . Aborigines . . . were in possession of this entire nation . . . (and) urges the Australian Government to admit prior ownership . . . and . . . to compensate . . . Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders for dispossession of their land.

I must point out that the provisions in this Bill do not attempt to deal with the question of the land rights of Queensland Aboriginals in its entirety, much less with the general question of land for Aboriginals living in other States of Australia and the Australian Capital Territory. Those questions remain to be addressed, and it is not intended that this legislation will preclude any further legislative action to provide Aboriginal land rights in Queensland or elsewhere. This Bill applies only to reserve lands. The 3,048,917 hectares comprising the land area of Queensland Aboriginal reserves amounts to 1.8 per cent of the total Queensland land area of 172,000,000 hectares. When the various Torres Strait island reserves are added to the Aboriginal reserves the percentage of Queensland land areas affected is approximately 2 per cent. Surely there can be no argument that the claim of 2 per cent of Queensland for Aboriginals is anything other than a reasonable claim.
Brief History of Aboriginal Reserve Lands in Queensland

We must remind ourselves that a bloody war was waged across the Australian continent by the British colonialists in order to wrest it from its indigenous inhabitants, the Aboriginal people. In Queensland, as in other States, European settlement was achieved by the violent eviction and dispossession of Aboriginal people from every region where white settlers chose to live. Aboriginal resistance was met with brute force by white settlers using the superior power of the gun against spear and club. Mass poisonings were common. For example, at Kilcoy, Queensland in 1842, 60 Aboriginals were poisoned by flour laced with strychnine in retaliation for the killing of two white men and a prize bull. In Queensland alone there are records of mass poisonings at Laidley, North Pine River, McIntyre River, Warrego, Maroochy River, Maryborough, and so the list goes on.

Even greater numbers of Aboriginal people were murdered by indiscriminate shooting parties. In the nineteenth century it was common practice by squatters and authorities alike to avenge the death of each European with the slaughter of up to 50 Aboriginals-men, women and children. The history of nineteenth century Queensland is riddled with records of such massacres. By 1880 Aboriginal people-deprived of their rivers, their hunting grounds and their land, devastated by alcohol and opium and by introduced diseases such as syphillis and leprosy, and decimated by the murderous vengeance of white settlers-were in danger of total extermination.

I recount this sad and deplorable chapter in Australian history because to understand the current stand by Queensland Aborigines, their angry refusal to accept leases to their land and their demand for land rights, it is necessary to appreciate the circumstances under which Aboriginal people lost their land. In 1897 the Queensland Aboriginals Protection and Restriction of the Sale of Opium Act was passed. This legislation empowered the Government to move Aboriginals forcibly on to reserves and to keep them there. Over the next 50 years the governments of Queensland attempted to move the entire Aboriginal population on to reserve lands.

The 1897 legislation also embodied a comprehensive legislative denial of Aboriginals' fundamental human rights. The Act provided for control over freedom of movement, the right to seek employment, the right to wages or moneys, the care, custody and education of children and the practice of rites and customs in respect of Aboriginals. Control over most of these was vested in the local 'Protectors'-usually the local police. They could imprison Aboriginals without trial for breaking regulations or for failing to maintain good order. Amendents to the Act were passed in 1901 in order to curtail the rapidly growing half-caste population which the Queensland Government regarded as highly undesirable. Protectors were given the right to control marriage of female Aboriginals, and visitors to reserves were prohibited. Concern over the 'half-caste problem', as it was called, continued until, in 1934, a further amending Act made sexual intercourse between an Aboriginal woman and a non-Aboriginal man an offence. Such was the regime on Aboriginal reserves.

Between 1927 and 1971 a series of Acts was passed through the Queensland Parliament providing and modifying specific laws in respect of Aboriginals. Some of the more outrageous violations of human rights, such as the right to control marriage, were withdrawn in the 1965 Act and in 1966 regulations formally establishing Aboriginal councils were introduced. However, overall the position of Queensland Aboriginals and particularly of those on reserves has remained one of significant disadvantage and restriction of freedom.

The Acts currently governing Queensland Aboriginals and their life on reserves are the Aborigines Act and the Torres Strait Islanders Act, passed in 1971 and amended in 1974, 1975 and 1979. These Acts implement significant violations of the human rights and freedoms of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders in the following ways:
Aboriginal reserve councils do not have control of access to reserves; reserve managers retain veto powers over who comes and goes.
Residence on reserves is a privilege, revocable at any time by the Minister.
Aborigines on reserves can still be required to work for token payment.

Transactions entered into by Aboriginals may be varied or cancelled by the Director of the Department of Aboriginal and Islander Affairs, a provision which can seriously inhibit people from entering into any agreement with an Aboriginal or an Islander.

Court proceedings for Queensland Aborigines on reserves are conducted according to rules different from those of other courts; for example, representation is allowed only 'subject to the consent of the court'.

It is clear that the Queensland Acts and their regulations and by-laws represent a fundamental violation of human rights and are in contravention of Australia's obligations under international conventions, such as the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, for which Australia voted in the United Nations General Assembly 1948, and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights signed and ratified by Australia.
Why This Act

The Federal Government has come into conflict with the Queensland Government over Queensland's treatment of Aboriginal people on numerous occasions. The passage by the Whitlam Government of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders (Queensland Discriminatory Laws) Act 1975 and the passage by the Fraser Government of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders (Queensland Reserves and Communities Self-management) Act 1978 reflect attempts by Federal governments, in line with their constitutional responsibility, to protect the rights of Aboriginal Australians. As documented in the reports of the Commissioner for Community Relations, the Queensland Government under Mr Bjelke-Petersen has consistently failed to uphold the rights of Queensland Aboriginals. Mr Bjelke-Petersen's Government is responsible, for example, for the refusal to transfer land titles to Aboriginal land purchasers, thus Aboriginals in Queensland have been prevented from purchasing freehold land.

Mr Bjelke-Petersen's announcement during the last Queensland election campaign that he would repeal the iniquitous Aborigines and Torres Strait Islander Acts was welcomed by the Federal Opposition. However, Mr Bjelke-Petersen's indication that he would also abolish Aboriginal reserves in Queensland by de-gazettal under the Queensland Lands Act, was not. Aboriginal people in Queensland have made it quite clear that a system of 50-year leases, proposed by the Premier is unacceptable to them. Such a system fails to give Aboriginals any security of tenure. It also fails to recognise the Aboriginal people's prior ownership of the land and the injustice of their present dispossessed state.

As I have already stated, this legislation embodies only those principles already enacted in pieces of legislation that have passed through this Senate. It is in line with, and is in fact a logical consequence of, Senator Bonner's 1975 motion passed by the Senate to recognise the prior ownership of the Australian continent by the Aboriginal people. It has been drafted in response to calls from Aboriginal people and it has been drafted in consultation with Aboriginal people. Not only did Aboriginal people lobby for this Bill, but I also had representations from hundreds of fair minded non-Aboriginal Australians, and from numerous churches and other organisations, including: The Uniting Church; the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace; the Australian Council of Churches; the Aboriginal Advancement League of Victoria; the National Campaign for Land Rights and Self-management in Queensland; Action for Aboriginal Rights, Victoria; the Jamieson Division of Social Justice and Ecumenical Mission-Uniting Church, Victoria; the Diocesan Synod-Anglican Diocese of Rockhampton; Fairplay, Queensland; the Australian Student Christian Movement; Tamaresk Presbytery-Uniting Church in Australia; the Queensland Association of Professional Anthropologists and Archaeologists; and the Northern Queensland Land Council. The Bill is in line with the major recommendation of the recent World Council of Churches report entitled 'Justice for Aboriginal Australians'.

The necessity for Federal action on this issue has been exhaustingly investigated by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in its 1978 Report on Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders on Queensland Reserves. That bipartisan Committee found:

74. The Committee notes that, since the amendment of the Constitution in 1967 to give the Commonwealth Parliament power to make laws with respect to Aboriginals, most attempts have failed to achieve any co-operative arrangement with the Queensland Government regarding management and control of the affairs of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders in that State and the current agreement in respect of local government arrangements cannot, as yet, be seen as successful or as generally acceptable to the residents of Aurukun and Mornington Island. The Committee accordingly bases its recommendations regarding Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders in Queensland on the assumption that co-operation between the Commonwealth and Queensland is not likely to provide a full and sufficient discharge of Commonwealth obligations to Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders in Queensland and that some unilateral action by the Commonwealth will therefore be likely to be necessary.

75. In cases where the effective management and control of their own affairs by Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders requires the continued occupation of specific lands by those people, the Committee considers that some acquisition of property must form part of the legislative scheme.

The Senate is entitled to an explanation of why I am introducing this private member's Bill in this form at this time. The answer is that Queensland Aboriginals living on reserves are facing a crisis, a crisis which is likely to be resolved against their interests by the Government of Queensland, a crisis which can only be resolved in their interests and in the interests of justice if the Federal Parliament acts.

I have documented the long history of abuse and oppression of the residents of Aboriginal reserves in Queensland. In recent years this Senate has had further evidence of the determination of the present Government of Queensland to deny to Aboriginal reserve dwellers the two things they asked for, the two things to which they are indisputably entitled. They asked for and they are entitled to, self-management; they asked for and they are entitled to freehold ownership of their land. Neither of these requests will be met unless the Federal Government meets them.

We saw in the events affecting the Aurukun and Mornington Island communities in 1978 that the Queensland Government was not prepared to allow a system of untrammelled self-management. We know, because the Premier of Queensland has said it publicly time and time again in recent weeks, that he and his Government are bitterly opposed to freehold title for Aboriginals on reserves. We know that whatever leasing system he is prepared to introduce after the degazettal of the reserves, that leasing system will not meet the demands of Aboriginal people for fair and just treatment.

In taking this action I am acting in accordance with the constitutional responsibility of the Federal Parliament as established by the referendum on Aboriginal rights in 1967. I am acting according to established legal principles and the recommendations of a standing committee of this Senate. I also have the support of a number of major church and Aboriginal welfare organisations. Further, I am acting in accordance with the policy of the Australian Labor Party and in co-operation with and with the full support of the Australian Democrats. Most importantly I am acting according to the expressed wishes of Aboriginal people in Queensland at a time when their own State Government refuses to do this.

There is no constitutional reason, no legal reason, no philosophical reason, why Government senators should not support this initiative. There is an overwhelmingly practical political reason why they should. If the Senate passes this legislation and sends it to the House of Representatives for consideration by the people's House then surely the Government will respond positively. There is an urgent character to my initiative. The threatened degazettal of the reserves is imminent and we saw in 1978 how quickly the Queensland Government can act in order to pursue its policy of denying land rights to its Aboriginal citizens.

Also contributing to the urgent character of this initiative is the imminence of an important international event to be held in this country. I refer, of course, to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting to be held in Melbourne from 28 September and hosted by the Australian Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). The recent history of the Commonwealth, and a very honourable history it has been in recent years, has been one of eliminating colonialism, supporting independence for indigenous populations of former colonies and opposing racism in all its forms, including its most obnoxious form of apartheid. I believe it is entirely proper and timely that this Senate should act in accordance with this recent proud history of the Commonwealth. By supporting this Bill, the Senate will contribute to the banishing of the remnants of colonialism in this country, to the recognition of the rights of the indigenous population and to the elimination of racism and the conditions in which racism can flourish.

I present this initiative as a positive step in a spirit of co-operation. I have acknowledged the full co-operation in this matter by the Australian Democrats. I believe that they are to be congratulated and that their action in this matter so early in their history as a political party of significance does them great honour and credit. I hope for the co-operation of Government senators, many of whom have expressed in this place the same sentiments which motivate my action. I commend this Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

Motion (by Senator Siddons) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to encourage the introduction of industrial democracy in Australian enterprises through reductions in company tax for enterprises classified as industrial democracy enterprises.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill, which I foreshadowed in my maiden speech, is designed to encourage the introduction of industrial democracy in Australian enterprises. The Australian Democrats believe the participation of employees in making decisions which affect their work place is a basic democratic right and as important as the right to vote. It was Lawrence of Arabia who said: 'We were fighting for freedom, the second of man's creeds'. He was, of course, referring to the desert battle that eventually won political freedom for the Arabs. Those who have read The Seven Pillars of Wisdom will have some appreciation of the excitement and exhilaration of that struggle.

There is, however, another freedom equally important which can be won only by careful thought and attention to detail. I refer to the humanisation of the work place, to an organisational structure that frees people to use their qualities of imagination, initiative, technical expertise, sociability and leadership during the eight-hour working day. Nothing, certainly not money, can compensate for eight hours of monotonous, mind-killing work. If people are not free to use their human qualities during the eight-hour work day, continued industrial strife is inevitable. The humanisation of the work place is one of the greatest challenges facing Australia and the Western world today, and likely to face it for the rest of this century.

Unfortunately, there are no hard and fast rules on how this can be achieved, but there are principles which, if adopted, lead us in the right direction. This Bill is designed to encourage companies to adopt these principles and work out how they can be specifically applied in their organisations. The principles are: A cellular organisational structure, profit sharing, employee share ownership and consultative councils.

The Bill calls for the setting up of a seven-member industrial democracy board which would have three members nominated by the Minister for Industrial Relations, three nominated by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and one nominated by the President of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, all for terms of three years. The board would be supported by a small secretariat. The board would create and maintain a register of industrial democracy enterprises, which would be available for public inspection. The register would list each enterprise which, in the opinion of the board, substantially complied with the criteria laid out in the Bill.

These criteria are: That at least 14 per cent of the issued share capital of the enterprise is owned by employees or held by employees under contract of sale through an employee share purchase trust; that the activities of the enterprise are carried out through autonomous working groups based on profit centres within the enterprise; that a profit sharing scheme has been established in the enterprise; and that a consultative council has been established. We believe these criteria are achievable, but we recognise that in virtually all enterprises considerable reorganisation would be required. In this legislation's first year of operation it is thus likely that only a small number of enterprises would be able to satisfy the criteria, but over a period of years more and more would see the value of this enlightened approach.

I would like now to examine the criteria in some detail and to discuss briefly the reasons why they have been advanced. Fourteen per cent of the issued share capital of the enterprise, or about one-seventh, seems to us to be a reasonable proportion which most companies and their employees could afford. For example, a company which had 1,000 employees and 20 million 50c shares would be required to sell 2.8 million shares to its employees, which means they would receive 2,800 each. If these were bought over five years, it would cost the employees $280 a year or $5.39 a week. However, under the procedure we have outlined, they would receive a dividend on the shares in full, so they would not be out of pocket to any great extent.

Alternatively, the shares could be bought over a period of 10 years, in which case the company would have to declare only a 12.5 per cent dividend, allowing for average income tax of 20 per cent, for employees to enjoy a rate of return equal to their cash outlay in the first year. Once the shares were fully paid for, the employee shareholders would continue to profit as would any shareholder. Employee share ownership achieves an important synthesis between labour and capital. For too long Australia has been bedevilled by a confrontationist approach to industrial relations. Industrial democracy is an important step on the road to industrial relations sense, of which this country desperately needs a large dose.

Employee share ownership is not enough by itself. We believe worker involvement should and could go further, to the shop floor and throughout the enterprise. Overseas and Australian experience has shown the enormous value of autonomous working groups based on profit centres within the enterprise. One need cite only the example of Japan to be aware of the advantages of such an approach. Experience has shown that these groups are most effective when they have between 10 and 50 members.

The Bill also provides for a consultative council to have half of its members elected by secret ballot of employees and half nominated by the management of the enterprise, with an alternating chairman. The council will have the function of discussing, and making recommendations to the management in respect of such things as working conditions, safety, long term planning, budgeting and internal decision-making processes. The council-I stress this-will not discuss, or make recommendations in respect of, matters directly concerning awards or rates of pay, or other matters which should be considered by trade unions.

The board would have the power to refuse registration, or to deregister enterprises which did not provide such information as the board considered necessary to inform its judgments with reasonable notice. The key point of the Bill is that tax payable by companies which satisfied the criteria of the board would be reduced by 8 per cent. Before honourable senators jump to conclusions about the cost of such a proposal, let me explain that we believe the cost to the Commonwealth would be nothing like $400m, which is what the cost would be if every company immediately met the criteria.

Many companies, particularly multinationals, would not be willing to issue 14 per cent of their share capital to employees, or to Australians at all. The reaction of Shell to a suggestion that it sell to Australians 25 per cent of its equity in Australia presumably is typical. Our own estimate is that in the first year not more than 5 per cent of companies would meet the criteria at a cost of no more than $20m. Fortunately, however, these companies would tend to be labour-intensive companies and would therefore benefit most from the introduction of these principles. The Government would not necessarily lose out in the long run. Experience has shown the introduction of industrial democracy greatly increases efficiency and productivity-that is a most important point-and it is thus quite probable that profits, hence tax, will rise also.

The Bill which I have presented today is simple and logical. If enacted, it would bring Australia to the forefront of those countries that have adopted an enlightened approach to industrial relations, for example, the Scandinavian countries, Germany and Japan. I commend the Bill.
