SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall not speak for very long on the Export Grants Acts Amendment Bill. The Opposition wishes to ask a number of questions pertaining to clause 7. The Bill changes the composition of the Export Development Grants Board so that the Chairman will be drawn from one of the four part time members of the Board and the executive officer will be the only full time member of the Board. Previously the chairman was a part time member. It is stated in the second reading speech, brief as it is, that this is in conformity with the constitution of other statutory authorities. I observe in passing that this is not entirely correct. The four major statutory marketing authorities are not constituted in this way but other statutory authorities, which are more comparable to the Export Development Grants Board-such as the Snowy Mountains Corporation and the River Murray Commission-are constituted in this way.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has made a major amendment, although it has post-dated the operation of that amendment, to the Export Market Development Scheme and the Export Expansion Grants Scheme so that the rate of payments will be halved after June 1982. However, because of the enormous backlog still existing-it is likely to exist also at the end of June next year-under these schemes, it is unlikely that the cost to revenue will decline significantly in the financial year 1982-83. It could be questioned whether, given a deliberate policy of export disincentive by way of protection of domestic industry, it is rational to have export incentives simultaneously. In other words, it could be argued that it is quite irrational having one brigade of bureaucrats administering tariff and quote policies, which are export disincentives, and another brigade of bureaucrats administering other schemes to distribute export incentives, and then wrapping them up in the same package and mislabelling it 'small government'.

Be that as it may, the specific questions which I want to ask pertain to clause 7 of the Bill. The explanatory memorandum which was circulated by the Minister for Trade and Resources, Mr Anthony, states that clause 7 provides for the Minister to appoint an acting member to the Board. On more detailed consideration and because of prior amendments I can see that it does do that. However, it also deletes old section 29 (9) which ensures that the validity of an action taken by the Board cannot be called into question because of technicalities concerning the time of appointment of an acting member. The new sub-section retains that provision by adding a line which guarantees the validity of actions taken by the Board, or by an acting member of the Board, where there is a defect or irregularity in, or in connection with, his appointment. This adds to the previous safety net, if you like, pertaining to the date of appointment. The Minister's explanatory notes make no mention of that change. This seems a little strange. A provision which is identical to that is contained in the Snowy Mountains Corporation legislation. There is no such clause in the River Murray Commission legislation.

I now ask the following questions: Why is it necessary to add that provision? Will it have retrospective application? In other words, if there is an irregularity or defect pertaining to the appointment of an existing or previous part time member of the Board, will that provision be relevant? Why is there no similar provision, so far as I can see, to cover actions taken by people who are regular members of the Board as distinct from acting members of the Board? The Opposition does not intend to oppose the Bill but would like to have explained those points which I have raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I would like to take the opportunity of congratulating you on your election to the office which you now occupy. This is the first opportunity I have had so to do. I understand the points raised by the previous speaker, Senator Walsh. I too believe they are worthy of consideration. I think that the importance of the Export Market Development Grants Act has to be taken into account to really appreciate that although these are only, by any standards fairly minor amendments, they are amendments to a fairly important piece of legislation that has been running since 1974. Since that time it has been of great value to the export industries. The legislation has been responsible for an enormous number of new exporters entering the field and has encouraged both people in primary industry and manufacturers to go into export.

SPEECH.PARA: These days world trade is affected very substantially by inflation and by the variation in currency valuations. Although there have been many variations in these areas, both up and down, since 1974, we have been able to ride them out. By controlling the inflation rate in this country as well as we have, we have been able to maintain reasonable continuity. We have become recognised around the world as a fairly reliable supplier, subject only to our industrial problems. As our economy has tightened up and has got much stronger, so has our currency value also. We have now reached the stage where selling on the world market is a far greater art than it has been in the last few years.

The original Act, it must be remembered, covered a variety of areas in which expenditure could be claimed. At this juncture it is worth looking over that to see the way in which the Bill before us is covered by the original Act. Section 4 of the Act refers to expenditure incurred primarily and principally for the purpose of creating or seeking opportunities, or creating or increasing demand, for the sale for export, or export and sale, of eligible goods that have been manufactured, produced, assembled, processed or packed, or graded or sorted in Australia. It covers a very wide range, including the carrying out of market research and advertising, as well as expenses directly attributable to samples, for the making of investigations, for the selection and design of materials for packaging and labelling, and expenses for the grant and registration of rights. The assistance that has gone into the various industries concerned has been considerable. The delay in the recoupment of these amounts has always been a cause for complaint, and still is. I have many inquiries every year from people who would like to receive payment much sooner than they do. I hope that with the amount allocated in this year's Budget-$84m compared with $60m last year-we will be able to catch up considerably in those payments.

As the chairman of the Government members sub-committee on trade, I have had discussions with a great number of manufacturers, producers and potential exporters. I would specifically like to mention the apparel industry, with which I have had considerable contact. This industry, which has all sorts of problems on its domestic market, has really tried to start a worthwhile and meaningful export arrangement. I am chairman of the Australian Clothing Export Council, and I give the members of that body considerable credit for what they have done to get Australian goods firmly marked in the various international spheres. There are many other areas where Australia's high skills and top technology can, with effort, find new markets. We have only to look at the skills in this country to see that they would find a place anywhere.

Many industry groups, organisations and others appreciate the encouragement that the Export Development Grants Act and the Export Expansion Grants Act provide. We have much discussion about our commitments under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and the Multilateral Trade Negotiations. I find that more and more organisations are starting to ask what advantages apply to Australia from its participation in those areas. We find that too often Australian industries suffer both ways. We recognise the various regulations of GATT in particular, but people with whom we deal do not. I believe that any trade discussions we have in this area should take that factor into account. Any arrangements we make with other countries should take into account relationships to GATT requirements.

We have also to consider that since 1974 many changes have occurred in the export trade, and I believe that incentives to export are necessary and desirable. We should look at what has happened since then to see whether the Export Grants Amendment Bill now accords fully with today's situation or whether alterations should be made to suit the current requirements. I think an announcement of a 5-year extension would be appropriate. However, if alterations are to be made, no less than two years should be the requisite minimum. It usually takes about 18 months in the pipeline before any change to an exporting program really comes to fruition, and that sort of time span would be highly desirable. We have to consider that the costs of market development have grown tremendously since 1974, and very substantial increases are necessary to restore the position, if it is the wish of the Government to do so.

We need to keep our industries export conscious, and I believe consideration of the increased cost is desirable. An increase in the gross amount needs to be considered. For instance, an amount of up to $250,000 would not be an inappropriate level. In addition, an allowance to exporters for personal expenses for accommodation, meals and so on of up to $100 day could be a worthwhile inclusion. It is of great necessity to Australia that employment be retained and extended. It is also recognised that our domestic market is unlikely to increase and so export will become more important than it is now. We have no alternative on a national basis but to provide the incentives for our industries to go out and pursue the markets of the world. I look to the amendments to provide a stronger background to the Export Development Grants Board, and I certainly support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, the Opposition has circulated three amendments for debate in the Committee stage of the Bill. All of the amendments relate to clause 29 of the Bill, and I seek the leave of the Committee to have those three amendments taken together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 14, sub-clause (2), line 12, leave out 'without warrant', insert 'in accordance with sub-section (3A)'.
(2) Page 14, sub-clause (3), line 15, leave out 'without warrant', insert 'in accordance with sub-section (3A)'.
(3) Page 14, after sub-clause (3), insert the following sub-clause:
''(3A) A constable or Officer of Customs may seize an article pursuant to sub-section (2) or (3) if, and only if-
(a) He acts in pursuance of a warrant properly issued by a judge or magistrate; or
(b) He believes on reasonable grounds that it is necessary to act without the authority of a warrant in order to prevent the loss or destruction of the article.''.

As I said, all of the amendments relate to clause 29 of the Bill, which deals with the identification of forfeited articles and makes provision for their seizure without warrant. The definition of articles forfeited to the Commonwealth appears in the extensive sub-clause (1) of clause 29, and includes such articles as not only counterfeit money itself or counterfeit prescribed securities but also, as shown in sub-paragraph (b):

all machines, engines, tools, plates, dies or other instruments . . . that are known to have been used, to have been adapted for use, or to be intended for use, in, or in connection with, the making of counterfeit money or counterfeit prescribed securities-

It also covers items known to be intended for use in that particular respect. Further down in clause 29 there are references to bullion, paper, metal, ink, die or other material that again is capable of use in this fashion and has been extracted, or is known to have been extracted, from a mint. There are further items relating to material obtained by stripping the edges off a genuine coin so as to diminish its weight. There is further provision for disfigured paper money to come into this description of forfeited articles. Finally there is a catch-all reference to articles that have been or are intended to be used in connection with the commission of an offence against this Act.

It will be appreciated from this recitation of the matters contained in clause 29 (1) that quite a large array of articles are encompassed by the definition of articles forfeited to the Commonwealth and that not all of these articles can be objectively identified in advance of some proper inquiry by a judicial body as to whether in fact they are forfeited. The scheme of the provision here is to identify these things as forfeited, to make provision for their seizure, and then to allow a further procedure by which a court can actually determine, if the matter is contested, whether they satisfy this description of being forfeited articles or not. That is the background against which the Opposition's amendments must be considered. The Opposition's amendments relate to clause 29 (2) of the Bill, which provides that:
A constable may, without warrant, seize any article that is forfeited to the Commonwealth--
That is, an article that comes within the definition that I have just set out-
or that he has reasonable grounds to believe is forfeited to the Commonwealth, under sub-section (1).

The Opposition's concern is with this unqualified power in all cases for a constable to seize forfeited goods or goods which he believes to have been forfeited without going through the procedure of obtaining a warrant. The remaining part of clause 29, which is not the subject of this amendment, provides for a procedure whereby, as I suggested a moment ago, someone who has had an article seized in this way can in fact require the court to determine whether or not the article in question is in fact forfeited.

The provisions contained in clause 29 providing for seizure without warrant do not in fact, I readily concede, change the existing statute law. To this extent I suppose it could be argued that they are unnecessary in this Bill. They do not change the existing statute law because section 9 of the Commonwealth Crimes Act already contains a general provision not confined to counterfeiting law relating to the seizure without warrant of goods that are forfeited to the Commonwealth under any Commonwealth statute. What this Bill does do is allow an opportunity for the legislature to improve the law and this, I suggest, is an exercise which the Senate, particularly with its new composition, should be about and which we can now be about in debating Bills of this kind. Certainly an attempt to improve the existing statute law is what this particular amendment is about. It may be that there will be further opportunity to improve the law generally in respect of search and seizure when the proposed criminal investigation Bill is debated in this Parliament. But we have been waiting for the appearance of a criminal investigation Bill for something like six years now, since the carriage of such a Bill was recommended by the Australian Law Reform Commission, and I am afraid that I will believe in the existence of such a drafted Bill and the present Government's commitment to it only when I see it. I suspect that that Bill is still a long way away.

There is, and will be, I suppose, a temptation, even with the enactment of a criminal investigation Bill-if it ever happens-to leave existing pockets of exception or exemption to new rules about search and seizure alone. There will always be a temptation, for historical reasons, I suppose, to treat Customs matters, revenue matters and perhaps also the kind of matter that we are dealing with in this Bill as being in some kind of exceptional category.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you see this linked with the proposed criminal investigation Bill?

—I will come to that in a moment. I want to explain why it is that I am anticipating that I will be met with the argument that if the law is at fault here it should be left alone and dealt with in the context of a criminal investigation Bill-if our patience extends that far. I make the point, firstly, that our patience may not extend that far and, secondly, that even when a general law of this kind is in fact passed clarifying, rationalising or updating the law of search and seizure along the lines that have been recommended by the Law Reform Commission, there may be a disposition to leave in place existing pockets of statute law for which there is perhaps some historical rationale, if not a rational rationale. It is for those reasons that I argue that the Senate, if it can be persuaded that there is merit in these amendments, ought to make the move now to improve this particular small area of the law dealing with forfeited goods in the context of counterfeiting law.

SPEECH.PARA: Coming squarely to the amendments, the basic approach that is adopted in the amendments is simply to follow the recommendations or the approach of the Australian Law Reform Commission in its second report 'Criminal Investigation' of 1975. The recommendation states:

The requirement of a warrant properly applied for, properly issued, is an important safeguard of liberty, liberty of the person, liberty of the property, and it should be required unless there are exceptional circumstances that can be identified which make the requirement of a warrant inappropriate.

Of course the short point of the Opposition's amendments is to delete the reference to the power of seizure without warrant and to replace it with a reference to a seizure with warrant, or if the seizing constable or officer 'believes on reasonable grounds that it is necessary to act without the authority of a warrant in order to prevent the loss of destruction of the article'. This is in conformity with the recommendation of the Law Reform Commission and I will give a little bit more detail about it. In paragraph 197 of the Commission's report the recommendation is put in summary form in the following terms:
. . . that all searches and seizures be unlawful unless made pursuant either to a court order or warrant, or, if made without a warrant, in accordance with one of the following criteria:
(a) in response to circumstances of such seriousness and urgency as to require and justify immediate action without the authority of such an order or warrant;

(b) at the invitation, or with the consent, of the person occupying the premises or in charge of the vehicle in question, a signed acknowledgement being prima facie evidence that such an invitation was made or consent given, the absence of such acknowledgement being prima facie evidence that it was not; or
(c) pursuant to specifically designated statutory authority.

The key exception which is identified and which is relevant in the present context is that referred to in paragraph (a), that is, that the primary circumstance in which the power to seize without warrant ought to be acknowledged is where it is 'in response to circumstances of such seriousness and urgency as to require and justify immediate action without the authority of such an order or warrant'. The Law Reform Commission goes on to identify with a little more precision exactly what those circumstances may be, that is, circumstances of seriousness and urgency. These are identified in general terms in paragraph 198 of the report as, firstly, circumstances in which the search or the seizure that is made is incidental to arrest. That is further qualified in another part of the report. I will come to those qualifications in a moment. The second category of urgency justifying, in the opinion of the Commission, a search or seizure without warrant is:
emergency searches necessary to prevent loss of evidence;
The third situation that is identified is:

searches of persons and vehicles suspected on reasonable grounds to be carrying any article which is an offensive weapon, or is either the fruit, instrument or material evidence of the commission of serious offence.

The third case is the kind of stop and frisk power which is common in the United States and which the Law Reform Commission decided would, in fact, be an appropriate additional weapon of law enforcement in this country-a not uncontroversial recommendation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those grounds are very different from the one you have specified.
—I make the point that the ground we have taken in paragraph (b) of the proposed amendment to clause 29-the addition of the new clause (3A)-which refers to the seizing officer, states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . believes on reasonable grounds that it is necessary to act without the authority of a warrant in order to prevent the loss or destruction of the article.

That is not a stop and frisk situation which is being contemplated. To give a stop and frisk power of the kind I have just identified would be going further than the existing law allows. That is not an area which I think it is appropriate to get into at this point. Arguably, however-and this is the point I want to make-the criterion we are specifying in the amendment straddles the two other situations which are identified in the report, that is, 'searches incidental to arrest' and 'emergency searches necessary to prevent loss of evidence'. I argue that by the language of our amendment, it is clear that the prevention of the loss of evidence is covered. However, it may be suggested-and this is the final point I want to answer-as it has been suggested to me by officers of the Attorney-General's Department with whom I have been able, thanks to the courtesy of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), to discuss this matter, that the power to make a seizure incidental to arrest, which is recommended by the Law Reform Commission in its report and which is in fact available as a matter of common law, is a wider power than is allowed by the language of the second part of the amendment. It has been suggested to me that as a matter of common law the power to seize incidental to an arrest is wider than a power to simply seize in circumstances where the object of that seizure is to prevent the loss or destruction of the article.

I want to meet that point by referring to a couple of other parts of the Law Reform Commission's report in which it is made clear-and I would hope that it would be accepted by the Attorney and his officers-that on a proper analysis of the existing common law the relevant part of the common law goes no further than the language which the Opposition has set out in its amendment. The situation of search and seizure incidental to arrest is articulated in paragraph 58 of the Law Reform Commission's report, which states:

It has always been the case at common law that a police officer could lawfully search the body, clothing and property in the immediate possession of a person arrested, if such search was reasonably believed to be necessary either (a) for the purpose of discovering a concealed weapon or any article which might be used by the person to injure himself or others or to assist him to escape, or (b) to secure or preserve evidence with respect to the offence for which the person was in custody.

The short point I make-which I can elaborate perhaps, if necessary, in a second go in a moment-is that the power to search incidental to arrest in cases where there is suspicion of concealed weapons is manifestly not relevant to the particular circumstances of seizure of forfeited counterfeiting materials. The latter justification as a matter of common law for arrest-this relates to a search incidental to arrest in order to avoid loss or destruction of evidence-is exactly the language to which this part of our amendment is addressing itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I succinctly record my entire endorsement of the remarks made by Senator Evans. I am in accord with them so much that I would like to hear some further remarks from him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take only another minute or two of the Committee's time. I think it is important to put the arguments in some detail, because I anticipate that this is the line of resistance to the Opposition's amendment, namely, that it goes further than what the common law allows. I will follow this up by a further reference to paragraph 193 of the Law Reform Commission's report, in which what exactly is the scope of that power to seize incidental to arrest is acknowledged. The scope of it has been the subject of a degree of controversy. Paragraph 193 states:

SPEECH.PARA: On the narrowest view, search incidental to a lawful arrest extends only as far as the physical area within which the person arrested might obtain weapons or evidentiary items of a destructible character.

In other words, that refers to items within the physical arm's reach of the person in question. Certainly that is the very narrow view which has been traditionally adopted by the American courts. Paragraph 193 goes on to state:
Another view is that it can extend as far as the seizure of any goods in the arrested person's 'possession or in his house'.

In other words, it refers to goods within the physical property which the person happens to be occupying at the time of his arrest. The authority for that is the rather controversial decision of Lord Denning in the English case of Ghani v. Jones in 1970. There is yet another view which is even wider than that-even more extreme-and that is:
. . . pursuant to an arrest the police may seize any property they find which is evidence of a crime committed by anyone.

That is the 1934 King's Bench case of Elias v. Pasmore. I think it has been conceded by anyone who has ever written about this matter that that went further than any authority before or since, and it is simply not accepted. In any event, none of those authorities counter the basic point in issue, which is that as a matter of common law the power to seize incidental to arrest did extend and was available only in circumstances in which either the seizure was believed necessary to get hold of some weaponry that might have been in the possession of the person in question or it was necessary to avoid the loss or destruction of evidence. Those points are succinctly made in clause 45 of the draft legislation which the Law Reform Commission produced. The proposed general rule is this:

(a) A Police Officer may, upon taking a person into lawful custody in respect of an offence, search his person, the clothing that he is wearing and any property under his immediate control if the Police Officer believes on reasonable grounds that it is necessary to do so-

(1) for the purpose of ascertaining whether there is concealed on his person, in his clothing or in that property a weapon or other article capable of being used to inflict injury upon a person or to assist him to escape from custody; or
(b) for the purpose of preventing the loss or destruction of evidence relating to the offence.

The Law Reform Commission took the view that was the essence of the common law power that ought to be acknowledged and codified in statutory form. The Opposition is suggesting that the present forfeiture provision involving, as it does, counterfeit money and machinery used in the production of counterfeit money or securities, does not raise questions of armaments or weaponry. It does, however, squarely raise the question of the possible loss or destruction of the article in question if time off is taken to obtain a warrant. The amendment acknowledges that there may well be many circumstances able to be envisaged where that time off simply cannot be taken, that as a result there ought to be acknowledged at least some power in the statute to search without warrant. But the basic principle ought to be maintained that unless there is a circumstance of that kind-namely, a lack of time to obtain a warrant in order to secure the evidence or article in question-a warrant ought to be obtained in the normal way. That is the principle embodied in the Opposition's amendment. Thus explained and, I hope, thus understood, and with the language in the Opposition's amendment which I hope is now better understood by the Attorney-General than may have been the case before, I hope and believe that the Attorney-General and his Department could not possibly as a matter of principle object to anything in the Opposition's amendment. It is a simple amendment that is proposed. I suppose it is quite a small amendment in terms of the large corpus of criminal law we have to deal with, but it is an important affirmation of a principle which, as I say, I believe we all accept and which this Parliament should accept.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to what Senator Evans has said about the amendment he has moved. I agree that he has a point in wanting to redefine clause 29 of the Crimes (Currency) Bill. I am not sure that his amendment is correct or that we should adopt it in its present form. Many of the things he has referred to in the course of his speech have been strangely inapposite to the matter that is before us because we are dealing with the Crimes (Currency) Bill and in particular the forfeiture of articles. To talk about common law rules, concealed weapons and so forth as grounds for forfeiture, is not relevant. I think it is worth reminding ourselves that this clause deals with the forfeiture of articles, which include counterfeit money or counterfeit prescribed securities, machines, engines, tools, et cetera, if they have been used in the course of counterfeiting. It also deals with bullion, paper, metal, ink, die and other materials. Those may be substantial and valuable items and the person who is making the arrest may be mistaken, or the things taken may have no connection with the matter or may belong to someone else. I think we ought to be pretty careful about the inclusion in this Bill of a provision which allows taking of items without a warrant.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not satisfied that Senator Evans's amendment is the appropriate one. It seems to me that if we take the two cases in which the Australian Law Reform Commission suggests that this might be done-or where there may be concealed weapons and things of that sort and where there may be grounds for preserving evidence-we might be nearer the point. But these may not be the only reasons why the arresting officer wants to retain the items involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are some other reasons?
—I am coming to those. We may agree with the points in Senator Evans's amendment which, in part, states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a warrant properly issued by a judge or magistrate; or . . .
He believes on reasonable grounds that it is necessary to act without the authority of a warrant in order to prevent the loss or destruction of the article.

It seems to me that that may not be the only reason why the article should be seized. I looked up the definition of the word 'loss' in the Oxford English Dictionary. It is rather hard to come across opposite definitions in the legal dictionaries because 'loss' has all kinds of meanings relating to various matters. The Oxford English Dictionary has a couple of definitions of 'loss' which I think are worth recording. One definition is:
The fact of losing . . . The being deprived of, or the failure to keep (a possession, appurtinance, right, quality, faculty or the like).
The word 'loss' in that sense means the loss of the possession of something. Another definition is:
Diminution of one's possessions or advantages; detriment or disadvantage involved in being deprived of something, or resulting from a change of conditions;

One comes across expressions like 'destruction' and 'loss' in the case of a will being destroyed or partially destroyed. We then have a rather limited situation-a situation where somebody must be shown to have intended to change his mind and not want to go ahead with the disposition of his estate as set out in the will. Therefore 'loss' and 'destruction', in the general understanding, are to be taken as language in the same category. Under the legal ejusdem generis rule the words must be regarded as related to the fact that if the person does not have a warrant and, therefore, does not arrest anyone, the particular article may be destroyed or lost to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never heard you being so Jesuitical in the entire time I have been in the Senate.

—All right, Senator; we are dealing with this matter on the run. We are not dealing with this matter with the scrutiny of a Bills committee, which I hope we will soon have; where advice can be obtained before we go on to debate legislation. We could then put to the Senate other views in relation to the terms used in Bills. I believe this is a typical example of where a Bill ought to be looked at by such a committee. Today we are trying to persuade the Committee of the Whole to accept that the amendment covers the ground Senator Evans seeks to cover. I do not think it does. I think other situations may arise. If an article is not taken it may be removed from the availability of the Commonwealth; it may be taken abroad or elsewhere. Loss and destruction may not be the only situations-
—Loss or destruction.

—Loss or destruction may not be the only situations in which it would be desirable and reasonable to take articles. It may be important, as Senator Evans says, that the articles be taken for the purpose of preserving and making available evidence. That is the common law situation. But that suggestion is not incorporated in Senator Evans's amendment.
—I would be delighted to incorporate that phrase, Senator, at your suggestion.

—Yes, we might incorporate that phrase. I might move a further amendment and then the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) might say: 'You have not included various other things'. The point Senator Evans has raised is certainly worthy of considerably more discussion and consideration than it has received. I do not propose to support the amendment because it seems to me it does not go far enough and does not cover those circumstances in which it could be necessary to seize such articles. As this matter has yet to be considered in another place, I hope the Government will give further consideration to the arguments raised by Senator Evans and to trying to make a provision whereby if an officer takes goods, even though he thinks the people concerned are guilty, he does not take goods of great value which belong to someone else. I think it therefore behoves the Parliament to be very careful that it limits the power of taking articles without warrant, and I hope that it will look into this matter further. Therefore, I do not support this amendment.
—We are only talking about the forfeiture of goods.

—We are only talking about the forfeiture of goods, but I ask honourable senators to look at the goods mentioned in clause 29. It mentions bullion, paper, metal, ink, dye, machines and tools. They are very substantial and possibly valuable things which may be the tools of trade of an innocent person. Under sub-clause 5, the court can order goods to be condemned if it is satisfied that a case has been proved. But it may well be that before that happens months have gone by and people who are in fact innocent find that their goods have been seized and their livelihood has gone.
—The same would happen if there is a warrant.

—Yes, but a warrant would mean that the police have satisfied a magistrate that the facts justify the granting of a warrant. A constable who did not have a warrant would not be able to seize various articles-including perhaps articles that belonged to someone else who had nothing to do with the counterfeitor-which he suspected were being used for counterfeiting. We therefore ought to be very careful that we do not give too great a power to the arresting constable to seize goods without warrant. I therefore think that the Government ought to give this matter much more consideration before the terms of the Bill are finalised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are, of course, dealing with not only an interesting but also a very important question. Since we last considered this matter in this place I have had the opportunity of discussing it at some length with Senator Evans. I have become aware of his arguments. Discussions have taken place with officers of my Department as well as with me. We have had the further benefit today of hearing Senator Evans's argument fully stated. I think that the matter has been now given very full consideration. I believe that the provisions contained in the sub-clauses of clause 29 of the Bill should remain.

SPEECH.PARA: I would be prepared perhaps to give further consideration as to whether the drafting may be improved or whether some incidents that have not been fully covered, although I cannot offhand see in what respect the provisions are deficient. Of course, there will be opportunities before this matter is finally passed through the other place and through the Parliament to take up any suggestion of that kind. However, I am not prepared to accept the proposals contained in Senator Evans's amendment. The reason for this is very much along the lines that Senator Missen has expressed.

We are dealing with the basis on which forfeited goods may be seized by a constable or officer of Customs. To understand the matter we need to look at the specific provisions of the sub-clause of clause 29 which set out what are forfeited articles. Senator Missen has already referred to them in general terms and I do not propose to repeat what he said. Counterfeiting of currency is very serious. We are dealing with a situation in which a police constable is concerned with arresting people whom he proposes to charge with very serious offences. There may well be counterfeit money. There may be means by which counterfeit money is being produced -the machines, the dyes and so on. Ultimately, of course, these matters have to be proved in a court. The forfeiture of goods may be involved. An arrest may be made in an emergency situation. If the machines are churning out money the police officer ought to be able, in that emergency situation, to take action and not have to go to get a warrant before he can act.

The law does not operate, and never has operated, in this way. Senator Evans does not propose that we should have a general provision in the law that police officers cannot act without warrants. Obviously they have to arrest without warrants. They can and they always have been able to do this. Senator Evans and the Law Reform Commission-this chamber has heard from Senator Evans and other senators about the now famous report of the Commission on criminal investigation-recognise that fact. They recognise that there are a number of cases-Senator Evans has detailed them already-in which police may act without warrant. One of the proposed clauses of the Criminal Investigation Bill is annexed in the report of which Senator Evans is an author. I do not know whether he was the draftsman as well; he might have been. Proposed section 64 (2) provides:

A Police Officer who believes on reasonable grounds that a person is carrying an offensive weapon or anything connected with an offence (being a serious offence) may stop that person and seize any such weapon or thing that is found on the person.
That is the sort of general principle--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a little bit away from it, isn't it?

—It is a general principle. Here I am applying that general principle to the specific situation in which a police officer is arresting a person whom he has caught red-handed printing off counterfeit money on some machine. That is the situation with which he is presented. The police officer obviously believes that on reasonable grounds he can make an arrest, that he should be able to seize the forfeited property there and then. Under the terms of the amendment he could arrest but he would have to go off to get a warrant and come back again. By that time more damage may have been done.
—Isn't that covered by Senator Evans?

—No, that is another question. Circumstances in which the machine would be destroyed would be covered by the amendment; however, the prevention of the exercise going on would not be. The position is simply this: For a number of situations at common law and statute law-even under the much vaunted proposals of Senator Evans and the Law Reform Commission-there will always be, for very good reasons, provision for arrest and seizing of property without warrant. We are saying that the provision is in the legislation for a good reason. We are saying that in circumstances which involve the forfeiture of property the police should be able to seize that property there and then.

SPEECH.PARA: People are not without any redress in relation to this matter. The other sub-clauses in clause 29 provide a person with rights, the question of whether it was forfeited property having been determined. So it is not as though the right of people to have that question determined is not protected. All it would mean, as I said, is that under Senator Evans's amendment the police officer would have to get a warrant. Before he could seize the property he would have to say to the person issuing the warrant that he believes on reasonable grounds that the property is forfeited property. Having seized it he has again to establish before a court that he was entitled to seize it. So I really think that the provisions in this clause are reasonable and in accordance with general principles in relation to actions taken by police officers without warrants.

My view is that the clause should stand. I think there are some other problems with the drafting of the clause. Obviously, if this chamber agreed in principle with Senator Evans rather than with me, I would suggest that there ought to be some changes in the wording of the amendments. At this stage I would like the Senate to express its view. I do not want to go into those sorts of technical details about the wording of the amendments, although, as I said, I have some criticism of them. I think the Senate should resolve the matter of whether it wishes to support the principles of the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise now in the hope that some of the things I say might be able to be dealt with by Senator Evans, if that is convenient to him. As I see the situation, even if we pass the amendments moved by Senator Evans, the right of seizure without warrant of forfeited items would still not be denied. Surely that matter is dealt with in the principal Act. I raise this point because I think that as a Senate we ought to determine these matters. If we are to make decisions then those decisions ought to be effective. As I understand the position, section 9 of the Crimes Act allows for seizure without warrant of forfeited items, and, I am advised that that has been so since 1914. I think Senator Evans adverted to this in his previous comments in the Committee of the Whole. I therefore cannot see the value of this debate other than in raising the issue of the importance of the principle of the rights of the persons engaged in these activities.

SPEECH.PARA: When we come to the general debate and discuss these matters in substance, our decisions will in effect lay down the principles upon which officers of the law should proceed. At that time I think we should also have regard to the vicitims of the crimes. I do not know whether any honourable senator has had the unfortunate experience of having a dud $20 note-or a dud any amount of money-unloaded on him.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are too sharp for that.

—Yes, Senator MacGibbon. It is a bit like musical chairs. The last person who cops the package opens it and he gets hung with it. I view this sort of crime in a slightly different fashion from some other types of crime. The victims of this crime are generally little men such as shopkeepers and even bookmakers, although I do not cry any crocodile tears over bookmakers. Generally it is someone like the small shopkeeper who has to bear the brunt of the dud currency circulating around the place.

SPEECH.PARA: I for one would hesitate to limit the powers of the police to obtain the evidentiary material necessary to ensure a prosecution. In this case I would be very hesitant to limit police powers, unless evidence were placed before the Senate showing that those powers had been abused. In both the second reading stage and the Committee stage no evidence was adduced in respect of currency crimes to show that the police had abused their rights under the legislation. I congratulate Senator Evans and Senator Missen in raising the general and broader issues in relation to warrants. I feel that voting against these amendments and for the Bill will not put close to the debate. Ultimately the matter will crop up when the principal Act is under consideration at some future time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the gentlemanly atmosphere in which this debate has so far been conducted, it does rather appear that everybody has his mind made up on how he will vote. Nevertheless, I think there is some utility in replying briefly to what I see as being the three major sorts of objections to the Opposition's amendments that have been advanced from around the chamber. The first of them, put by Senator Harradine a moment ago, was to this effect: 'Isn't this all a bit useless, given the fact that you retain in the statute book section 9 of the Crimes Act, which confers a general power of seizure without warrant of all forfeited goods'. That is true, and it may be that in the clean-up of the statute book we will need to do later on we will need to take account specifically in section 9 of the existence of other pieces of legislation of the kind I am endeavouring to get through today.

SPEECH.PARA: In the meantime, I suggest to Senator Harradine that, as a matter of proper interpretation of statutes, these particular amendments were they to go through today would, I believe, take precedence. A lot of Latin has been thrown around this chamber in the last two or three days, but the particular maxim that would appear to be relevant here is generalia non specialibus derogant. In other words, general things do not take precedence over special provisions; general provisions in legislation do not overrule the much more specific provisions made elsewhere. There is another rule about later statutes taking precedence over earlier ones if there is any potential conflict. Although the cause of long term statute book neatness might be advanced by dealing with section 9 of the Crimes Act to make it clear how it relates to these provisions, nonetheless these provisions would in fact take precedence.

The second objection made around the chamber appears to be that there is something rather special about forfeited goods, articles which makes them significantly different from the goods or articles involved in ordinary criminal law search and seizure situations. I suggest that that is simply not so, and I will make several points in explanation of that. In the first place, it is not as if the statutory definition here makes it absolutely beyond doubt that the particular article we are talking about that will be seized will be properly seized. All that is involved is a requirement that the seizer have a reasonable belief that the good or the article in question satisfies the description of being forfeited. there is no one to test the reasonableness of the belief of the constable or Customs officer involved. He just has to do his own thing, by definition, in the absence of a warrant requirement. It is that very question as to whether he does have a reasonable belief that the particular pile of money in the shopkeeper's till is counterfeit and therefore forfeited, a reasonable belief that a particular printing press is intended for use for counterfeiting purposes, that is very much here in issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —That provides a defence to the defendant when the issue comes before the court, does it not?

—Yes, but the second thing to take into account is that the person whose goods are seized in this way does not get an opportunity to test the reasonableness of the seizer's belief until the matter is prosecuted, if indeed it is prosecuted at all. Of course, that might be months or a year or more ahead. Even if a prosecution does not proceed, even if the police decide, having seized the notes or the machinery in question and having had a good look at them and all the circumstances, that there are no grounds for prosecution under sub-clause 4, the seizer can hang on to the notes or machinery for fully 90 days-three months-without having to return them. That is the sort of situation we are talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing to bear in mind, of course, is that the value of the articles seized may be very substantial. The face value of the notes seized might be very substantial indeed, or relatively substantial, given the income or assets of the person from who they are seized, even if they amount to only $20, $50 or $100.

Of course, in the context of a printing press being seized it can amount to someone's whole livelihood. It can simply be extracted from him; taken away for 90 days without there being any grounds on which subsequently a prosecution can be mounted. He will get his machinery back when the matter is tested, as is provided for in these later sub-clauses, but in the meantime he will have to do without his machinery. Senator Harradine says that he is interested in the small man rather than the kind of character that is likely to be caught up in counterfeiting situations but I ask him to have regard to the way in which these things work.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the same situation would arise if you had a warrant.
—No. The whole point about a warrant is that the reasonableness of the officer's belief has to be tested.
—By a judge, who determines the reasonableness.

—By a judge or a magistrate. Yes, there is a judicial determination as to whether there is a degree of objective reasonableness about the situation. That is the crucial significance of having a properly working warrant situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot bring forward particular cases in substantiation, but what can be involved, in this malicious and hostile world that we all inhabit, are situations in which tip-offs are given to the police-entirely without substantial, verifiable foundation-purely out of personal malice. There may be a family feud. Service stations across the road from each other may be having a price war brawl which has become pretty emotional. One of the proprietors may ring the police and say: 'The fellow across the road has a till full of forged $20 notes'. It is not an entirely fantastic situation; something like that could happen. It cannot just be assumed, because of the nature of these offences, that we are necessarily talking about corporate crooks of a high order who are almost certainly likely to be guilty of something or other if the police proceed against them using the powers that are available in this legislation. In these circumstances, all sorts of changes can be rung. It is easily possible to envisage circumstances in which goods will be unfairly seized. That is the reason for the argument that this warrant procedure ought to be followed.

The third category of objection was that which asserts that the language of the proposed amendment is simply not good enough to cover all of the possible contingencies that one might envisage as justifying seizure without warrant. There is another variation on that argument-that the language generally might not be good enough; that perhaps it is technically not proficient; that we should have defined 'judge', 'magistrate' or something of the kind. But if the objection is of such a purely technical nature, it can certainly, as the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) himself acknowledged, be sorted out quite easily. I took it that the Attorney-General was not suggesting that any possible technical deficiencies of this kind would be a ground for the Senate's voting against this amendment. But he did suggest, as did more particularly Senator Missen that the term 'loss or destruction' was simply not adequate, even at very obvious face value, to cover the situations that might be involved. I cannot accept that that is so. I am prepared to accept that it may be useful to add to the formula here not just a reference to prevention of loss or destruction but also such words as 'to secure the preservation of'. Then the sub-clause would read:
. . . without the authority of a warrant in order to secure the preservation of or prevent the loss or destruction of the article.

I believe that would cover the situation that Senator Missen had in mind. If not, perhaps again that is the kind of matter that can be cleaned up at a later stage before the Bill departs forever this Senate, never to be seen again. I doubt that that is necessary. I believe that the notion of preservation is inextricably the mirror image, if you like, of the language 'loss or destruction'.

The only other situation that the Attorney-General felt able to identify as not clearly covered by the language of 'loss or destruction, was that which he postulated of the printing press continuing to pound out $20 notes while the police officers in question toddled off to get their warrant. True it is that the printing press would hardly be lost or destroyed in the interim. The danger is that it would be possible to create more obnoxious articles while the police officers were away. However, I ask the Attorney-General whether he believes that life works quite like that-that it would be possible for a police officer, having entered premises under some lawful authority and knowing that the machinery in question was pounding away producing counterfeit notes, to do other than, even if he did not stay in the building, to place a cordon around it. These days they have two-way radios.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the hiding of the article or its removal from jurisdiction?

—Hiding or removal from jurisdiction is squarely contemplated, on any view, in the language 'loss or destruction' as found in this proposed sub-clause. I put it to the Senate, and in particular to Senator Harradine, if he is still likely to be moved by considerations of this kind, that the arguments that have been advanced by Senator Missen and the Attorney-General on the question of the linguistic range of this sub-clause are simply not persuasive; that they have all the character of a desperate search to find some ground on which to rub out as unnecessary or insufficiently comprehensive the Opposition's proposed amendment. It lacks credibility that the kind of consideration that Senator Missen has advanced could be a ground for voting against this amendment. If Senator Missen thinks that we are on a good thing, as far as the principle of this is concerned-which he seemed to be clear about--
—Yes.

—And if Senator Missen takes account of what the Attorney-General has said about his being prepared to regard the vote on this clause as essentially one of principle, that he will allow this Parliament at some later stage-if we report progress or bring the matter back from the other House-to clean up the language further, Senator Missen, if he is consistent, will vote to support the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Doubtless much more could be said about the amendment because, although it is a relatively small matter in many ways, it does raise large questions of principle, but perhaps what I have said is sufficient to convey to the Senate at least the flavour of the reply that the Opposition advances to the points that have been made. I hope that that reply will be persuasive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make two very brief comments. Firstly, I understand what Senator Evans has said about forfeited articles which, under sub-clause (4) of clause 29, can be retained for a period of 90 days after seizure. It is clear from what has been said that some of these forfeited articles may belong to a person or persons other than the person who is arrested, charged and presumably subsequently convicted. The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) mentioned in his previous comments that such persons have some means of redress. Will the Attorney-General explain to the Senate what means of redress an innocent party has in such an event? If there is no such redress, has it become evident that there is now some need to amend the legislation to establish procedures for redress?

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, I am still not convinced that there is a need for this legislation. I repeat, whether or not a warrant is used there may be need for redress. I agree with both Senator Evans and Senator Missen that such redress should be available not merely post-factum but ante-factum, before the event. Surely all of the relevant information is not available to the magistrate at the time. If there is to be redress, surely there is need to spell out the procedures to be followed. Perhaps I am missing something in that regard.

Secondly, although provision for seizure without warrant has been in the legislation since 1914, no evidence has been placed before the Senate that the police have acted beyond their powers or that those powers have been to the substantial, or even minor, disadvantage of the people concerned. If we are to talk about the rights of individuals surely we ought to be talking about the rights of the victims of the crimes. The person who gets the dud $20 note ought to be able to go to John Stone and demand 20 bucks to make good his loss. This is the sort of attitude that I adopt to these things rather than giving to criminals an additional ability to bleed the public, the little man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sub-clause (7) of clause 29 takes up the point that an article that is condemned as forfeited to the Commonwealth, shall be dealt with or disposed of in accordance with the directions of the Treasurer. Senator Harradine, I understand, posed the case of a person who owned the goods but was not involved in the crime.
—I think somebody said 'tools'.

—That may be. The principle under this type of legislation has always been that even though the person who owned the goods was innocent of the crime the goods should be forfeited. That is the provision. In the event that it is established that the person with the goods was involved innocently, I imagine that the Treasurer would return them to the person who owned them. This sort of thing has arisen from time to time under the Customs Act. I do not know about the case referred to but I know that under the Customs Act this question arises. There is provision for returning goods to the innocent owner.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Evans's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Durack) read a third time.
Sitting suspended from 5.55 to 8 p.m.
General Business taking precedence of Government Business after 8 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 August, on motion by Senator Davidson:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will look this evening at the report entitled 'Children and Television', which relates to the impact of television on the development and learning behaviour of children, and the second report, entitled 'Children and Television Revisited', which is a review of the original report. It is rather interesting that the second report has been called 'Children and Television Revisited'. I wish to speak very briefly on the first report. It was my privilege to serve on the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts when both the original report was compiled and when the review was undertaken. I think it is fair to say that this is one of the Senate reports which created a good deal of interest. There have been a number of them over the years. Some create more interest than others and this was one that attracted a lot of interest, not only from the media, from which there was a good deal of favourable comment, but also from a number of parent groups, teachers, service clubs and so on. This interest was expressed in a number of ways and I know that I, certainly, as one member of the committee-I am sure the other members were involved in the same way-must have spoken to 25 or 30 such groups. The interest shown when I spoke with those groups was most commendable.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought it might be interesting for the Senate-particularly for the newer senators who were not members of the Senate when the report was compiled and perhaps have not been able to read it yet with the amount of material they find in front of them-to look at the topics of the first report which attracted a great deal of attention as shown by the comments and the questions put to me by the groups that I have mentioned. We can then perhaps see why these topics form the basis of the review or second report.

There is little doubt that the major topic which attracted attention was what we called the 'Emery thesis'. I will read from the first report, that is, the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts on the impact of television on the development and learning behaviour of children. Page 46 of the report states:
This thesis is the main thrust of a published work 'A Choice of Futures: To Enlighten or Inform' by F. E. and M. Emery.

In essence, the Emerys postulate that by its very nature, the television signal produces a temporary numbing of the left hemisphere of the brain which is the perceptive or thought processing function, thus allowing other parts of the brain to dominate. In other words, television viewing induces a passivity or mental torpor in the viewer which leads to an impaired capacity to process and remember information, thus limiting the medium's active ability to familiarise the viewer with something but not to inform him about things.

I think the reason that this was of such interest to the groups to which I spoke was that they were either parent groups, teacher groups or service clubs interested in education. Of course, we can think immediately of the effect of television in the classroom situation. It is quite clear that, if television is used as an audio-visual aid, for an hour or longer after such viewing the child loses the capacity to process the information. I do not want to go into detail about this; it is a fascinating subject and one on which I could speak at great length. But I will leave it at that. If the television set is used as an audio-visual aid in the classroom the child is not able to process either material which comes out of that program or which is presented to him afterwards. Whilst this is still an hypothesis, the suggestion is that it might be an hour or an hour andd a half before the child is able to react to and work on material given to him.

I think we as parents might also think of the effect of television on home study. If we allow our children to watch television for an hour before they do their homework, quite clearly they will not be able to work effectively on that homework. Because this was of so much interest to us, and because quite clearly if the hypothesis were correct it would have had a dramatic effect on education, we recommended a further study to test the hypothesis. It was a great disappointment to all the members of the Committee-I mention also former Senator Davidson who was Chairman of the Committee and who spoke at great length on this subject-that no grant was made available to the Emerys. In fact the Committee took what I think might have been almost an unprecedented step of recommending to the Commonwealth Grants Commission that money be made available. A letter went from the Committee, over the Chairman's signature, asking that money be made available to the Emerys. I am glad to say that some money was made available and some work is going ahead at present.

The second topic which was of great interest was that of media education. The Committee recognised, as certainly did the people who discussed it with us, wrote to us and questioned us during our lectures, the need to train young people to watch television critically. I sometimes wonder whether this capacity to watch critically is more important than appreciation. It is quite clear that children need to be able to handle the material, in the full sense of the word, if they are not to be affected adversely by it. Of course, the corollary of this is the need to train teachers to do the job of media education. During the inquiry we saw good work being done, but much more needs to be done.

There is no doubt that television is a very intrusive medium. It comes into the home and there seems to be no way of keeping it out. Many of us will have seen our children, other children, or adults for that matter, on whom television seems to have a sort of hypnotic effect; they are not able to tear themselves away from the screen. I cite a personal instance: I visited a friend of mine and as I walked through the front door into the room where the television was situated, he said: 'Thank goodness you have come. I can turn this thing off'. Such was the effect on him that, if the television was there and there was no one to talk to, he had to watch it. I do not think that he is an isolated example.

Another topic which attracted our attention in the inquiry, and one which certainly was put to us during questions, was the effect of violence on television. The violence that we spoke about was not the sort of violence one sees in films. It seems that children and young people, but children particularly, are able to cope with the cowboys and indians approach. They are conditioned to seeing somebody get shot and fall over because they know that, as in their own games, the hero will get up and carry on with his business after the film is over. We call it the sort of 'count 100 and get up' syndrome. Children seem to have this capacity. But the sort of thing that is disturbing is the amount of violence which one sees on television news and on television documentaries. Many of us, both members of the Committee and those who appeared before us, were frightened that children were becoming desensitised, almost immune to suffering and violence. In fact, as one witness put it to us, children seem more concerned about the plight of a cat in a tree which is not able to get down than about people being killed or dying as a result of natural disasters such as floods, famine and so on. This desensitisation is a very worrying aspect.

The topic which perhaps was of greatest interest was the effect of advertising during what we might call 'children's viewing time', that is, the time between 4.30 p.m. and 6.30 p.m. or 4.30 p.m. and 7.30 p.m., depending on the State. I refer to the sort of advertising that encourages children to get their parents to buy expensive toys, the pressure of advertising to raise the expectations of children perhaps beyond their parents' buying capacity or buying power. I refer also to the encouragement of the television commercials for children to eat trash foods. I use that word carefully because it was a word used very much by people during our inquiry and in the questions that were asked later. A problem with many of the young people was that they were not able to differentiate between advertisements and programs. It was feared that when the hero of the children's program came forward to suggest that they buy product X, they would not be able to differentiate when that hero is speaking as the forecful figure he plays in his ordinary programs and when he is appearing in a commercial. I do not want to mention a name, but the point I am trying to make is that a hero in a program at one time might encourage children not to light fires in the bush or not to play with glass and then a few minutes later the same person is saying 'buy product X'. It is difficult for the young child to separate the two situations.

The last point I wish to mention is a topic of great interest. I refer to the quality of programs. Quite clearly it is very difficult to define what we mean by the 'quality' of a television program. Most of us would know what is meant by that, particularly those who have been involved in teaching or who are parents. We know what quality television means. Many of the people who came before the Committee said there was a real need to establish some sorts of criteria by which programs might be judged. The teachers of English said we should judge them in the same way we would judge a novel; the teachers of drama or those involved in drama said we should assess them on other criteria, on the same sorts of things by which we would judge a play. I think something different is involved. I do not want to go into this matter of definition. The problem we saw was that children were being conditioned to accept third rate programs. The reason they are getting third or fourth rate programs is that such programs are cheap to buy or to make. The situation comedies that are 30 years old or more are being pumped out over the air waves because they are cheap to buy. Let us face it, the advertisers do not care what is on television as long as their advertisement is at the beginning of the program, the end of it or in the middle.

One must make the point that if programs are made cheaply it usually follows-though not necessarily because of the cost-that they are of poor quality. As a matter of fact, in our first report we used that delightful phrase from Shaw, in which he said: 'Take care to get what you like, or you will be forced to like what you get'.

We were very concerned to think that children are being conditioned to want to like or to want to see third rate programs. These and other matters were looked at in the review. The five points I have mentioned, and others, were the basis of our review, the report of which we are discussing tonight. A commitment was given at the time the report was put down. Page 1 of the report states:
At the time of tabling this report on 23 November 1978-
That is referring to the original report-
The Chairman of the Committee made the following statement-

'Because of the great amount of interest in this inquiry and the likely continued public interest, I inform the Senate that we will be looking at the subject of children's television again in about eighteen months.'

It was because of that commitment by Senator Davidson and the pressure of interest from parent groups and others that we undertook the second inquiry. I will draw attention to a number of aspects of its report. No doubt speakers to follow will draw attention to others. I firstly remind the Government-I do this very sincerely-of Senator Davidson's extreme disappointment that the Government did not see fit to act on the recommendations of the first report. Very little has been done as a result of the first report, which is entitled 'The impact of television on the Development and Learning Behaviour of Children'. Despite the fact that educators, parents and others throughout Australia commended the report and said what excellent suggestions it made, the Government decided-I cannot say in its wisdom, I would have to say in its folly-not to accept the recommendations and do something about them.

The effects of televised violence is the first matter that I mention which we dealt with in the second report. I suggest that we look at the original recommendation in the first report. We have done nothing about that. The recommendation in the second report is that we proceed to fulfill the terms of the original recommendation. Program classification is another area in which nothing has been done. We had to make virtually the same recommendation in our second report. Virtually nothing has been done in regard to advertising. The Government is prepared to say: 'Let the industry regulate itself'. We can see the effects of that. In other words, a great deal more needs to be done.

I turn now to three or four other major areas in which we have made recommendations. The first involves the Broadcasting Information Office. I express the real disappointment and concern of the whole Committee, both Government and Opposition members, that the decision was taken by the Government not to establish this office. Originally, the then Minister for Post and Telecommunications said:

The BIO will be headed by a Director with an independent status similar to that of the Commonwealth Statistician. It will be a statutory office charged wih the collection of broadcasting data and research which will be available to the industry, the public and to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.

We recommended that the Broadcasting Information Office be set up as a research body to study the whole field of broadcasting and that it be given full resources to fulfil that function. We saw the research function of the BIO as concentrating more on the social science side rather than the technical side of broadcasting. We wanted to see the Broadcasting Information Office appoint an advisory committee to advise it on the allocation of research priorities and we wanted to make sure that the information collected by the Broadcasting Information Office would be made freely available to the public, to all those people interested in education and television. Unfortunately, the Broadcasting Information Office is not to be set up. A half-hearted attempt was made by the Government to establish it but it was given almost no resources and was still-born. One has to say that the Government bent to pressure from vested interests. There is no doubt that there is a place for the Broadcasting Information Office and it should be established. It has support from the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and it has support from public interest groups. This support was shown in evidence to the Committee and is mentioned in the report. Page 16 of the report states:

We are of the opinion that there is need for such an organisation as the Broadcasting Information Office with a status similar to that originally approved by the Government and that because of rapidly changing circumstances in broadcasting the need is even greater now than it was when we made our recommendations in 1978.
The 'we' in this situation is the Committee. Once again, on behalf of the Committee, I call on the Government to support the establishment of the Broadcasting Information Office.

I turn now to the Children's Program Committee of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. We had discussions with both the Program Committee and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. The Tribunal praised the achievements of the Program Committee. There is no doubt that evidence which we got from teachers, from media experts and from parents showed the need for the Program Committee to have formal and independent status. It cannot be subordinate to the Tribunal, doing only what the Tribunal tells it. It cannot operate effectively under the present conditions. The report calls for the Committee to be given formal status with appropriate legislation taking note of the recommendations of our original report and of the present review. There is a great need for the Children's Program Committee. This is the committee which looks at children's programs-those imported and those produced locally-and which makes recommendations to groups that want to produce programs locally. It makes clear guidelines available to anyone on what should be done in this area. Let me pay tribute to the members of that program committee. I will not mention them by name, but they are all experienced people. They have a fine chairperson, and as a group they would know as much about children's programs as does any other group in Australia, and I would suggest more. It is a great pity that they are not given the opportunity to work effectively.
We have also made certain recommendations about a children's television program production unit. Recommendations 5, 6 and 7 state:
5. That the Commonwealth Government supports the Australian Children's Television Foundation and that this support encompass financial contribution.
6. That Films commissioned by the Foundation for local production qualify for tax concessions under the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.
7. That financial support to the Foundation from the private sector qualifies as a tax deduction.

Both of the inquiries that were conducted indicated strong support for the establishment of a children's television program production unit. The purpose of the unit, of course, would be to produce high quality programs which would be made available to the ABC and to the independent television channels in Australia. I do not think it would be going to far to say that such a unit would replace the rubbish that is being imported, and it would complement the few good programs that are being imported and the few good programs that are being produced. The commercial channels made it quite clear that they would be happy to use the material produced by such a production unit. I will not go into the details of how this unit might be set up, but quite clearly it would need to be funded as we have suggested, and it would need to have certain tax concessions to encourage its development. I see it as a vital unit to lift the expectations of children-in other words, an education in developing the standards of children. Again, I have to express the concern and the disappointment of the Committee at the lack of Government response.

Without being too complimentary to the reports, because after all I was a member of the Committee which produced them-although only one of six members of course-I think it is fair to say that the reports have been accepted as giving some sort of lead in this area. Let me remind honourable senators that Senate standing committee reports are unusual in that they are a collection of ideas which have been brought together and collated by a group of six lay persons. There is no suggestion that the six people sitting on the Committee had any particular expertise. There is no suggestion that the reports are the ideas of those members. They are a collection of the ideas of those people in Australia who ought to know something about the field. We had the advantage not only of excellent witnesses and excellent submissions but also of excellent advice from those people who were commissioned to help us in this area.

It might be worth while making the point that in some areas we have had people say to us: 'What do you know about it? Have you got a degree in education?' In the national resources area they might ask: 'Are you qualified in this area?' I made the point to them, and I make it again now, that it is not the function of the members of committees to be expert in any particular area. It is up to the expert witnesses who come before committees to break down the academic nature of some of the evidence and to present it to us as representatives of the Australian people.
