I think the committee system, and I am a great supporter of the committee system, is valuable in collating the best available data and condensing it to make it available to the Government in the form of recommendations.

I believe that the Government has an opportunity to make a real contribution in this area. I call on it to resist the pressure from vested interests and once again look at the recommendations of this bipartisan Committee, and that is not a word that I fling around like some people do. The Committee is bipartisan. We had a consensus report. Both sides of the political spectrum, shall I say, or both sides of the political field, supported this report. I ask the Government to look at both reports-the first report, which has plenty of recommendations that have not been worked upon, and the second report, which is a review of the first. I think if the Government implemented the recommendations contained in both of these reports it would improve the quality of children's television in Australia. There is no doubt about that. Many of the witnesses who came before us made the point that television has great potential-potential for great good or for great harm. It seems to me that it would not be becoming emotional about it or even stressing the point too strongly to say that the choice of whether television in Australia is going to be for good or for harm lies firmly with the Government at the present time, and it is a choice from which it simply cannot back away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like first of all to make some comments of a general nature on the report and then a more specific comment relating to violence on television and its effect on children. In reading some of the reports, I have been amazed at the capacity of honourable senators on committees to produce such quality reports while they are under so much pressure from other contending areas. Unfortunately, this report and its predecessor, as Senator Robertson has said, have not been taken up. Nevertheless, I think they have provided a useful forum within the community to discuss a range of issues about television, which must be accepted as one of the major changing elements within our society. Unfortunately, in many ways the whole education debate often takes place in an atmosphere in which it is assumed that something like television never occurred. The changes that have been wrought by television since its introduction into Australia in the 1950s are immense. Yet many people, in criticising schools, refer back to their own time, which in fact was pre-television and quite a different type of society.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make a specific comment about what I see as the rather simplistic view that is taken in the report in relation to violence on television. The report quite correctly points to the majority view, and it is the majority view according to the research that has been carried out in the area, that the observation of violence on television is, if not a determining factor of subsequent violent behaviour on the part of children, at least a contributing factor. I think that is probably very much the accepted view and one about which there is very little dispute. However, there are two minority views, firstly, the view that the observation of violence on television may in itself be cathartic, and, secondly, the view which tries to draw a distinction between it being provocative and cathartic.

A great deal of very useful work has been done, and the report refers to this, on trying to distinguish between the various forms of violence as they appear on television and the different levels of portrayal of representation of violence. Senator Robertson referred to the fact that children seem to be able to make a distinction between, for example, watching the old style cowboy and Indian movies and some of the newer television shows and watching the news. In fact, younger children find it very difficult to distinguish between the news and what went before and what follows after.

Whilst I believe this useful work should continue, I want to make a point about the simplistic view that the report takes on violence. Violence is really a very notable example of the effects of socialisation on our thinking about any matter. An assumption is made in the report that violence is undesirable in that it contradicts the accepted social norms. However, if we have a look at real societies, we observe that this indeed is not the case. Interestingly enough, most of the research work referred to in the report was done in either America or Australia at a time when both of our societies were engaged in violent action. I think that violence was authorised violence-authorised by a political decision-and such violence is acceptable. It was acceptable at least at that time in this community and in America. However, at the same time within those countries research was being done in relation to a different type of violence-for example, violent protest or armed robbery in which violence occurred. All of these types of violence were considered to be wrong.

If we really want to make a distinction-which unfortunately the report does not make-we can say that unauthorised violence is inadmissible and not authorised violence. This type of distinction exists between approved and non-approved or impermissible forms of violence. We have an interesting situation, to which much of the research failed in its methodology to address itself, that the law in Australia and in America at that time could say: 'You will be punished if you refuse to kill in a foreign war' while at the same time it could say: 'You will be punished if you kill in the course of internal political struggle'. Unfortunately, it seems to me that we really have not taken sufficient cognisance of that social aspect of violence, and neither does the report. Basically, the whole argument about violence depends ultimately not on television but on the social structure and the social norms.

I will specifically refer to television in Australia. The argument, which unfortunately is accepted by the report, runs something like this: This society discourages violent behaviour. Violent behaviour is constantly represented and reported on television. We need to study, modify or prevent its effects on children. I suggest that we look analytically, at least for a while, at those first two statements and the extraordinary relationship we have been able to get ourselves to accept-that is, we can accept that this society discourages violent behaviour and, at the same time, accept the truth of the statement that violent behaviour is constantly represented and reported on television. If we really address ourselves to that extraordinary contradiction we must seek some type of resolution.

One conclusion which comes to mind is that the controllers of television are really motivated by greed and indifference and are not at all concerned about the effects of anything that happens on television on those who view it. They are governed-if we are to run that argument to its end-only by the profits that can be made by showing violence on television. Unfortunately, such an explanation does not really go to the heart of the matter. The problem is that we have a view that the society discourages violent behaviour. I believe that is really where the false element in that argument lies. To take the other view is to suggest a situation which does not get us out of the dilemma at all.

Control over television viewing habits in this country, over the television systems, a major communication network, is vested in those people who want to be called-at least in churches on Sunday-the pillars of society. In other words, it is not true that this society discourages violent behaviour. I believe it is much more reasonable to say that this society encourages violent behaviour and that violent behaviour is constantly represented and reported on television, its major communication system. I believe that this report fails to face up to the eventual nature of the problem of children viewing violence-that it is not ultimately a problem for television; it is ultimately a problem for this society.

If we continue attacking only the symptom-as unfortunately this report does in a couple of places-and not the cause, there will be no solutions to the problems of violence in our society. Not only will there be no solutions but also we will see in Australia, as have people in other countries such as the United States and more recently Britain, an increase in violence. We may continue to blame that on something like television, which is only a symptom of the situation, rather than go to the heart of the matter and say that the society is structuring and organising itself in such a way as to make violence inevitable, to make violence the only way out for many people within our society. Unfortunately, in Britain it was mainly young people who were involved in those violent incidents.

Violence stems not from viewing violence on television. The real violence in our society stems from the degradation, the poverty and the oppression of so many groups within our society. That is where the real violence lies and that is the violence which will ultimately cause the breakup of our type of society. Therefore, I wish that a report such as this, rather than constantly bringing forward the problems at a superficial or simplistic level, would address itself to the ultimate cause of violence in our society, and that is the structure of wealth and the distribution of that wealth in this society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hearn Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to draw attention to the fact that sufficient emphasis has not been put on the danger to children of the actual act of watching television. When Senator Teague was speaking about education the other night he drew attention to the large number of students who lacked the ability to master the basic skills, particularly the skill of communication, communication being the ability not only to communicate information and ideas but also to imagine, to grasp, to understand, to listen and to hear. In various places in the world many people such as doctors, teachers, psychologists and neurologists are seriously questioning whether young children should be watching television at all. Indeed, the British Broadcasting Corporation has a childrens' program which says: 'Switch off and go and climb trees'. It recommends that children go and do something else altogether. It is not just the effect of what is on the program that is important but the effect of the child sitting before a television set for many hours at a time. The simple act of watching encourages passivity, poor concentration, distortion of perception and reality and a lack of development of the child's whole sense of perception.

SPEECH.PARA: A book by Marie Winn, published in the United States of America in 1976 entitled Plug-In-Drug points to the fact that television watching is inimical to healthy child development, mental, physical and psychological. For the young child, seeing is imitating. What models do we give to young children who sit in front of television imitating what they see? Often by the time children start school they have already been damaged by watching too much television. Young toddlers are sat in front of televisions, sometimes for quite a number of hours and I do not think parents are aware of the dangers that this can do to them.

It is said that television is a time stealer. It steals the childhood from children-that time when they should be active, playing, developing their imagination and their social interaction, reading and talking with other children and with their parents. That is when they develop the capacity to communicate. Many young children who just watch television are denied that period in childhood whey they should spend their time drawing, writing and doing all the things that little children do to try to express what they have seen in the world around them. A child imitates the every day happenings in the world around him, in his home and his neighbourhood and then he recreates them in his play. His play is a vital part of acquiring social skills and co-ordination, the activity of exploring, just having fun and living in their own individuality, instead of just sitting in front of a television set living through some fantasy on the screen. Television deprives small children of these experiences. It also affects their whole central nervous system so that they develop in an unbalanced way. This is where the problems arise when they later go to school. They are then not able to picture things, as they have lost the ability to develop vocabulary and to think.

The exercise of the senses is very important for children to be fully conscious and fully awake. Unless they can develop their total senses through their childhood up to the ages of seven or 10, they can be very badly deprived of the things that are necessary for their proper development. Work has been done in this area by Dr John Ott, who became famous for his work with X-rays and television. He has done tests with rats and plants in the same room as a television set. The effect on the rats was that they became very aggressive and hyperactive for about 10 days and then they became totally passive because their system had been damaged. The plants that were put before the television became distorted, their roots growing upwards and their leaves huge and out of proportion.

The other danger to young children is that watching too much television develops a consumer mentality. It also develops anti-social attitudes. I think previous speakers have spoken of those matters. When we think of a suitable environment for children, we think of play and grass, trees, flowers, the beach, sand and animals. We think of living things. These are the things children should be playing with and using in their development.

I think many parents who watch television are not aware of the dangers it creates for their children. I would like to see a report emphasising these dangers. I would also like to see further research into the effects of the very act of watching television and the results publicised in the community. I think half the problems we are experiencing in the field of education are caused by the uneven development of young children and by the fact that they are not able to develop that area which is normal for their development. When they eventually come to school they are lacking in those experiences which enable them to be educated.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON PASSENGER FARES AND SERVICES TO AND FROM TASMANIA

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 August, on motion by Senator Peter Rae:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak briefly about the report of the Select Committee on Passenger Fares and Services to and from Tasmania, which has already been spoken to by Senator Peter Rae and Senator Tate. I, along with Senator Grimes, was on the Committee with those honourable senators. I do not know how many different inquiries have been held into Tasmania, but on looking into the history of the matter we found that there had been almost continual inquiries. Keeping Tasmania and Tasmanians connected to the mainland in one way or another and as cheaply as possible is something that all governments have always taken seriously. As we went around Tasmania, even though I suppose each of us had more of an interest in the particular area in which we lived-though we represent the whole State-we learnt a tremendous amount.

SPEECH.PARA: We received some very good submissions and heard many very good witnesses. We became aware of the particular problems of particular areas from right down south to the islands just west of north-west of Tasmania-King Island and Flinders Island. People gave us submissions, most of which I think are covered in the report and in the speech which Senator Peter Rae made. I think we were upstaged a little by the Government bringing in the 10 per cent subsidy for Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans Australia Airlines following the report of the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares, because I think that the subsidy is one of the things we might have been able to recommend. Had we recommended it, it would have been at a higher rate than 10 per cent. In some ways I do not think subsidies are the answer because they can be left at a certain level in money terms and therefore be eroded by inflation or they can be removed altogether by a government, though a government would need a lot of political courage to remove some subsidies applying to Tasmania. Nevertheless, subsidies can be removed.

I think the application of that subsidy to the air fares acknowledges the disadvantage of living in Tasmania and the disadvantage that Tasmanians have in having to travel in the majority of cases by air from Tasmania to the mainland. Those who live on Flinders Island and King Island are at an even greater disadvantage. Our Committee recommended that those people be favourably treated. The subsidy has certainly shown that the Government acknowledges the disadvantage.

When it is realised that in most areas 70 per cent of the people drive to their holiday destination, it can be seen that Tasmanians are at a disadvantage because they have to fly or sail to their destinations. That is something which worried the Committee a great deal. We spent a great deal of time looking at shipping to and from the different areas of Tasmania, and we came to the conclusion that sooner or later, and most probably sooner, the Government will have to make some decision about the Empress of Australia, which sails between Melbourne and Devonport. I think the situation is due to be surveyed in about five years time. Although some of the people travelling on the ship told us that they felt that it was in quite a good state and could continue for a lot longer, there must be concern about a replacement. To replace a ship such as the Empress of Australia these days would cost in the order of $36m. The interest on that money is perhaps more than Australia can really afford to pay. Therefore we looked at some way of combining the capacity of that ship with some of the freighter ships that go back and forth between Tasmania and the mainland. That is why we suggested that two ships, not one should operate. We suggested that one of the ships carrying 450 passengers, cars and freight could ply between Melbourne and Devonport. We looked at the other alternative destinations, such as Westernport Bay and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about swimming?
—I do not know whether anybody has tried to swim to Tasmania. However, if aircraft travel becomes much more expensive I can imagine a lot of the people of Tasmania would like to swim away.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, we decided on two ships, one of which would carry 450 passengers, freight and cars between Melbourne and Devonport and the other which would be used at times perhaps to level out the peaks if there were not enough passenger demand to keep it operating all the time. I think there would certainly be enough freight demand between Melbourne and Burnie. I am not convinced that enough passenger demand could not be generated to keep two ships in operation between Tasmania and the mainland all the time. Our suggested total passenger capacity of just under 700 people is somewhat less that I personally would have liked. I was a little hesitant to agree with this proposition. However, I did agree. I should say that the two Liberal and two Labor senators on the Committee were in unanimous agreement on the report. Not once did the deliberations of the Committee get down to tribal warfare of the kind that I have occasionally seen in this place between Tasmanians from different sides of the political fence. It was a pleasant committee on which to serve. The Committee took a lot longer to report than I thought it would. In due course I suppose we will find that for some reason or other yet another inquiry with regard to Tasmania will be instigated. I hope that this will not happen for quite a while. However, if another committee is set up and I happen to be a member of it, I hope it will be made up of people as pleasant to deal with as those senators on this Committee. I thank members of the Committee for their co-operation. I thank also all those who helped us, and particularly the Committee staff.

Finally, I reiterate that we felt that air fares could be brought down quite markedly if Tasmania operated a single airline across the Strait. From evidence we know that regional operators in the United States of America which operate with pretty full loads are able to charge lower fares than exist in this country at the moment. But such an arrangement is a long way off. I hope that the north-west Tasmanian situation is looked at very urgently, particularly in regard to the upgrading of one or both of the airports to small jet standard. I am pleased to see that Hobart airport is already being upgraded to enable larger aircraft to operate into that port.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few remarks on a couple of aspects of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Passenger Fares and Services to and from Tasmania. I was not a member of the Committee but I congratulate the four senators who served on it for the work they did in producing yet another report on Tasmanian transport. I regret that only Tasmanian senators have spoken in this debate. I would have liked to think that other honourable senators would have read the report and would have wanted to make some contribution. It seems to be very much a closed shop discussion-I think that is a pity. Perhaps one or two non-Tasmanian senators should have been included in the membership of the Committee in the first place to ensure that there was some outside observation. I suppose it is a little difficult to gauge what the Government's response is likely to be or what the response on the mainland is likely to be when senators from other States have not spoken in this debate.
—Senator, I just indicate that I thought the tables were very interesting. They give a lot of information you don't often see concerning the transport needs of Tasmania.
—I am not criticising the report. I am saying that it is good. I am glad that at least the Minister has seen that there are tables in the report even if he has not read every word of it.

SPEECH.PARA: There would have been no need for this Committee to be established if one of the actions of the previous Labor Government had been followed up by this Government. The Senate may recall that before the 1972 election Labor promised to set up an inquiry into all aspects of transport to and from Tasmania and to legislate to re-establish the Inter-State Commission as is provided for in the Constitution. The report before the Senate recommends that the Inter-State Commission be re-established. In fact, legislation in respect of the Inter-State Commission was passed in 1975 and was to be proclaimed. However, the legislation was not able to be proclaimed by the time this Government came to power, and it has still not been proclaimed. The Inter-State Commission would have been a permanent watchdog on the needs of transport between all States but in particular between the mainland and Tasmania because air and sea transport are so crucial to Tasmania's communications.

Even though this report is concerned with passenger fares, I would like to make a side reference to the Commission of Inquiry into Transport to and from Tasmania-the Nimmo report. Unfortunately the Commission did not report before we left office. However, it was the Labor Party which initiated the whole idea of freight equalisation between Tasmania and the mainland. That report came to the present Government which certainly gained quite a lot of kudos from implementing a freight equalisation scheme. I remind the Senate that this freight equalisation scheme was established as a result of a Labor Government initiative of establishing the Nimmo Commission before the 1972 election and during its time in office. I recall that there was not unanimous support from our opponents when the Inter-State Commission Bill was being dealt with a few years ago. Therefore I hope that the recommendation that the Commission be re-established is not shot down in flames.

One of the main recommendations of the current report on passenger fares to Tasmania is that either the two existing national airline operators be replaced by a single regional operator or a third operator be allowed to compete with the existing national airlines. I appreciate all the reasons for this recommendation. To have so much parallel scheduling is so wasteful, especially from Tasmania's point of view. We all know the stupidity of such an arrangement. One of the small victories that I can remember in our time in office was changing one set of parallel scheduling by agreement between the airlines. One of the daily services out of Hobart was changed. Previously both services went either straight to Melbourne or to Melbourne via Launceston. After the changes the airlines altenated, one flying Hobart-Launceston-Melbourne and the other direct to Melbourne. As I recall, it was a battle to get even a small change to the parallel scheduling. But that was achieved. It ought to happen more often. It would be preferable, in my view, if there were only one operator, as long as that operator was the publicly owned one, Trans Australia Airlines. I doubt that Ansett Airlines of Australia would agree to that. That is why there is the suggestion that an entirely different company be the single operator.

I have some reservations about this recommendation mainly because of Tasmania's image with the rest of Australia and overseas for that matter. There is some advantage in its being seen as part of Australia and so as part of the national trunk network served by the same airlines which serve the major cities of the rest of Australia. Enough people have the attitude already that Tasmania is a separate entity not quite part of the rest of the nation without the further obvious separation involved if it were to be served by an entirely different airline almost as though it were an overseas country. With that indication of a slight reservation on my part I state my support for the thrust of the main recommendations of the report and congratulate the Committee on it.

I turn now to another aspect of the report. I do not mean to deal comprehensively with Tasmania's transport problems or even just the subject matter of the report, but perhaps not everyone remembers in thinking about Tasmania the Bass Strait islands. Even if people recognise the problems of Tasmanian transport they forget about the Bass Strait islands such as King Island, Flinders Island and others of the Furneaux group. I will read the commentary on the Bass Strait islands from the report. It states:

Tasmania's problems of isolation are compounded for the residents of the Bass Strait Islands because not only do they lack many essential services, but they are also completely dependent on air travel.
Submissions to the Committee from the Bass Strait Islands argued for a subsidised air fare. Commissioner Nimmo--
I referred to this earlier-
in his report on transport to and from Tasmania in 1976, recommended that the Commonwealth Government subsidise air fares to the Islands. The Government rejected that recommendation.

The Committee received details of various employer schemes for travel concessions for residents of the Bass Strait Islands. Commonwealth, State and local governments, as well as some large employers, had a range of schemes, some quite generous. However, not everyone on the Islands received these concessions.

The Committee concludes that compensation is justified for travel to and from the Bass Strait Islands and recommends that a twenty per cent concession on the air fare be immediately introduced, to be funded by the Commonwealth Government.

I strongly support that recommendation. I remind the Senate of the existence of those islands and of the Australian citizens who live on them. I hope that the Government in its response will take up that recommendation amongst others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take up one of the points Senator Coates made at the start of his speech when he said that the contributions made tonight will be useful to the Government in examining the report from the Senate Select Committee on Passenger Fares and Services to and from Tasmania and in preparing a response to the Parliament on the report. The honourable senator will know that the Government tries to respond within six months of the presentation of a report. As a result of this debate having come on with some expedition the speeches of honourable senators will be available for consideration by Ministers when they are preparing the response. I assure the honourable senator that the debate that has taken place here tonight will be of considerable help to Government. I hope the Government response can come within the agreed time and, indeed, that some of the recommendations may be taken up. I hope they can be considered carefully.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Senator Walsh asked me a question without notice this morning about possible loss of Government revenue resulting from proposals contained in the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981 standing in my name. The money affected by the Bill referred to by Senator Walsh this morning is made up of money held in both savings bank accounts and building society accounts. In the savings bank accounts the relevant details are as follows: An amount of $9,715m is held in investment accounts offering 10 per cent interest per annum. There are some 1,998,000 of those accounts, with an average account level of $5,000. This provides an annual interest bill of $971.5m. Other bank accounts, averaging between 3 3/4 per cent and 6 1/4 per cent interest, involve 20.5 million accounts with an average account level of $655, giving an annual interest bill of $655m.

SPEECH.PARA: In the building societies $9,081m is invested in accounts offering 8 1/4 to 9 per cent interest, providing $817.2m in interest annually. Therefore, the total annual interest involved is in the vicinity of $2,443.7m. Not all of this money is subject to taxation since a component of these accounts comes from small depositers whose annual income is not large enough to put them into a taxation bracket. We estimate that this component accounts for something like $947.1m, leaving a potential for tax on the remaining $1,496.6m. The interest on the major part of this money is at the base tax rate so the estimated loss to revenue is in the vicinity of $500m from funds already in savings banks or building society accounts paying 10 per cent or less interest per annum.

A further potential tax loss of up to $300m could come from people transferring funds from higher interest bearing accounts which are not tax exempt to the lesser interest bearing accounts which do offer a tax concession. The estimated total loss of revenue to the Government from the scheme outlined by me in my second reading speech last Wednesday is therefore in the vicinity of $800m. This is reasonably in accord with the amount mentioned by Senator Walsh this morning. However, some $200m of this loss should be offset by probable increased welfare housing costs resulting from an increasing inability of people to buy or build privately. This estimate is contained in a recent Housing Industry Association paper by Dr Ron Silberg entitled 'Measuring Need for Rental Housing Assistance'. Interested honourable senators can consult that at their leisure, but the figures are set out in it. Therefore, we estimate that an actual revenue loss of $600m would occur. However, if this amount were used for low interest home loans at least 10,000 extra families each year could buy or build a home of their own. The influence this would have on expenditure and employment in the building industry would justify the implementation of the scheme.

DEBATE.TITLE: MATTERS RELATING TO TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 August, on motions:
That the Senate take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few remarks on the subject of transport, a vital industry whose future we should consider seriously. Australia's transport is possibly the dearest in the world. The Senate should undertake serious measures to investigate just what can be done to develop and improve this country's transportation system. If that is not done, Australia will lag far behind many other countries. For many years transport has been treated on an ad hoc basis. When we consider what the State governments have done and the different rail guages that have resulted we cannot help wondering just how long such a system could or should last. Australian National, as I believe Australian National Railways is now called, should progressively take over rail transport. Many lines in Australia are totally inadequate as well as in the wrong place. A complete review should be made of the country's rail system.

SPEECH.PARA: Also, we should consider seriously improving our shipping and out air transport. This is a very large country with a very small population, and unless we can improve our transportation system I do not believe that we will be able to compete on world markets. The Senate should consider seriously setting up a body, probably a committee, which can consider the improvement of our transport system over the long range. All political parties should contribute. If we are to improve out transport system that will not be achieved in the short term. Probably it will take 50 years to complete and for that purpose ongoing funding will be needed.

It may surprise many to learn that Australia had the first pure container ship in the world. Much could be done to move cargo from one port to another in ships. Again, there is need to consider seriously just how we should go about that. More thought should be devoted to the subject. It cannot be approached haphazardly. Long term planning is the answer.

I believe that air transport is the only way for Australians to travel any distance. The major airlines, Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans-Australia Airlines, should get out of commuter air transport services and concentrate on catering for the major trunk lines. Smaller airlines can service country areas far more satisfactorily. They can procure more suitable planes and provide a better service to country people. Whereas the Government provides financial help to the major airlines to purchase aircraft, it does very little or nothing to help the smaller airlines. I know of one company in South Australia that wanted to buy a Nomad aircraft. It found it impossible to raise finance in this country for that purpose. The company was obliged to go to Brazil to buy an aircraft. It was able to obtain financing from the Government of Brazil at an interest rate of 8 per cent. Australian airlines that wish to buy local aircraft such as the Nomad should be given some financial assistance to do so. I repeat, no help whatever is extended to the small companies, which provide the major growth area for employment in Australia. The Government has said many times that it will help small business people, but when it really comes to the crunch no help whatever is given.

To return to the subject of land transportation, we should not simply rely on interstate semi-trailers to move goods. It is a very wasteful system. Our rail systems should be improved. Main lines between capital cities should be electrified and duplicated, and a fast service between the States provided in order to overcome present difficulties. The lines that go out into the country should be upgraded and placed in the right areas. Feeder services should be provided to rail heads.

Better planning co-ordination should exist between the States. Roads that are used to provide feeder services to rail heads should be upgraded and widened. A whole range of improvements should be under way, but no one has yet begun to think about, or plan for, the long term. Unless this is done the nation will regret it in the years to come. As fuel becomes scarcer and dearer, our transport system should increasingly be the subject of planning.

Unfortunately, we have allowed ship building to get away from us. It is cheaper, we are told, to buy ships overseas. I disagree with that theory. This nation should participate in the building of its ships. If the shipyards at Whyalla and Newcastle had been upgraded and modern technology introduced we would have been able to build not only our merchant fleet but also the warships that we buy overseas. I believe those vessels should have been built here. This country has a tendency to buy overseas. The more this is done the more we lose the techniques and skills of our workers, a trend that is to Australia's detriment. Transport is vital to us, as are our communications. More thought could have been given to those subjects. If it had, I believe Australia could have come up with the right answers. Australians have invented many things. I believe we could lead the world in some of these fields. Because Australia is a large country with a small population there is a need to build ships and trains suitable for this country. We have a sufficient number of people with the intelligence, given encouragement and financial support, to come up with the right answers. Unless long term planning is introduced I think this country will be in trouble.

Perhaps at some future time the Senate may care to look seriously at our transport system. I hope the Australian Democrats will support any move in this direction. Irrespective of what side of politics one supports, I believe there is a desperate need for ongoing planning to be supported by us all. There is a tendency in this country to plan only for the short term and I believe it is inadequate. We have to plan for many years ahead. Our objectives cannot be achieved overnight. Because of the mistakes that have been brought about by the rivalries that have existed between the States, our transport system today is a shambles. That is simply not good enough. I hope in the future that in a Federal parliament such as this we will be able, with common sense, to reach a consensus on bringing about a reasonably economical transport system. I believe it is in the Senate that we may be able to reach the consensus necessary to achieve that end. I leave it at that. It is food for thought. I believe this to be a serious matter and we should all be starting to think about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak for a few minutes on the report on the general aviation study which, for the great benefit of the people of Australia-
—Here we go.

—No, this is not what I had intended to speak about before dinner, unfortunately. For the great benefit of the people of Australia, this general aviation study has been thrown out by the Government. It would not have been of any value at all to the people of Australia. The presentation of the report was accompanied by record and unprecedented protest crowds involving members of a very law abiding section of the community, namely the pilots and engineers. The report received universal condemnation from them, and well it might have because it displayed a very marked philosophic bias, a lack of objectivity, poor scholarship and contained quite a large number of errors.

SPEECH.PARA: General aviation is defined under Air Navigation Regulation 191 as embracing four broad categories. They are private operations, aerial work, charter, and regular public transport. The first three of those categories-private, aerial work and charter work-fall into the general aviation section. In the general aviation study, that functional breakup was split into several categories. The first contained community services like the Royal Flying Doctor Service, the Air Ambulance Service, shark spotting and search and rescue operations. The second category is commuter services. For the benefit of honourable senators I would differentiate commuter services from charter operations because they are virtually an RPT service-a regular passenger transport service-operating under several exemptions which are provided for under ANR 203 which allows some concessions in respect of equipment performance standards. Another category is charter services, which are freight services and non-scheduled passenger traffic, followed by private, commercial and ancillary operations, personal flying, agricultural aviation, flying training and, a very minor category, international general aviation.

The general aviation sector is a very large sector of the industry. It is the dominant sector in the aviation community in Australia. In 1979, out of 5,997 aircraft on the Australian register, 5,865 were in the general aviation category compared with only 132 in the RPT airline category.

The general aviation study is based on the simple argument of the cost recovery doctrine. Very simply, that looks at taking the whole cost of providing aviation services to Australia, grouping the users of those services, attributing a ratio to those users in the aviation community and dividing that into the total cost, thus coming up with a percentage for the cost recovery figures. By this formula the Department of Transport computes that the general aviation sector is paying only 12.6 per cent of the costs attributed to it. The general public, naturally, is very concerned that only 12.6 per cent of the costs attributed to a sector is being recovered but it is a most specious argument.

I will look at some points in relation to that argument. First of all, is the concept of cost recovery a valid concept? Secondly, how is the grouping, which leads to how the ratios are set, determined? I have a substantial point of divergence from the concept of cost recovery, or the user pays doctrine. The concept of cost recovery involves no recognition at all of the place of aviation in the defence infrastructure in this country, the economic benefits that accrue to the whole of the community or the improvement in the quality of life that aviation services bring to the Australian nation.

The fact that we have an aviation industry in this country-a maintenance organisation and a flying organisation-gives us a very real infrastructure, both in human terms and in hardware, from a defence point of view. The economic benefits to Australia from the general aviation industry are hard to measure. But there is a gain to business because people are able to use private aircraft to travel around the country. It might surprise some honourable senators to learn that aircraft are as fuel efficient as many cars and they are certainly a good deal quicker. In a vast country such as Australia, the ability to move around it in a direct line is one of the great advantages provided by the aviation industry.

Tourism is also very dependent on the aviation industry. It depends on international services, the trunk services, the regional operators and the general aviation sector. There is a great multiplier effect. The people who are employed as a consequence in motels and in the tourist industry generally benefit Australia's economy. As to quality of life, this country is a large one. There are many isolated country areas. In times of flood, and even drought, the ability to move equipment and supplies by air adds immeasurably to the quality of life of people who live in the distant parts of Australia.

I do not accept the user pays concept in its bald terms because I think it denies the advantages that I have been talking about. After all, we do not use the user pays concept for education. Whenever the Government has tried to bring it in, as we did in respect of fees for the higher educational degrees, we have met quite a community reaction to it. But somehow or other we tolerate it for the--

TALK.START.PARA: —Were you in agreement with them?

—I am in agreement with it for higher degrees. I think there is a valid economic argument for it there. But that is a diversion and I would thank you, senator, to be quiet for a while. As to the groupings, we have got to get the operators in the commuter sector out of the general aviation sector because, really, they are mini airlines. That is the sector that places demands on the Department of Transport for navigation aids, airfields and all the infrastructure support that the rest of the general aviation community does not need. I exclude charter operators from the commuter service sector because many charter operators live away from the main airports such as Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne. They are based out west. They might move across the length and breadth of the country but they never go into controlled air space. However, it is essential that we regroup the bodies which the Department of Transport at present put into the general aviation sector if we are to go down the path of cost recovery.

SPEECH.PARA: Now we come to the actual costs which have been attributed to the sector. The report does not address two very important factors. First of all, there is really no control by the users of the services given to them. There is no way that the users can challenge what those ratios are. The Aviation Industrial Advisory Council is a body set up to advise the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) on this matter, but the general aviation sector is represented on it by only one member out of five or six members. It really is a case of taxation without representation. A consequence of that is that we have a body which is vastly over-regulated. Pilots really do not need that much regulation. Usually they are people with quite a degree of common sense. They recognise the difficulties and the dangers of the environment in which they are operating. As one of the great literary figures of the modern age, Ernest Gann, who was a professional airline captain for most of his life, said in one of his books: 'Pilots really are very simple, direct people, or they die sudden, violent deaths'.

TALK.START.PARA: —He wrote a very good book on the fishing fleets off San Francisco as well.

—He has many talents. I return to the point of the excessive regulation of the industry. The facilities that are provided for the general aviation sector-the airports and the navigational aids-are way beyond what that sector requires. As the report establishes, most of the operations of the general aviation sector are VFR operations, undertaken under visual flight rules on the basis of see and be seen. In the worst sense, that is a case of over prescription.

SPEECH.PARA: To learn the ratios assigned to the sector by the Department we turn to page 165 of the report, where we see a table headed 'Allocation of Costs by Aviation Sector and Location 1977-78'. The top line lists six types of airports ranging from competitive airports and to special airports. On the vertical side of the scale are balanced international airlines, trunk airlines, rural airlines, commuter operators and other general aviation operators.

The attribution of costs there just does not make sense. For example, the first column deals with competition ports, which really are the international airports such as those at Brisbane, Sydney, Melbourne and Perth, where the facilities are set up primarily for regular public transport operations, both internally and internationally. The cost attribution is $33.8m for the international airlines and $38.1-$5m more-for other general aviation operators. If I want to fly to Sydney I will run out of fuel before I get to the airport there because it is not an accessible airport for the average general aviation traffic. It is nonsense to have that kind of attribution of costs.

I turn to the classification of commuter airports, which are airfields specifically for commuter operations. We find that the cost attribution to the commuter airlines is $1.9m, yet $11.5m, nearly six times more, is attributed to general aviation. That is nonsense. Those sorts of figures cannot be justified. A bunch of bureaucrats who do not understand what is going on just fill in a report to keep themselves in a job. I believe that the commuter airlines need to be shifted out of this sector because they are the ones leading to the high cost attributions. They are the group that must have navaids around the country. They are the ones that must have sealed runways for all weather operations, passenger terminals and all the other infrastructure. The VFR sector, the true general aviation sector, does not require any of that. All it requires are grass airfields and to be left alone by the bureaucracy. That sector has had enough of the bureaucracy.
Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why they fly. They fly to get away from people on the ground.

SPEECH.PARA: At present, the general aviation sector is being financed by what are known as air navigation charges, which are similar to the registration charges on a car. One pays an annual registration fee for an aircraft, and that has covered the levies by the Department up until the present. Again, that is a rather absurd classification because it is based on aircraft weight. It requires a peculiar mind to say that, if one aircraft in a small category-that is, the small, single engined fixed undercarriage aircraft-is a little bit heavier than another, it should pay more to fly, even though both aircraft are doing similar tasks. Something like that cannot be substantiated. There should be a uniform charge.

The report proposed quite a severe increase in air navigation charges and a movements charge. It was really the movements charge which infuriated the industry because it meant that every time an aircraft landed or took off at any one of a large number of airfields around the country, a fee would be charged for it. If anyone has ever been in a control tower at a busy secondary airport, where aircraft are taking off and landing the whole time and departing to parts all over the Commonwealth, the mind boggles at trying to work out a bill for each one on the basis of movements, of landing and taking off. It is so impractical that I cannot understand how anyone could propose it. It is also ruinously expensive for anyone who wants to fly and maintain competency, who wishes to go in a circuit and maybe do 10 or 15 circuits in an hour. It is just a nonsense.

There has been a history of deteriorating advice to the Minister from the Department of Transport ever since we got away from the Department of Civil Aviation and had this huge conglomeration called the Department of Transport, which worships the idea that if anything moves it is transport and that if one understands how something moves one can handle any sort of movement. That is nonsense. I give an example as I believe you are a Queenslander, Mr Acting Deputy President and you will appreciate this. When I learned to fly we flew out of Archerfield, an airfield one mile square. It was a grass airfield known as an all over field. The only thing the tower told a pilot was the landing directions-north-east, south-west or whatever it was, depending on the wind. There could be half a dozen or a dozen aircraft on final approach at the same time and they automatically spread themselves out over a one-mile front and landed. There were no problems and no hassles. One man in the tower controlled the whole lot. If a pilot wanted to file a flight plan he just went to the tower and while the controller was announcing a landing direction he took the plan. Then what happened? Progress came. We went to a strip system. Series of strips were designated. They were not sealed strips; they were just areas pegged and marked with cones. We were told that if we did that we would be guaranteed the use of the airfield in the future because no one would build on the approach paths, there would be no noise problems-shades of last year and the protest movement around Acacia Ridge.

Then we went to a triple runway system. Three runway directions were designated and three runways were put in in three directions. That led to the most horrendous air traffic control problems because one landed on one strip, took off from another and did touch and goes on the third. The circuit, which was a nice stable and safe place, became like peak hour in a busy city, with aircraft cutting in and doing all sorts of unpleasant and potentially dangerous things. Incidentally, while we had a triple runway system we had to increase the manning strength in the tower. We had to have a whole lot of people in the tower. We had to have relief staff in case someone was sick or not available. We had to have shifts. Therefore, the cost of operating the airfield went up astronomically. Although I have attended hearings of the appropriate Estimates committees, I have never been able to find out how much it costs to run Archerfield. The only progress we have made has been in bumping up the cost to the community.

The final proposal is that we are to have two runways instead of the triple runway system. We will have conflicting counter-rotating circuits. Can anyone imagine a more dangerous situation than a training airfield with two aircraft on base leg flying towards each other and turning on to two runways? I cannot imagine it. It is an example of the bureaucratic mind at work again.

Another thing concerning the aviation industry is this business of biennial flight checks. Again, the snake oil merchants in the Department of Transport are saying there is a high accident rate in general aviation and that the cure for it is to bring in biennial checks. They say they will make everyone with a licence do a flight check every two years; after all, all the professional pilots do it. It is a very plausible argument. It is so simple one wonders why it did not occur to them before. However, it is just as false and just as falacious as the general avaition study that the Department produced. They are dissembling; it is a half truth. The accident rate for private pilots, or the general aviation sector, is not very high. More importantly, the accident rate is coming down. Statistics cannot be taken on a year by year basis because the accident rate is so low, but over a 10, 15 and 20 year period even blind Freddy could see that in proportion to the number of hours flown the accident rate is coming down. But we are told that in the interests of safety there has to be a biennial review.

Of course, if one can strike the mantle of safety when dealing with the Department, anything can be got through. I have served on hospital committees in many parts of the world and whenever we could not get a piece of equipment we had only to say that a patient would die if we did not have it, and immediately the money was made available. Precisely the same is true with the Department of Transport. All the people in the Department have to say is that it is a matter of safety and that lives will be lost unless we have the biennial flight checks. So the most horrendous and draconian legislation is introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —But take a pilot with excessive blood pressure. Wouldn't he be a high risk if he got dizzy flying into Kingsford-Smith airport?

—That is quite right, but I want to inform honourable senators about that. Every two years a pilot must renew his licence but before he can do that he has to undergo a quite stringent medical examination. That is quite different from a flight test. This flight test is a real harassment to me. It is a real harassment to me, coming from Queensland, and to the people I represent. It places a very high economic penalty on them. As I will show, it serves no purpose whatsoever. Quite typically, it was introduced without reference to this Parliament. It came in as a regulation from the bureaucracy and we just did not have any say about it. The recency criterion, of so many hours-three or five hours, or whatever it was-spent in command before renewal, will be removed. The proposal is that every two years before a licence is renewed a pilot will have to show that a flight test has been done with and A1 flight instructor. The air navigation regulations do not define what that test will be.

SPEECH.PARA: What will the test do? The Department says it will not gain from any financial or empire building aspect because the tests will be carried out by designated instructors in flying schools and organisations such as those. The Americans have had this requirement and have seen that it does not work. They have evidence over about 10 years to prove that it does not work. At least the Americans do not require a pilot to prove he has done a flight test. The Department will have to have proof that a pilot has done the flight test, so there will be more bits of paper coming in and there will be a bunch of clerks handling them. There is also postage and other things to be considered.

I wish to make some points about this matter. What is being tested and what are the causes of accidents in general aviation? The first point about testing is that a pilot will merely do a flight test before an instructor. I have only ever flown with one instructor who in my judgment was dangerous as an airman. I think all the other instructors I have flown with have been excellent airmen-way above the average. But the almost universal failing they have is that they cannot teach.

TALK.START.PARA: —They can't see?

—They cannot teach. That is rather different from not being able to see. I cannot see the point of having pilots who cannot fly very well going before instructors who created the situation because of the fact that they could not teach. The problem will not be made any better. The correct approach to this is to put the instructors through a central flying school, which we should have. We seem to have no shortage of money for building colleges of advanced education and things of that nature to teach people basket making, pottery and that sort of thing. The Victorian and New South Wales countryside is littered with monuments to this sort of hobby endeavour. We should be putting money into things like a central flying school so that we can lift and standardise the level of instruction in the general aviation sector through the flight instructors.

SPEECH.PARA: Any flight test will be of a practical nature and will be likely to test no more than aeronautical skill. It will not test the judgment of the pilot in any way. Judgment is the crucial thing; that is what we want to get at. Having read the Aviation Safety Digest, the excellent publication that the Department has produced I suppose for over 30 years, I am driven to the firm belief that accidents fall into four categories. The most common category is weather-related accidents. The second category is improper judgment of operational conditions, often by very experienced pilots. The third category-it is a minor category-is mechanical failure, and the fourth category, which is even smaller again includes unforeseen circumstances. No flight test will cope with those basic causes of accidents. A flight test will not assess the competence of a pilot to avoid a weather-related accident, flying into bad weather and into instrument conditions. At best this flight test would look at a limited display of aeronautical skills.

The accident history of training flights in Australia indicates that pilots flying solo with very limited experience have a surprisingly low accident rate. Not many pilots are killed in training. I am driven to this conclusion: What is the need for this test? What are we trying to do with it? Earlier I said that the accident rate was surprisingly low, and it is falling. The figures I have been able to get show that there were 42.28 accidents per 100,000 hours flown in 1976. That figure fell to 28.16 accidents for 100,000 hours in 1978 and in 1979 the figure was down to 19.19 accidents. That is a very short data base, only three years, but I have looked at the situation over longer periods of 10 and 15 years and quite clearly the accident rate is diminishing. I come back to the question: Why are we introducing this biennial test, unless it is just to harass the ordinary citizen?

A very real economic cost is involved in this. I was speaking to someone in my electorate the other day and he told me that to fly from Charleville to Brisbane to do this biennial flight test and back again will cost over $400. That is an imposition that he should not have to bear. One of the people in the aviation organisation told me of a person in the backblocks of Western Australia who will have to travel to Darwin to do his biennial review, and he estimates that it will cost him $1,000 just to renew his licence. Not all pilots own their own aircraft. In fact, the very great majority of them do not. Over 25 per cent of general aviation operators are in located rural regions. Let us look at fuel consumption. We have a national energy policy; we are trying to conserve fuel. Over 24,000 pilots are on the private pilot section of the register. If half of those, 12,000 have to do a biennial review every year, they will each burn 7 or 8 gallons of fuel an hour-30 litres an hour-so we can work out for ourselves what a huge and absolutely unnecessary cost that will involve.

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't prove a thing.

—That is right; it does not prove a darned thing. It is just a waste of time. People in the community do not understand that the Government can support a department that goes on in this way. Of course, the final insult added to the injury was the business that went on last week with the air traffic controllers in the State of Queensland. They are prepared to close Mount Isa, they are prepared not to open Proserpine on Thursdays, because of a shortage of air traffic controllers, and they are proposing to close Brisbane airport from 9 o'clock until midnight seven days a week. If that does not show bad management or a lack of planning, I want to know what does. It is time we had an inquiry into the whole of the departmental operations in aviation in this country. Things have just gone from bad to worse ever since the Labor Party consolidated the Department of Transport and appointed the present administrators to senior positions. Once upon a time we had people in the Department of Civil Aviation who had a superb level of professional skill and expertise. They have now gone. They do not want to be running light houses, they do not want to be running trains. They have moved away from the area and we have people in their places who are just career public servants, people who know nothing about a very specialised field of operation.

SPEECH.PARA: With particular reference to the subject on which I am talking tonight, the general aviation study, we need a different grouping of the general aviation groups. We must get the commuter airlines out of general aviation. We must have a separate department of civil aviation and we need to get rid of those people who are at present at the top of the Department of Transport.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.

The speeches read as follows-
Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1-9) 1981

These Bills will give effect to the proposal announced in the Budget Speech to increase the various rates of sales tax by 2 1/2 percentage points. The Bills will increase the respective rates from 2 1/2 per cent to 5 per cent, from 15 per cent to 17 1/2 per cent and from 27 1/2 per cent to 30 per cent. The nine amending Bills are necessary because sales tax is imposed by nine separate Acts in order to meet the constitutional requirement that an Act imposing taxation shall deal with only one subject of Taxation. Increased rates of tax are proposed for all goods other than those covered by the first Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act, and which are thereby exempt from sales tax.

The second Schedule to that Act identifies the goods at are to be taxed at the top rate, now to be 30 per cent. Goods embraced by the second Schedule include radio and television receivers, record players, cameras, films and photographs, watches, jewellery, cosmetics, fountain pens, certain goods made of precious metals and furs. Goods in the third Schedule to the exemptions and classifications Act have attracted a rate of 2 1/2 per cent, which is not to be increased to 5 per cent. This covers household furniture, appliances such as refrigerators, washing machines and range of household goods. Motor cars and commercial motor vehicles are in the fourth and fifth Schedules to the exemptions and classifications Act and they, together with goods not coming within the terms of any schedule to that Act, have been taxed at 15 per cent. It is proposed that they be taxed in future at 17 1/2 per cent.

Other goods also now to be taxed at 17 1/2 per cent include boats, confectionery, stationer, computers, soft drinks, potable spirits and imported wines and beers. It is customary for changes in the rates of sales tax to take effect on the day following the introduction of amending Bills and these Bills, when enacted, will accordingly operate on and after 19 August 1981.

The sales tax is basically a tax on sales at the wholesale level and, in the ordinary case of sales by a wholesaler to a retailer, the increased rates of tax will accordingly apply to sales made after Budget day. As usual, an explanatory memorandum covering technical aspects of the bills and providing, on this occasion, a detailed listing of the goods affected by these measures is being made available to honourable senators. I commend the Bills to the Senate.
Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A-9A) 1981

In the Budget Speech last week three separate sales tax changes were announced. Two of them-an increase of 2 1/2 percentage points in existing rates and the correction of a number of anomalies and inconsistencies that have crept into the law-are before the Parliament in other Bills. The Bills I am now introducing complete the legislative package and will, with effect from 1 January next, impose sales tax of 2 1/2 per cent on a range of goods that are now exempt from the tax.

In speaking last week, I drew attention to the clear advantage that lies in effecting some change in the mix of direct and indirect taxes. I spoke about, and again emphasize, the potential that such a change generates for desirable reductions in direct taxes, particularly personal income tax, as economic and budgetary conditions permit. It is said by some that the Government's Budget decision is at variance with what was put in the general statement about taxation last March. Nothing could be further from the truth, as a fair analysis of that statement and a consideration of the modest change now proposed will reveal.

As honourable senators know it is, for constitutional reasons, established practice to enact nine separate Acts when imposing sales tax. The approach in each of the present nine Bills is to impose tax of 2 1/2 per cent on goods that are identified by reference to items in the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act that at present exempt the goods from tax. These exempting items, along with a large number of other exemptions that are being retained, are contained in the first Schedule to the Exemptions and Classifications Act.

The technical effect of the Bills will be to tax at 2 1/2 per cent, on and after 1 January 1982, goods which are at present exempted by items 51, 53 54, 58, 60, 82 to 90F (inclusive), 96, 105, 107, 113F, 120 and 120A in the first Schedule. The broad classes of goods which fall within the scope of the items other than 107 and 113F are books, magazines and newspapers, building materials, packaging and wrapping materials, hand tools, clothing, footwear, drapery, soft furnishings and manchester goods. The goods covered by items 107 and 113F are, very broadly, motion picture films, servicing equipment and construction equipment. I emphasise that goods falling within any of these categories will still be exempt from sales tax if they are sold in circumstances in which an overriding exemption in the first Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act applies. By way of example, where a school entitled to exemption under item 63A purchases books for the school's use, the books will remain exempt from tax. Similarly, where a manufacturer purchases hand tools for use as ''aids to manufacture'', as defined, the tools will remain exempt under the ''aids to manufacture'' head of exemption.

I do not think that I need to go into greater detail at this stage. As usual, however, an explanatory memorandum covering technical aspects of the Bills is being made available to honourable senators and this provides details of the goods affected by these measures. The net result of the changes will be an increase in revenue estimated at some $132m in 1981-82 and $330m in a full year.

Mr President, changes in sales tax are a significant part of this year's Budget; indeed, they are an integral part of it. As I indicated earlier, the present Bills complete the legislative framework for the changes, and it is desirable that they soon become law. I therefore trust that the Senate will give these and the earlier Bills a speedy passage. In that spirit, I commend the present Bills-the Sales Tax Amendment Bill (Nos. 1A to 9A) 1981-to the Senate.
Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1981

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act to alter the sales tax classification of certain goods. Honourable senators will be aware that the Exemptions and Classifications Act not only classifies particular goods as exempt from sales tax, but also places other goods in one or other of the tax rate categories. The present Bill is primarily concerned with the alteration of those sales tax classifications. In all, there are some 36 substantial changes. In a sales tax system that has exemptions and a number of rate categories it is inevitable that at the borderline between one category and another there will be anomalies, real or apparent.

There has in fact been no general review of the sales tax classification of goods for many years and a review that has been carried out has brought to the Government's attention a number of anomalies and inconsistencies which we think should be remedied. In carrying out the review we have given attention to representations that have been made to the Government by parliamentarians and other interested people. The sales tax system operates according to a number of principles. In our review, we have endeavoured to work within these. We have been concerned to remove anomalies in classifications that give some goods a competitive advantage over other products and to achieve a greater measure of uniformity in classification. We have necessarily had to keep an eye to the revenue consequences of the possible solutions that have come up for consideration. We have found in our review that certain exemption provisions have not kept pace with technological changes.

Decisions of the courts and administrative experience have highlighted weaknesses in the law that allow exemptions beyond what was intended when the law was first framed, or that result in an unacceptable lack of clarity in the law. Some exemption items have become redundant due to changes in other laws, such as those relating to customs duties and laws covering the manufacture of motor vehicles. A number of amendments resulting from the review will bring into the taxable field goods which, for technical reasons only, have had to be accepted as exempt, although the exemption does not fit in with the general policy of the tax. Other amendments will, for consistency's sake, move goods into a higher tax bracket. However, it is not all a one way street and in some instances anomalies and inconistencies are being removed by exempting goods that are at present taxable.

Speaking in more detail, one of the important changes relates to the treatment of containers for use in marketing soft drinks. Under present law, non-returnable bottles used in marketing taxable soft drinks are exempt from sales tax, while cans used for the same purpose are taxable. Manufacturers of cans have urged the Government to remedy this inconsistent treatment. We propose to correct it by removing the exemption for non-returnable bottles and containers used in marketing soft drinks. Returnable bottles will remain exempt.

Photographic materials and products are generally taxable at 27 1/2 per cent, or 30 per cent as it will be from Budget night. However, the particular item, which was intended to cover all photographic materials, does not catch instant-type film packs which have become popular in recent times. These packs compete with conventional films and it is appropriate that they be taxed on the same basis. Similarly, photographic cameras and equipment have been taxable at 27 1/2 per cent, while projectors and other viewing equipment have been taxable at 15 per cent. Both will now attract tax at the new rate of 30 per cent. Projection equipment of the kind used for commercial purposes, such as in theatres, will remain taxable at the lower rate. Further alterations relate to the unusual position of cathode ray tubes for TV sets and motor vehicle seat belts.

A general principle of the sales tax law is that goods are classified according to their commercial identity, and not on the basis of the component parts of which they are comprised. Television receivers, of which the picture tubes form a major part, and motor vehicles, in which seat belts are fitted, are taxable as such.

However, for reasons relevant at the time but no longer applicable, provisions were introduced into the law some years ago to exempt cathode ray tubes and motor vehicle seat belts from sales tax, even where they form an integral part of taxable goods. The reasons for this special treatment having disappeared, it is proposed to repeal the relevant exemption provisions. This will result in these goods being taxed according to the identity of the product of which they form part, or in their own right when sold separately.

Foodstuffs for human consumption, but not including confectionery, are exempt from tax. Due to deficiencies in the law, the exemptions relating to foodstuffs have in some instances not operated as intended. They were never intended to exempt manufactured pet food, but exemption for this has had to be conceded under the present law. It is proposed to restrict the foodstuffs exemption to goods for human consumption, with the result that manufactured pet food will again become taxable. Food for livestock will remain exempt under other provisions.

A similar problem has arisen with certain chocolate-coated confectionery. As a general rule, confectionery is taxable. However, some confectionery lines have gained exemption on the basis that they are biscuits which are exempt under the general foodstuffs exemption. These lines compete directly with others of the same basic type and are sold as confectionery. They are now to be taxed as such.

Some industry-related exemptions in the law which are couched in wide terms do not specifically exclude road vehicles and this has led to some industries being able to obtain vehicles free of tax, while vehicles for use in other industries remain taxable. A particular problem has occurred in connexion with road vehicles used for bulk handling of grain. Relevant exemptions are to be amended to exclude road vehicles, so as to place industry use of vehicles on a more equitable footing and to prevent continuation of abuses that have occurred.

Consistent with the overall philosophy of the sales tax law in relation to motor vehicles, it is proposed to tax oil, greases and other lubricants used for motor vehicles. These goods are at present exempt whereas motor fuels are subject to excise. Mr President, these comments outline the more important alterations to sales tax classifications that will result in increases in revenue. There are others, but I think what I have said sufficiently illustrates the kind of adjustments that are to be effected by the Bill.

The other alterations will result in the withdrawal of minor exemptions and the restriction of certain business exemptions to restore them to their original intention. I think that I need not go into all of them in this introductory speech. They are fully explained in the explanatory memorandum that is being circulated to honourable senators. There is one further point, however, that I should mention. It is a feature of the sales tax law that aids to manufacture-goods used in manufacturing processes-are exempt from the tax. The Bill makes a number of amendments to the definition of aids to manufacture to clarify its meaning and to remove weaknesses. I indicated earlier that there are measures in the Bill that will reduce sales tax revenue and they are also covered in the explanatory memorandum.

There are three I would like to make some comment about at this stage. The first relates to log forwarders for use in timber-getting. The expansion of logging of softwood forests has led to the development of specialised equipment called log forwarders to haul the felled logs from the felling point in the forest to road-side pick-up points. These vehicles perform the same function as tractors, which are exempt. It is proposed, in the interests of equity and consistency, to provide an exemption for log forwarders also. I am sure the timber industry will welcome the Government's decision, both because it recognises technological advances in the industry and because log forwarders give better protection to forests than less sophisticated equipment does.

The Government has also decided that protective clothing of a kind used for sport or recreation, such as helmets, guards, gloves and mittens should no longer be taxed at the general rate. Clothing in general, including sporting clothing such as football jumpers, cricket trousers and swimwear, is at present exempt. The protective headwear, pads, gloves and mittens are worn primarily to protect participants from injury and it is proposed to bring these goods into line with clothing in general.

Exemption is also being proposed for compressed natural gas. This is consistent with the Government's energy policy. Natural gas supplied through a reticulation system is already exempt. The net result of the changes will be an increase in revenue estimated at $142m in a full year and $107m in 1981-82.

It is customary for sales tax changes to come into operation on the day following the introduction of the amending Bill and the Bill therefore provides that the amendments are to be effective from 19 August, 1981, the day following introduction of the Bill. I commend this Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.
