SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Earlier today the Remuneration Tribunal's 1981 Review was tabled in the Senate. The Government has accepted the Tribunal's report on judges' remuneration and the following determinations: allowances for members, Ministers and office-holders of the Parliament, and remuneration payable to holders of offices in the first division of the Australian Public Service and holders of public offices. The Government accepts the merit in the Tribunal's decisions with regard to the increases in salaries for Ministers, members and office-holders in Parliament.

The decisions recognised the real decline in Parliamentary salaries that have already occurred in comparison with the wages earned by the average Australian. It is important to note that between March 1975 and December 1980 average weekly earnings rose by 84 per cent while the salaries of members of the federal parliament rose by 50 per cent. It should be remembered that members of parliament did not automatically receive the cost of living increases which flowed to most wage and salary earners as a result of national wage case decisions. It is also significant to look at the restraint that has already been exercised by the Government on its own ministerial salaries in the interests of setting a national example.

Salary increases recommended for Ministers by an independent inquiry in 1971 were not implemented until 1973. Increases recommended by the Remuneration Tribunal in 1974 were not implemented. Increases in ministerial salaries recommended in 1975, 1978 and 1979 were not implemented. In 1978 the Tribunal recommended that Ministers' salaries be increased by 4.9 per cent in line with national wage increases over the previous twelve months, but the Government did not accept this recommendation and no increases were given. In 1979 the Tribunal recommended increases of 9.1 per cent but the Government approved a rise of 7.3 per cent.

Mr President, the Government believes that the inflationary threats posed by excessive wage increases are so serious that an example of restraint must once again be set. Thus, as a lead to the rest of the community the Government has decided that the salary rise recommended by the Remuneration Tribunal for all senators, members, parliamentary office-holders and Ministers will not be taken at once, but spread over two years. I express the hope that the community will take full note of this example being set by the Government and the Parliament.

The Remuneration and Allowances Amendment Bill gives effect to these views where action is required to implement or modify the Tribunal's decisions. Part II provides that members and office-holders of the Parliament will receive in 1981-82 salary or additional salary increases amounting to half those determined by the Tribunal. The rates which appear in the Bill reflect the total amounts which will be received in 1981-82. Part III deals with the salaries of Ministers and provides for the sum appropriated under the Ministers of State Act to be increased to provide for half the increases in the Tribunal's report. The Tribunal's report on the remuneration of judges is implemented by Part IV of the Act. Finally, Part V provides that the power of disallowance in the Remuneration Tribunals Act will not apply to the Tribunal's 1981 determinations, including those proposed to be modified by this Bill. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The explanation for this Bill is set out in the second reading speech which has just been incorporated in Hansard. It is now late on Thursday night, and I suppose I have lost my courage for the fight. The Opposition does not oppose the Bill. I want to make two or three observations about it. Of course it has been the cause of tremendous Press speculation and so on. There are one or two facts I think which should be remembered. The salary rises were fixed by an independent tribunal and then reduced by political decision because of political pressure. When politicians voted for their own wage rises, the community called for an independent tribunal. When politicians' salaries were fixed by an independent tribunal, the decision of that tribunal was likewise condemned and political pressures were applied to government in relation to them.

SPEECH.PARA: As the second reading speech points out, the salaries of politicians in relation to community movements have fallen behind over a considerable period, some five years, and in a sense it can be argued on behalf of some politicians at least that their salaries compare unfavourably with those of people with similar skills or responsibilities in the corporate sector of the community. That of itself, I suppose, is not necessarily a persuasive argument in relation to all salaries, but it is an important matter to consider in the overall context. As I have said, this matter has received a great deal of speculation and so on in the Press, much of it ill-informed. For the reasons I have stated the Opposition does not oppose the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting this Bill I would like to draw attention to what I consider to be an anomaly which is increasingly affecting allowances, particularly as they relate to the chairmanship of the Senate Committees. I am sure that those members who are looking at the Bill will notice that the chairmen of the joint committees receive an allowance far in excess of the allowance received by the chairmen of Senate standing committees. I think that that is an anomaly that this chamber should look at in the future and should not allow to go unnoticed. As far as I am concerned it is a slight on this Senate. It is a slight on our standing committees, the committees of the Senate which have been built up over a period. As I move around the community I note that those who are interested in the parliamentary system pay a lot of attention to those committees. In the schedule of allowances on page 2 of the Bill there is a vast difference between the allowances paid to the chairman of joint committees and those paid to the chairman of the standing committees of the Senate. I think it is an insult of the greatest order and something that should not go unnoticed for any length of time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats made their position in relation to this Bill clear when the report of the Remuneration Tribunal originally came forward. Unfortunately that was in an era when indexation was still operating but made it clear that we would have preferred that parliamentarians' salaries should rise by the same amount that the salaries of all other Australians rise, and that those rises be dictated in the normal course of events by tribunals other than the specialist tribunal for the salaries and allowances of parliamentarians. However, since that date the indexation package which was available to all other workers within the community has been abolished. So it is no longer possible to argue along those lines. However, the Democrats accept that the rise set down for this year is an acceptable rise in terms of the percentages granted to other workers within the community over the last 12 months.
—It is somewhat less.

—Yes, it is less. Therefore it is a reasonable amount, and we believe it will be seen by people in the community as a reasonable amount since it is the same percentage as they received through decisions of other tribunals. We do not agree with the decision to pay the other half next year and to include such a provision in this Bill. We believe that parliamentarians should be subjected to the rigours to which everybody else in the community obviously will be subjected. The percentage should be worked out in 12 months' time, and it should be the average of the amount other workers in the community receive. We believe that every person is worthy of his hire, including parliamentarians, but that parliamentarians should receive no more or less than other people in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to allowances we believe that the full rise in the allowance is justified. Indeed, the allowances and provisions made to parliamentarians are inadequate on a range of issues. Certainly, the ability to be able to perform one's duties depends very much on one's research staff and one's capacities in various offices, both here and in the electorate. The primitive nature of some of those types of provisions obviously dates them back to the last century. It is not possible in this day and age to make comprehensive evaluations of complex matters unless these issues are updated. Therefore, we support the inclusion of the total allowance package.

We disagree with Part IV of the Bill, under which judges will receive the full rise granted in the original Remuneration Tribunal 1981 review. We believe that the link between parliamentarians and judges ought to have been maintained and that judges also ought to receive only half the rise. Their rise ought also to be linked to the rises of other workers in the community, as this Bill links parliamentarians' rises with those of other workers. We do not agree that judges should receive the full rise and parliamentarians half the rise. We believe that both ought to receive only half the rise. Lastly, I refer to Part V, which contains the miscellaneous provisions. It seems gratuitous in many ways that this Bill does not allow for disallowance of sections of the Remuneration Tribunal's determinations made on 18 June. With those qualifications, we support the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief in following up the point raised by Senator Collard about the disparity between payments made to chairmen of joint committees and chairmen of other committees of the Senate. I do not think any joint committee can claim to be more important than a Senate standing committee, and I fully endorse the views of Senator Collard on this matter. The other point that concerns me is the way the Whips in the House of Representatives are paid more than the Whips in the Senate. Mr Acting Deputy President, as an ex-Whip you would know that the difficulties of a Whip are far greater in an adult community such as the Senate than they are in a place such as the House of Representatives. They are very difficult.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, is that the truth?

—It is the truth. The Whips in the House of Representatives have a far greater party discipline behind them and much easier job to do than any Whip has in the Senate. I am a very charitable person, but I feel for the Whips in this place. They perform a very difficult job and they are entitled to every bit as much in the way of an allowance as a Whip in the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to throw a little-
—Levity?

—Levity, thank you. I would like to throw a little levity into the consideration of this matter. I refer to a comment Lord Glenamara made in giving evidence to the House of Commons Select Committee on Procedure in relation to the Parliament and the future of Parliament. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The balance of advantage between the Parliament and Government in the day to day working of the Constitution is now weighted in favour of the Government to a degree which arouses widespread anxiety and is inimical to the proper working of our parliamentary democracy.
I just wonder whether some of the changes being made by the implementation of the recommendations of yet another qango, or quasi-autonomous national government organisation, are not-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not Parliament you are referring to, is it?

—No, the qango is the Remuneration Tribunal. It makes the determinations which Parliament decides it will review through the Executive from time to time taking control of what happens. One wonders about the extent to which the fact that a compromise was able to be developed was a result of the extreme advantage of the Executive achieving increases which were vastly disproportionate to those of the majority of the division fodder of this Parliament. I wonder for how long the cannon or division fodder of this Parliament will look to the increasing disparities without question. I wonder for how long the Remuneration Tribunal can continue the farce of the consultation that takes place between the Minister of the day and the members of that Tribunal, which I am told has taken place repeatedly in the past before the determination is made. I wonder for how long we will continue to put up with the situation which was so eloquently described by Lord Glenamara. I wonder whether the points made by Senator Collard and Senator MacGibbon, and I have no doubt they could be made by others, about the increasing disparities between the power and influence and patronage that exist in the Executive, in comparison with the position of the Parliament will be tolerated by this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I give notice that I believe a notice of motion on the Notice Paper referring to one of the aspects we can consider-the relativity between chairmen of committees and junior Ministers-should be brought on soon. The view of this chamber could then be determined on whether we will increasingly say that there are the gods up there who are part of the Executive and the division fodder down there who are just part of the Parliament, and it does not really matter. I refrain from taking up more time. The subject having been opened up, I could not resist the opportunity to express a few views which will be developed at much greater length as soon as the motion standing in the names of Senator Hamer and Senator Rae is brought on for debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-It is with some trepidation that I rise to speak. My friend, Senator Peter Rae, and I normally sit together. I advise honourable senators that I have not come to this end of the Senate chamber to avoid my colleague who has referred to me as a member of the Executive, but simply because this is the place where the Minister who keeps the House has to move in order to take his role in responding to debate on Bills. —I am sorry. Senator Peter Rae has made his point. No one has denied that percentages worked from different bases provide different amounts. But the honourable senator may care to note that some disparities are corrected in this Schedule. This does not apply just to Executive members. I draw to the honourable senator's attention that the Leader of the Opposition has some long-standing disparities in relativities corrected; that the Presiding Officers and a whole range of office bearers have some relativities brought up to date and corrected on the basis of what the Tribunal thought was fair.

SPEECH.PARA: I can check the point Senator Colston made. Clearly the Government has no intention to ask one group and not the other to take half of a salary rise. TALK.START.PARA: —One of the matters I wish to refer to is retrospectivity. Can the Minister tell me why the Government considered it was necessary to engage in retrospective legislation on this issue? I am indebted to Senator Peter Rae and Senator Colston for referring to Part III of the report of the Remuneration Tribunals, which deals with salaries payable to Ministers of State. The report contains a list which is similar to the list which appears on page 2 of the printed Bill. The list contains the following items: Prime Minister, $39,600; Deputy Prime Minister, $27,000; Treasurer and Deputy Leader of the Government, majority party, $21,600; Minister in the Cabinet, $20,700; Minister not in the Cabinet, $16,200. Could the Minister give me the new salary rates, which presumably he has, for those office bearers?

—I can seek to obtain those figures for the honourable senator. Again, I have no particular worries about this. I can do it later if the honourable senator wishes us to carry the Bill over. I can have it for the Committee when we resume the week after next. It is of no concern to me. I can get the information for the honourable senator either now or later. It is a matter of public record.

—Senator Macklin asked another question which I thought was of some significance. If Senator Peter Baume will permit me may I give him a break for a moment and refer to that question. It was about retrospectivity. As I understand it, the legitimisation of retrospectivity is that under the legislation establishing the Remuneration Tribunal there are dates from which determinations made by the Remuneration Tribunal take effect. The Remuneration Tribunal made a determination which took effect from 1 July. That being so, the legal determination was part of the law of this country from 1 July. The interference, the readjustment or what have you that is being made tonight is not an increase retrospectively but a decrease. So that the adjustments being made tonight will take effect from the time of the commencement of the determination. Therefore, if anybody is to suffer it is those who will be the subject of downward adjustments. It is not a case of retrospectivity imposing a penalty either on the Consolidated Revenue or on anybody but the recipients of the benefits or otherwise of the determination that was made. In those circumstances it is not offensive retrospectivity but rather the opposite. It is imposing a penalty on the recipient and not on anybody else and backdating it.
—I am concerned about what is to happen with Ministers' salaries. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) said to me that he may be able to get the information.
—I have some here.

—I really want some firm indication about what is to happen to Ministers' salaries before I see this legislation go through. As the Minister may have some information I will yield and see what he can provide.

—The Ministers of State Act determines cartain matters in relation to salaries payable to Ministers. What the Committee is being asked to agree to in clause 6 of this legislation is that the pool from which Ministers may be paid be increased to a certain amount of money. The rate at which they are paid will be determined by an amount set down by the Tribunal and as adjusted and determined by the Executive. That is, we are not going to take the full amount determined by the Tribunal. But we have to have the pool to pay Ministers any kind of increase at all.

—I can understand the argument about the pool. But I cannot accept the fact that members and senators are expected to pass a Bill relating to their own salaries without knowing what is to happen to the salaries of Ministers. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its courtesy. I regard what happened tonight as a rather extraordinary thing indeed. I have seen the Bill for only a few minutes. I heard Senator Rae speaking and I had the impression that he was speaking on a Bill in connection with the remuneration of members of parliament. I have taken part in discussions on this matter constantly but I had no knowledge that the Bill had been introduced in the Senate. I looked at the Notice Paper today. I was assured that tonight General Business would be taking precedence of Government Business. There was no reference of course on the Notice Paper to the fact that the Bill was to be brought forward. Nor did I have any knowledge that it had passed the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to say a number of things about the Remuneration and Allowances Amendment Bill 1981. I support the Bill. I am prepared to vote for the Bill. I am very sorry to see that the Bill overturns some of the decisions made this year by the Remuneration Tribunal. For years I have supported the fact that we have a tribunal which is supposed to take out of politics the question of the remuneration of members of parliament. Unfortunately, nearly every time the Tribunal makes a decision there is some interference on the part of government which determines-sometimes it then changes its mind-that it will alter the decision made by an independent tribunal. It is high time we respected the umpire's decision and decided that these matters be taken out of the realm of politics. Of course, in the last few days a very considerable objection has been raised by the overwhelming number of members of government parties to what has taken place.

Under the provisions of this Bill members of parliament this year will take a $3,000, more or less, reduction in the amounts which the Tribunal determined. After very close consideration and after massive submissions were made to it, the Tribunal established the considerable need and entitlement of members to increases in salaries. That view was expressed in the submissions made by the party committee of which I am a member and which put substantial facts before the Tribunal. It can be seen from the Tribunal's judgment that those submissions were generally accepted. It was not as though the decision of the Tribunal was a generous one; I think it was a moderate one. It is not as though I find myself in complete agreement with everything the Tribunal did. Amongst other things-I think this was referred to by Senator Rae this evening-the chairman of the party committee made representations to the Tribunal. Senator Rae and I appeared before the Tribunal and argued our case. In fact, the Tribunal decision made no reference whatsoever to those submissions. I think that is an extraordinary omission. I do not know to what extent Senator Rae has spoken on this subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not do more than quote Lord Glenamara out of that submission.

—I see. As far as that is concerned, we are not all that happy with that part of the Tribunal's decisions which is concerned with the requirements of the Senate office holders and the Chairman of Committees. Nonetheless, as far as I am concerned that was the decision of the Tribunal. I think it should have stood. I think it would have stood and I think the initial decision of the Government would have been upheld but for some members of parliament who sought to climb on a bandwaggon of indignation created by the Press. It is interesting to indicate that the Press, which told the community how terrible it is that there should be increases in parliamentarian's salaries, did not take into account their own salary increases. One can make a comparison between what has happened to parliamentary salaries and the salaries of Press people. Over the last seven years I think Press salaries have increased by 109 per cent, but parliamentary salaries have gone up by 50 per cent. If one looks at the profits of newspapers one finds that in the period from 1974-1980 their profits have ranged from 142 per cent for Advertiser Newspapers Ltd, 274 per cent for Consolidated Press Holdings Ltd and 355 per cent for the News Corporation Ltd. These are enormous increases in the profits made by newspapers. Yet they have the audacity to tell members of parliament that it is all right that they receive only a 50 per cent increase on their salaries. If I had been in the country when that controversy was going on-unfortunately, I was spending my money elsewhere trying to acquire information to come back here to serve the people-I certainly would have had a lot to say about the way the Press handled the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important that the community should know the facts so far as comparative salaries are concerned. As an indication of comparative salary rises I desire to incorporate in Hansard two documents prepared by the Parliamentary Library. One of the documents is entitled 'Indicators of Newspaper Company Profits, 1974-1980' and the other is entitled 'Movements in Salaries for Selected Occupations June 1974 and March 1981'. It is indicated, for example that a professor's salary had gone up on the average by 104 per cent. A senior tutor's salary has increased by 109 per cent. Of course no other groups on the list compares with parliamentarians as regards the level of salary increases. Medical fees have increased in that period by 138 per cent. Similarly, pensions and benefits have gone up by 146 per cent. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the documents I have referred to so that these facts will be known to people.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a result of the representations that were made and the evidence that was heard the Tribunal came to certain conclusions. Although we may accept the decision which has now been made and which I presume is contained in the Bill-I saw the Bill only a few minutes ago so I have not had time to read it-one can conclude that there are dangers when we appoint a tribunal and ask it to determine the salaries of members of parliament and then overturn its decision. One wonders how long a tribunal will put up with that sort of treatment of its efforts. So far as this matter is concerned, I believe members of parliament have been much too meek and quiescent in accepting the constant abuse and blame which they have received. Tonight I intend to announce the commencement of a campaign for shorter hours for members of parliament. I think we should aim for a 65-hour week. In my opinion most members of parliament work much longer hours than that. For many jobs we are talking fashionably now of a 35-hour week but this Parliament sits for a crazy 65-hour week.
—We could change that next week.
—Senator Sibraa, as we all know, next week we will be back in our constituencies working hard.
—The next sitting week.

—Yes, it will be a good idea if we change the working hours. The illnesses which have fallen upon parliamentarians, even this week, ought to make us think about why people are not seeking to enter parliament and why people are frightened off contesting the pre-selection ballots in the various parts of the country. I say that we ought not to be quite so silent about the criticisms which are made of parliamentarians.

SPEECH.PARA: We now have before us a Bill in which the only change effected to the determination is the reduction by $3,000 of the remuneration to be paid to members. The purpose is said to be to encourage the community to exercise restraint. I do not think that it will have that effect. It never has had. Whenever we have refused any increase it has had no effect on the community whatsoever. The reduction is not being applied to judges or to public servants. There are now some 1,500 Commonwealth public servants earning more than are the members of this Parliament. They treat those members with a fair amount of contempt because money is what matters to quite a lot of the members of the Public Service. If the original proposal had been followed through, I understand that there would have been only 700 members of the Public Service earning more than do members of parliament. They are, of course, untouched by the gesture that we are now making.

Finally, insofar as we accept this reduction as members of the Parliament, and get the Government off the hook, having in mind the awkward situation that it is in, we recognise that next year the Tribunal will meet again in the normal course and that submissions will be made to it. We expect that by then the full 20 per cent increase, as of right, will have come to members of parliament and may expect that the Tribunal will take into account the changes in inflation levels which will occur in the interim. So next year there will also be a fairly large increase in members' salaries. If the Press again attacks us on the basis of what we are doing, I can assure honourable senators that I will be in the forefront of defending what members of parliament are doing.

I believe that my colleagues in this place and in the other place, on both sides, are doing a fine and excellent job. They are working under terrible conditions and do so because they are interested in their work and are concerned to be in the Parliament. They are not in it to make money, and they do not. Although I will vote for the Bill, I say that it is a pity that it comes about in this way and I am sure that next year we will be hoping that justice will be done the members of the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In closing the third reading debate I wish to respond briefly to the remarks of Senator Colston. There is a very simple explanation. Section 7 of the Remuneration Tribunal Act, which refers to senators and members, provides that the Remuneration Tribunal 'shall, from time to time . . . inquire into, and determine . . .' certain matters. It makes determinations in relation to senators and members. Ministers are in a different situation. Section 66 of the Constitution sets out their position. Section 6 of the Remuneration Tribunal Act provides that 'The Tribunal shall, from time to time . . . inquire into, and report . . .' upon the salaries of Ministers. The Tribunal does not have the power to make a determination in regard to Ministers' salaries.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1 July Ministers have been receiving only half of the increases recommended by the Tribunal. As the determination of the Tribunal did not automatically apply it was decided that Ministers should take only half of the increases recommended. The provision of $452,000 made in the Bill is sufficient to pay only half of the increases proposed for Ministers. I believe that is the assurance that the honourable senator sought.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.

Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-

These Bills propose to amend the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Act and the Television Stations Licence Fees Act 1964 to vary the basis on which commercial broadcasting and television stations are charged for their use of a limited public resource. Honourable senators will be aware that those Acts impose fees in the nature of a royalty charge, thus following the practice common to all governments of ensuring that the public gains some benefit from the commercial utilisation of public resources. The present Acts provide for a lump sum payment on the original grant of a licence and for a lump sum and a percentage of the gross earnings of the station in respect of each year after the grant.

The Bills propose an increased fee of $500 on the grant of a licence and tying the annual fee simply to a revised percentage of gross earning. That percentage varies in relation to increases in gross earnings. Royalties on resource use are based on the value of the resource used, rather than on the ability of the management of a particular user to make a profit from the utilisation of that resource. Accordingly honourable senators will know the charges are based on the gross earnings representing commercial value of licence use. There is of course a correlation, given competent management, between profitability and gross earnings. Those stations with higher gross earnings based as they are on the use of the public resource in general do enjoy higher profitability. It is equitable then that these stations should contribute a higher percentage of those earnings than much smaller stations.

This has been the practice in the past and continues with the present proposal. In fact, stations with gross earnings of less than about $2 1/2m will pay lower fees than under the current provisions. This will benefit approximately 120 of 130 commercial broadcasting stations and 20 of 50 commercial television stations. The Government hopes that this will enable stations benefiting by these changes to improve programming and services to the public. It does not believe that these aspects will sufer in the bigger stations. Advertising revenue is the life blood of commercial broadcasting and television. It is directly related to the audience share of a particular station and obviously this relates to the programming appeal of the station to the general public. No station can, therefore, afford to lower its programming standards.

The details of the proposed rates are clearly shown in the Bills. The changes will take effect on 1 September 1981. As the Treasurer (Mr Howard) announced in the other place on 18 September 1981, the new structure of fees for commercial radio and television station licences will raise revenue from this source to an estimated $31.5m in 1981-82. I commend the Bills to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I stress again that I took the trouble of giving Senator Chaney 12 hours notice to liaise with Mr Viner, the Minister for Industrial Relations. It is typical of Mr Viner. TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter in relation to the Department of Defence, where I believe a gross assault on personal liberties is taking place. I say personal liberties because I do not know that one can talk about civil liberties in a defence setting. Normally, this would be a matter of civil liberties. I was astounded earlier this year when I was contacted by a member of the Army who told me that she was in a de facto relationship with another member of the Army and that the relationship had been recognised for almost three years by the service, but due to new regulations this couple is likely to lose that recognition. After being contacted by the member, I made inquiries and I found that the circumstances arose because of a determination made by the Minister for Defence, the Hon. D. J. Killen, known as Determination No. 1 of 1981. The citation for the Determination reads:

SPEECH.PARA: This Determination may be cited as Determination 0114, Married Trainee's Allowance.

The Determination raises a number of matters, many of which, frankly, I find difficult to understand. One of the consequences seems to be that this young lady and her partner will lose a right which previously was guaranteed to them, namely, recognition of their de facto relationship. A Department of Defence memorandum issued on 7 April takes 10 pages to explain the Determination. On pages 4 and 5 the memorandum notes in part:
Recognition of a de facto relationship will not be considered where any of the following conditions apply:
A. Where both partners to the application are unmarried and there are no children in the care of the member or de facto spouse.
It seems that this will prevent continuation of the recognition of my constituent's de facto relationship. Part of a statement which this servicewoman gave to me states:

6. X and I met late in 1975, and began seeing each other regularly from early 1976. In the August of 1977, we were both posted to Queensland and began living together on a permanent and bona-fide domestic basis. Twelve months later, we applied for Service Recognition of our Defacto Relationship, which was granted on the 28th August, 1978.

7. Our domestic situation has not changed, and our Original Statutory Declarations are still valid, and yet, over four (4) years later, we are now confronted with the fact that if we do not conform with the Policy laid out by some moral expert or 'Heavenly Body' in Canberra, we will no longer be recognised as a Service Couple. The most drastic consequence of this new situation is that both being re-categorized 'O', we are not eligible to be re-posted together.

This seems incredible. The couple have been living together for four years, the relationship had been accepted by the Army for three years, and now they face derecognition. I wrote to the Minister for Defence about this matter, and in part he replied:
I refer again to your personal representations on behalf of a servicewoman, concerning Service recognition of de facto relationships.
It is true that new criteria for recognition of de facto relationships by the Services were brought into effect from 13 January, 1981.

The new criteria are more stringent and this was seen as necessary to correct an unacceptable situation which previously allowed some young Service people the financial benefits of married status, where in some instances, no genuine or potentially lasting relationship had been formed.

Following a transitional period of twelve months, all de facto relationships which were recognised before 13 January, 1981 are to be reviewed on 13 January, 1982, to determine whether recognition may be continued.
I would like to re-state part of that reply. It reads:

The new criteria are more stringent and this was seen as necessary to correct an unacceptable situation which previously allowed some young Service people the financial benefits of married status, where in some instances, no genuine or potentially lasting relationship had been formed.

Perhaps I should leave aside the question of who determines whether a genuine or potentially lasting relationship has been formed. Is it the moral expert or the heavenly body to whom my constituent refers? Even if I leave that aside, surely a relationship which has continued since 1977 should be accepted as a lasting one. Why now take away from two members of the Service who have a genuine relationship the recognition previously given? I suggest to the Minister that he have this matter re-examined and bring forth a regulation which allows previously recognised de facto relationships to retain such recognition. In making this suggestion to the Minister let me quote one further telling point made by my constituent. She said:
The Service seems to lose all reality at times, and continually forgets that the little 'cogs' in the great wheel are in fact individual people with individual beliefs, goals, and standards.

I believe we should regain some reality and recognise those individual beliefs, goals and standards of Service members. I look forward to an early comment from the Minister on my suggestion that he have the matter re-examined and bring forth a regulation which allows the recognition which this couple had to continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had two contributions to the adjournment debate tonight. I have noted the comments by Senator Mulvihill and will look forward to reading the document which he incorporated in Hansard.
—Senator Chaney had a copy this morning.

—Yes, but I think we now have to make sure that the material is passed on to Mr Viner, that Senator Mulvihill's views are made known, that his comments about Commissioner Walker are passed on and that we make an attempt to get some further information back to Senator Mulvihill.

SPEECH.PARA: In the same way, the matter which was raised by Senator Colston is a sensitive and difficult matter which he quite properly raised tonight. I note that it concerns Service recognition of de facto relationships. If I listened carefully, he referred to a particular relationship which dates from 1977 and which has been placed in jeopardy by some altered regulations. I suggest to the honourable senator that we pass on the Hansard report, when it appears, to the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) into whose area it falls and that we seek for Senator Colston a re-examination of the kind he has requested. I believe he is seeking an appropriate altered regulation. We can put that proposition to the Minister and we can try to make known to the honourable senator any determination that comes from the Minister as soon as it is available to us.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.58 p.m. until Tuesday, 8 September, at 3 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Government require the Australian Optometrical Association to conduct a survey with regard to members' costs to assist in fixing the optometrical fee; if so, did the Government ignore the findings of this survey and allow an increase considerably less than the suggested fee.
(2) What was the cost of conducting the survey and who paid for it.
(3) Has the Government been requested to allow increased fees for consultations by optometrists for those suffering visionary relation problems, amblyopia, strabismus and low vision.
(4) Did the Government refuse such a request; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Government required the Australian Optometrical Association to conduct such a survey before it would consider an adjustment in optometrical consultation fees in 1980.

The Government did not ignore the findings of the survey, in fact it used the information from the survey to develop an index of optometrical consulting practice costs and incomes. This index formed the basis of the increase of 9.6 per cent in fees that came into effect from 1 January 1981, twelve months after the previous increase.

The Government did, however, disagree with the Australian Optometrical Association about the way in which the Association had used the data from its survey in presenting its submission for a fee increase in excess of 30 per cent over a twelve month period.
(2) The cost of the survey was borne by the Australian Optometrical Association, and, as advised by the Association, the direct cost was approximately $30,000.

(3) Yes. The Optometric Extension Program, Australia, has made representations regarding time-tiered items, for optometrical consultations for conditions such as visually related learning problems, amblyopia, strabismus and low vision. The Australian Optometrical Association has also recommended the introduction of brief and extended consultation items.

(4) No. I met with representatives of the Australian Optometrical Association on 17 February 1981. I expressed some concern about increasing the number of items because this could lead to abuse. The Association advised that it would write further to me regarding this matter, however, to date no such submission has been received.

It has been suggested to the Optometric Extension Program, Australia, that they liaise with the Australian Optometrical Association to ensure that the Association's submission represents as fully as possible the views of the optometrical profession.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many projects currently funded through the Schools Commission Innovations Program will cease to be funded in the context of the new education guidelines.
(2) Which of these projects are related to:
(a) basic literacy and numeracy;
(b) education for handicapped children;
(c) school to work transition; and
(d) education for Aboriginal children.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Nil. All projects currently operating will continue until the end of the approved period for the project. All projects that have been approved for funding will proceed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the 1980 Index of Disadvantage, in relation to the Disadvantaged Schools Program, assume that if a non-government school is located in a disadvantaged district it should be regarded as disadvantaged for the purposes of aggregating numbers in non-government schools; if so, how does this take account of the selective nature on non-government schools which may draw their enrolments selectively from that district and other districts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Index of Disadvantage was recommended by the Commonwealth Schools Commission as the basis for distributing funds between States and between the government and non-government school sectors for the Disadvantaged Schools Program. The Government has accepted this recommendation. The Index itself did not classify individual government or non-government schools as being disadvantaged. It provided a measure of disadvantage, in terms of socio-economic criteria, for each collectors' district in Australia-the collectors' district being the smallest area of collection used by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in its national censuses. Student enrolments in both school sectors in the most disadvantaged collectors' districts, the lowest 16 per cent, were then used as the basis for the Commission's recommendation for determining the block funds to be made available to the government and non-government school sectors within each State.

Once these block grants have been established, State and non-government school authorities at the local State level, determine the individual schools that will participate in the Program. In the case of Catholic systemic non-government schools, representative committees in each State, the Catholic Disadvantaged School committees, establish their own criteria for selecting schools.

Individual non-systemic non-government schools are invited to apply for inclusion in the program where they feel they are eligible. The Commonwealth Schools Commission through its State Planning and Finance Committees assesses these applications in terms of socio-economic information provided by schools.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 11 June 1981:

ANSWER.PARA: The estimated full year costs would be of the following order:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 12 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will passage of the Plant Varieties Rights legislation give Australian plant breeders and seed merchants complete reciprocity with all overseas countries, for all plants. If not, what countries will not grant reciprocity, and for what species.
(2) Is there a guarantee in the legislation that varieties developed using public moneys will be held under a Public Use Right.
(3) Would a new native plant, for example a newly discovered species of orchid, found growing in the wild be covered by this legislation. If so, to whom is the right granted.
(4) What is the public interest referred to by the Minister for Primary industry in his second reading speech.
(5) (a) How will the Australian agricultural Council determine which species are to be registered;
(b) will an ordinary home gardner have the right to present a case to the Australian Agricultural Council (AAC) in his own right;
(c) are there to be any review procedures of AAC recommendations, or is this what was referred to as appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, for the protection of the public interest.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The granting of rights in one country does not mean that they are automatically granted in another country for the same variety.

(3) If a species has been declared by Regulation as covered by the legislation, then applications from breeders of plants of that species would be considered. The applicant would need to do more than merely discover a new variety. The growing and selection of a 'newly discovered variety' over time, to ensure that it was uniform (ie all plants of a generation showed similar characteristics) and stable (ie plants of successive generations remained true to the original description) could, however, be sufficient to overcome this limitation.
(4) Under normal circumstances the provision of reasonable quantities of the variety at reasonable prices.
(5) (a) This is a matter for the Australian Agricultural Council (AAC);
(b) any member of the public can present a case to his respective State member of AAC;
(c) No.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 12 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) Why is Plant Variety Rights Bill 1981 (PVR) restricted to horticultural, ornamental and other selected pasture and fodder species; and
(b) why have the major field crops and annual pasture species been excluded from the Bill.
(2) (a) What is the definition of 'horticultural' and 'ornamental' for the purposes of clause 10 (1) of the Bill;
(b) what are the other selected pasture and fodder species referred to in the Minister's second reading speech;
(c) what are the major field crops and annual pasture species which have been excluded; and
(d) are trees for forestry purposes covered by the legislation and, if so, under what heading.
(3) What are the major similarities and differences between the PVR Bill and legislation in the United States of America, United Kingdom and New Zealand;
(4) (a) What is the estimated cost of PVR in its first year of operation;
(b) how much of this cost will be recouped, according to departmental estimates;
(c) what fees are to be charged; and

(d) what is the cost of registering a plant in the United States of America, United Kingdom, New Zealand, Japan, Germany, France and South Africa, giving that cost in both the relevant currency and its Australian equivalent.
(5) (a) What is the time period for which a patent is issued in Australia; and
(b) is this different to the time of 20 years proposed in the Bill and, if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) and (b) Restrictions on the scope of the PVR Scheme followed a decision of the Australian Agricultural Council (AAC) at its February 1981 meeting. Discussions within AAC are confidential.

(2) (a), (b), (c) and (d) Plant groups are not strictly defined as each species will be considered independently by the AAC and as long as plants fall into the broad categories of ornamental, horticultural or pasture or fodder plants and are not major field crops or annual pasture plants then they could be included in the Scheme by ACC.
(3) Plant Variety Rights legislation in the United States of America, United Kingdom and New Zealand are similar to the Bill as tabled on 7 May 1981.

The United States of America has two complementary sets of legislation, one for asexually propagated plants and the other for sexually propagated plants. The United Kingdom and New Zealand include both groups of plants in their legislation, as it is proposed for Australia.
The Australian legislation differs from these other countries' legislation by way of the restriction of species included and the requirement that the AAC consent to the declaration of each species.
(4) (a) For the first year of operation of the Scheme the cost is estimated at $50,000.
(b) Nil.
(c) Not set at this time.

(d) The attached tables provide information on the registration fees charged in Japan, the United States, the United Kingdom, New Zealand and South Africa. Similar information for West Germany and France is being sought.
(5) (a) Patents in Australia are issued for 16 years with provision for extension for a further 5 year or ten year period in exceptional circumstances.

(b) Yes. The general trend throughout the world has been to move to a 20 year period of protection of patents with no provision for extension. This stance has been adopted by the European Patent Convention. The United Kingdom and South Africa have adopted this term of protection.
REGISTRATION FEES CHARGED BY VARIOUS OVERSEAS COUNTRIES
Japan-The Seeds and Seedlings Law 1978. Registration Fee=30,000 Yn ($A114.36)
United States-Plant Variety Protection Act 1970. Registration Fee=$US750 (A656.11)
United Kingdom-Plant Breeders Rights Act. Fees vary according to species from #1,040 ($A1,728) for cereals and potatoes to #170 ($A282) for fruit trees and some decorative species.
South Africa-Plant Breeders Rights Act 1976. Fees vary according to species from 300 Rand ($A288) for citrus trees to 120 Rand ($A115) for most garden vegetables.
New Zealand-Plant Varieties Act 1973. Fees vary according to species from $NZ800 ($A582) for herbage, agricultural crops and vegetables to $NZ300 ($A218) for fruits, ornamentals and forest trees.
Conversion rate as at 16.7.81.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 12 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Into what grouping under the proposal Plant Variety Rights Legislation do the following plants fall:

(a) wheat; (b) sugar cane; (c) sorghum; (d) rice; (e)jojoba; (f) Pinus radiata; (g) Pinus patula; (h) eucalyptus stricta; (i) ucalyptus marginata; (j) Manihot esculenta; (k) Asclepias spp,; (l) kelp; and (m) Sacchromyces spp.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Agricultural Council (AAC) decision, which the legislation attempts to reflect, was taken to establish guidelines concerning the scope of the scheme; no individual plant species have been identified by AAC as belonging to particular groups.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 April 1981 (Hansard page 1543) Senator Tate asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence:

ANSWER.PARA: My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, concerns the callous refusal of the Government to permit sailors who served on HMAS Sydney and its destroyer escorts during the Vietnam war to share in the benefits of our repatriation system. Is it a fact that the coastal waters off Vietnam through which those vessels moved was declared a war zone? Is it a fact that the port in which the vessels were anchored was defoliated in order to clear the area of Vietcong snipers? Is it a fact that on occasions when they were at anchor the sailors were closed up because of the dangers of their situation? Is it a fact that diving teams were constantly sent down to ensure that the hull and anchor cables were not in jeopardy because of mines? Why does the Government, led by a Prime Minister who was a Minister for Defence during that Vietnam war, continue callously to refuse to recognize the fact that these sailors were, indeed, exposed to danger and ought to receive the benefits of our repatriation system?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The coastal waters off Vietman were declared a special area under the Repatriation (Special Areas) Regulations. My Department is unaware of any defoliation operations being conducted in the Port of Vung Tau during the Vietnam war. It is confirmed that the armament an sensor systems of the ships were manned while transiting and at anchor within the special area. Precautions were taken against enemy swimmers by having the ships divers work in a two watch system so that one diving party cruised around the ship continuously, carrying out searchers of the hull and anchor cable as required.

The crew of HMAS Sydney and escorts were not allotted for special duty under the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962-67. The reason why HMAS Sydney and escorts were not allotted was because their voyages to Vietnam were of a transitory nature only. They did not remain thre for operational duty. Although the crews of HMAS Sydney and escorts were not normally allotted for special duty, they did not have a latent protection under the Repatriation Act for any possible occurrence from enemy action during the period of their journey.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 May 1981 (Hansard, page 1565), Senator Grimes asked me, as Minister for Social Security, the following question without notice concerning the new rules for people seeking disadvantaged status under the new health arrangements:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) How will these people claim for previously paid hospital and medical bills, as was stated in the Minister's answer to Senator Button's question last Thursday?
(2) How can they ensure that the doctor they see will participate in the disadvantaged scheme?
(3) Does the Government expect that in levying in-patient and out-patient charges the States will levy charges in hospital pharmacies?
(4) If so, will this remove an option for free pharmaceuticals which are at present available to the disadvantaged patient?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:
(1) See Hansard (5 May 1981, page 1565).

(2) I have been advised by my colleague, the Minister for Health, that the Commonwealth lacks any power to compel medical practitioners to participate in arrangements such as the disadvantaged persons scheme. However, the medical profession has a long tradition of providing care to needy patients at concessional charges. By and large the profession has co-operated in the present disadvantaged persons scheme, whereby under the bulk billing system the Commonwealth pays benefits to the doctor of 75 per cent of the Schedule fee. Under the new bulk billing arrangements the inducement to the doctor to treat the patient at disadvantaged rates will be greater because the benefit will be 85 per cent of the Schedule fee (and this will be the full charge to the patient). Moreover, doctors will be able, if they do not wish to bulk bill, to bill the disadvantaged patient for the full Schedule fee and medical benefit funds will pay a Commonwealth benefit of at least 85 per cent of the fee, leaving the patient to pay a maximum of $5 for the service, so long as the Schedule fee is charged.

(3) and (4) I have been advised by my colleague, the Minister for Health, that under the new funding arrangements, the Commonwealth will make a health grant to each State as the Commonwealth's contribution to that State's public hospitals, and community health and school dental programs. As in the past, the charges are expected to cover provision of pharmaceuticals to hospital patients which are necessary for their treatment. This matter will be one for States. Free public hospital in-patient and out-patient services to eligible pensioners and disadvantaged persons and their dependants as defined will also include pharmaceuticals necessary for the treatment of such persons without charge.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 March 1981 (Hansard, page 785), Senator Mulvihill asked me without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Until Nabarlek ceases operations in about six years time and proves that its effective sealing of its tailing deposits is not a future environmental threat to the Alligator Rivers system, will the Minister give an assurance that no mining operation leases will be granted other than those which are now in operation? Alternatively, will the Minister suggest to those self-same mining operators that they do their prospecting in the former pastoral leases of Sir William Gunn rather than in the Kakadu area? Finally, as the Minister will well know, if my suggestion is followed we will only be emulating the United States policy in Alaska where 40 per cent of that State is for evermore unavailable to any mineral prospecting whatsoever.
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

The Government's decision of 7 March 1979 to approve the development of the Nabarlek uranium deposit was taken following full consideration of the project's environmental impact assessment and the consequent recommendations of the then Minister for Science and the Environment. A detailed account of the environmental conditions applying to uranium mining operations at Nabarlek, the arrangements for ensuring compliance and the stage reached in regulation, research and development of standards, practices and procedures is contained in the Annual Reports of the Supervising Scientist.

Government policy on further exploration and development in the Region is that exploration in the Stage I area of the Kakadu National Park should not proceed for the time being and that future exploration will be carefully controlled in accordance with the Park Plan of Management.

Government policy in respect of the Stage II area provides that, before being incorporated in the Park, it will be declared a conservation zone, and exploration to identify the resources of the area will be permitted only under strictly controlled conditions.

Aboriginal land claims have been lodged over the Stage II area and assurances have been given to the Aboriginal people that until these have been determined, the Government will not permit the granting of mining interests without their prior consultation and agreement. A report on these land claims by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner, Mr Justice Toohey, was released on 22 July 1981.

With respect to the Gimbat and Goodparla properties formerly owned by Sir William Gunn, the Government accepted the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry's recommendation that they be considered for later addition to the Park. The properties were acquired by the Commonwealth in June 1978. A land use study of the leases is currently being undertaken jointly by the Commonwealth and Northern Territory Governments in order that decisions might be taken on their future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 May 1981 (Hansard, page 1884) Senator Missen asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Will consideration be given by the Government to the proposal put forward by the Council for Overseas Aid that Australia should move for a United Nations study of the possibility of introducing an international tax, including a tax on arms production, to raise funds for economic development.
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Government shares ACFOA's concern to improve the predictability of international aid flows. The Government is aware of a number of proposals for some form of international taxation including a variety of means of automatic transfer. However, it notes that the weight of expert assessment is that such proposals have substantial disadvantages, both of a conceptual and practical/administrative nature.

An important aspect is that automatic transfers through forms of international revenue raised from taxation have far reaching implications for relations among nations. A commitment to the principle of international taxation by levies on activities of sovereign states would involve a degree of derogation of sovereignty which most States at this stage are unprepared to accept. While it would seem highly desirable to divert to international economic development some of the enormous resources devoted to arms expenditures, it is a regrettable fact that while there are continuing threats to international security States are simply not, at this stage, prepared to do so.

The question of international taxation has already been widely canvassed. The Government has serious doubts that a special UN study on the matter would assist in overcoming the essential problems associated with the proposals, including the lack of preparedness by Governments to accept international taxation. It would prefer international attention to concentrate more on other measures to assure volume and continuity of funds for economic development.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 June 1981 (Hansard, page 3017) Senator Walters asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question, without notice, concerning the pos- sible removal of sales tax from various cosmetic items.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provide the following information:

Although it is agreed that many nourishing, moisturising and revitalising skin creams could be beneficial in harsh and dry climates, I could not support the proposal to remove all such creams from the luxury class of cosmetics which attracts a high rate of sales tax. However, in March 1978, the Government decided to remove sales tax from sunscreen preparations that provide effective protection from damaging ultra-violet rays. Since that time, any preparation which is marketed for use as a substance to be applied to the skin for the purpose of screening out solar ultra-violet rays and which is certified by the Director-General of Health to provide an acceptable level of protection from solar ultra-violet rays qualifies for sales tax exemption under Item 38A of the First Schedule of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1935. Some of the preparations in question do contain sunscreens and have met the required criteria for exemption from sales tax by the Commissioner of Taxation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 June 1981 (Hansard, page 3018) Senator Colston asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Education, a question, without notice, concerning the State offices of the Schools Commission in relation to the Review of Commonwealth Functions.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
It is expected that there will be some reduction in the level of staffing in a number of the Commonwealth Schools Commission's State Offices.

The Commonwealth Schools Commission, in co-operation with the Public Service Board and the Commonwealth Department of Education will endeavour to place displaced staff in appropriate vacancies within the Education Portfolio, and in the Australian Public Service as a whole.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 June 1981 (Hansard, page 3185) Senator Mulvihill asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My questions emanate from the CITES Conference held in New Delhi in March this year which considered the subject of restrictions to curb the alleged illegal black market export of ivory tusks from various African countries.
(1) What instructions have been given to Customs officers to check for illegal tusks?
(2) What role are we playing at the United Nations?
(3) Has any illegal traffic been detected and have any prosecutions been launched?
The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

(1) At the Conference held in New Delhi last March, Contracting Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) expressed concern about the depredation of some populations of African elephant by illegal trade in ivory. The Conference decided the African elephant should continue to be listed in Appendix II to the Convention to allow some strictly regulated commercial trade.

The provisions of CITES are enacted through the Customs (Endangered Species) Regulations. These Regulations are being amended to include the African elephant and products of this species. Customs officers have been instructed that imports of products of the African elephant, including ivory articles, are to be permitted only after the Australian scientific authority for CITES, the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, advises that the importation will not adversely affect the survival of the species and the importer has produced official documentation from the CITES management authority in the country of origin declaring that the ivory was legally acquired.

(2) Australia is one of 67 countries who are members of CITES. Since the inception of the Convention in Washington in 1973, the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service has represented Australia at all CITES Conferences.

(3) No illegal traffic of raw ivory has been detected in Australia. There have been a few isolated instances where small consignments of worked ivory, for example bangles, rings, et cetera have been imported without proper documentation and seized by Customs as prohibited imports. In these cases, because of the small quantity involved forfeiture of the goods concerned was considered sufficient penalty.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 31 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Did a delegation from Greece see the Minister for Social Security a few weeks ago about concluding a reciprocal pensions agreement; if so, what are the details of the proposed agreement and how does it differ from reciprocal agreements with other countries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I have not seen a delegation from Greece about concluding a reciprocal pensions agreement. However, the Ambassador of Greece called on me recently and discussed the possibility of Greece and Australia entering into a comprehensive reciprocal agreement on social security.

At that meeting, the Ambassador left with me, for information, examples of conventions completed by Greece with other countries. As is not unusual on such occasions, the Ambassador also gave me a draft for an agreement between our two countries which indicated the sort of approach that would be acceptable to his Government. That draft is being studied in the context of the Government's current examination of the question of negotiating reciprocal agreements on social security and it would be inappropriate for me to disclose its contents at this stage.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Are travel expenses paid on request to social security appellants who wish to attend the hearing of their appeals before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal; if not, is there any basis on which they are paid, and if they are not paid at all, how can a person without the means to travel successfully argue his or her case.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Energy Research and Development Program

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 29 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government committed $18.4m to its National Energy Research and Development Program.
(2) Is this approximately $7m less than the allocation for the previous year.
(3) What decrease does this represent in real terms.

(4) Did the Minister say in announcing the grants that the grants reflect the significance which the Government attaches to a vigorous energy research and development program as an integral part of its overall energy policy? If so, does this mean that the Government presently attaches less significance to vigorous energy research and development than it has in the past.

(5) Is the Government's expenditure in this area the second lowest per unit of gross domestic product among the 21 members of the International Energy Agency in 1980 and the third lowest expenditure per capita.
(6) What areas will be cut in order to produce the necessary saving in funds.
(7) Why will those areas be cut in preference to others; if they are to be cut, why were they supported last year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) At 29 May 1981 a total of $60.4m had been committed to the Program since its inception in 1978. The figure of $18.4m refers to the value of the grants approved in 1980-81 to 29 May. Funds for the Program are provided from appropriation and associated approved forward commitment and also from the Coal Research Levy.

(2) The value of the grants approved in 1979-80 was $7.9m higher than the value to 29 May in 1980-81. However this apparent decrease resulted from the fact that the bulk of the funds expected to accrue from the Coal Research Levy over the period 1979-82 was committed in 1979-80. Actual expenditure from both the Coal Research Levy and appropriation has continued to increase.
(3) See (2) above.
(4) My statement included the words quoted; the words did not convey the meaning attributed to them in the question.

(5) Australian Government expenditure on energy R&D is listed as the second lowest per unit of GDP in the IEA's draft Annual Report for 1980. In the same report Australia's expenditure on a per capita basis is listed as fourth lowest. However caution is needed in interpreting such comparisons as they are only meaningful if considered in conjunction with each country's energy circumstances and energy policy objectives for the future.
(6) See (2) above. Annual funds available for the Program have continued to increase.
(7) See (6) above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the New South Wales head office of the Department of Social Security been directed to relocate the Mayfield Branch of the Department at Tighes Hill.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Precise details of the costs of paying all Commonwealth employees are not available. I am, however, able to provide estimates based on a departmental study undertaken some years ago, of the costs of paying wages and salaries in cash to staff employed by Commonwealth departments under the Public Service Act (that is, excluding major statutory authorities) who were paid in this form. Estimates for the past five financial years, derived by updating the results of the study by relevant cost indices, are as follows:
These figures include estimated enveloping, delivery, and security services, computer processing costs and staff resources costs involved in distributing and acquitting pays.

(2) In the case of staff employed by Commonwealth departments under the Public Service Act, the estimated cost which would have been incurred in each of the past five years if those who were paid in cash had been paid by cheque or bank transfer is shown in the following table.
