ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 May 1981 (Hansard, page 1807) Senator Thomas asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister a question, without notice, concerning tax sharing arrangements.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Carrick undertook to refer the question to the Treasurer, who has provided the following response:

The matters raised in the letter from the Premier of Western Australia to the honourable senator were given careful consideration by the Government in the formulation of the revised tax sharing arrangements which have now been embodied in the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act 1981.

The new tax sharing arrangements reflect, inter alia, the need to restrain the growth in the public sector in order to make more room for the expansion of the private sector to proceed in a manner consistent with containing and reducing inflation. The Government considers that assistance to be provided to the States in 1981-82 and subsequent years represents an appropriate balance between the financial needs of the States and the requirements of responsible economic policy. As such, the Government sees the new arrangements as in the basic interests not only of Australia as a whole but also of individual States.

There was no 'assurance' given in 1976 that the States would continue indefinitely to receive any specific share of income tax collections. In fact, the States (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976 made specific provision for review of the tax sharing arrangements before 30 June 1981 and, at the Premiers' Conference in June, 1980, the Commonwealth gave clear notice of its view that the tax sharing arrangements established in 1976 had been unsustainably generous and that they would be reviewed in 1980-81. There were, therefore, no grounds on which any State Government could have based any expectation that the personal income tax sharing arrangements would not be modified.

The Government considers that the provision in the States (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976 requiring consultation was fully met. The arrangements decided at the Premiers' Conference held on 4 May took account of the detailed submission on tax sharing that the States presented in February 1981 and of the views expressed by Premiers at that Conference. In turn, the arrangements decided at the 20 June Premiers' Conference reflected consideration of the Commonwealth Grants Commission Report on State Tax Sharing Entitlements 1981 and of views expressed by Premiers at that Conference.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2794) Senator Teague asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice as to whether the task force appointed to consider occupational superannuation plans had completed its report. I undertook to refer the question to the Treasurer.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following answer:

In a Press statement of 12 July 1979 I announced that the Government had decided not to introduce the scheme of national superannuation recommended by the majority of the National Superannuation Committee of Inquiry. I also indicated in that statement that the Government had established a task force to consider the role of occupational superannuation in providing for retirement and whether there was a need to revise or impose new standards for schemes.

The task force has not yet submitted its final report. While the work of the task force has progressed a great deal, the matters under examination cover a range of difficult and complex issues and there are some aspects in respect of which arrangements are being made for the task force to be given some guidance by the Government. It is my expectation, however, that the task force will be reporting to the Government later this year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 June 1981 (Hansard, page 3026) Senator Button asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Were draft amendments of the Broadcasting and Television Act made available to and/or discussed with the News Corporation and/or its representatives, the Packer commercial broadcasting interest and/or their representatives, any public interest groups, and Herald and Weekly Times Ltd and/or its representatives on or prior to 14 May 1981?
(b) Will the Minister inquire from the Department about this matter?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I have indicated on several occasions that discussions concerning draft legislation were held with a range of people, including those named by the honourable senator, over a period of several months prior to finalisation of the Broadcasting and Television Act amendments. It follows that some discussions with lawyers and/or representatives of the commercial broadcasting industry took place prior to 14 May 1981. My Department had advised me that in the course of its discussions with industry representatives and other interested persons, no draft legislation was made available by it to any person, on or prior to 14 May 1981.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 5 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was a Mr Stan Robe of East St Kilda appointed co-ordinator of the Polish program on the Special Broadcasting Service Station 3EA from 1 May 1980 for a period of 12 months.
(2) Was an assurance that the appointment was for 12 months given to Mr Robe.
(3) Is SBS policy to convene a selection committee within 6 weeks of a new co-ordinator being appointed to select new broadcasters and was this done in Mr Robe's case.
(4) How many weeks was Mr Robe the sole broadcaster on the Polish program.
(5) Were broadcasters appointed at any time to assist Mr Robe, if so, when and by whom.
(6) How many people applied for the broadcasters position and were any of these appointed.
(7) Was Mr Robe dismissed as co-ordinator, if so, for what reasons or did Mr Robe resign, if so, what reasons were given.
(8) What complaints were made to the SBS by members of the Polish community about Mr Robe and what was the SBS response to these complaints.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Mr Robe was offered contract engagement for 12 months to co-ordinate the Polish language programs of Radio Station 3EA.

(4) and (5) Following a walkout, by the Polish language program broadcasters engaged by 3EA, Mr Robe was the sole broadcaster for the Polish language program for some 2-3 weeks, until suitable temporary broadcasters willing to work with Mr Robe, could be engaged by 3EA station management.
(6) Four, and yes, all were engaged on a temporary basis.

(7) Mr Robe's engagement with the SBS was terminated following numerous representations from the Polish community indicating that he was unacceptable to that community as the co-ordinator for the 3EA Polish language programs. Mr Robe subsequently received full remuneration to satisfy the terms of his contractual engagement.

(8) The SBS received representations from the Polish community that Mr Robe had no knowledge of, or contact with their community and that as he was unable to establish a viable rapport with the Polish community he should be removed.

The SBS and station management at 3EA made every effort to defuse the problem and to develop a rapport between the community and Mr Robe but was unable to do so. Management was therefore forced to reassess Mr Robe's position as co-ordinator for the Polish language program in terms of his primary function, that is, maintaining a focal point for community liaison with the broadcasters. As this was not possible Mr Robe's engagement was terminated and the position of co-ordinator for the Polish language program readvertised. Mr Robe reapplied for the position but was unsuccessful due to his non-acceptance by the Polish community.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) As a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions in what ways will any departments or instrumentalities under the Minister contract more work out to the private sector.
(2) Is it estimated that this measure will save those departments or instrumentalities money; if so how much is it estimated that it will save.
(3) In what way will those savings break down into component savings.

(4) Can the Minister give an assurance that the services to be contracted out to the private sector will not contribute to inflation or the Federal deficit by costing the Government more than would the same services provided from within the public services by salaried officers.
(5) If the Minister cannot give that assurance why have these moves been made without more comprehensive investigation and preparation.
(6) What investigations were made to ensure that the proposed action is economically sound.

(7) In the course of investigations that were made did the Minister receive any advice that in fact the proposed measures would cost the Government more money than they would save and if so what are the details.
(8) Has the Minister received any advice since the measures have been proposed that they would cost the Government more money than they will save and if so what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (8) The Department of Veterans' Affairs is continuing to examine its operations to determine where it might be practicable to contract out services to the private sector. This examination relates to the overall decisions about contracting out of services and involves consultation with those departments charged with the co-ordinating responsibilities for the particular decisions. Until this review is completed, it is not possible to comment on the number of issues raised in the question. However, on the specific decision relating to increased contracting out of limbs and appliance manufacture to the private sector, I can say that a number of new applications for contracts under the Free Limbs Scheme have been received from persons interested in establishing new businesses, particularly in regional areas. As these enterpises are established there will be an increased number of limbs and appliances manufactured outside of the Repatriation Artificial Limb and Appliance Centres, with some reduction in capacity in the centres. There will be some staff savings which will be achieved through normal wastage. Financial savings are not expected but the advantages will be greater access for patients to a more decentralised orthotic/prosthetic service.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 2 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) For each Federal electoral division in the 12 months to December 1980: (i) How many names were deleted due to death notification; (ii) how many names were deleted following habitation reviews; and (iii) how many names were transferred to other divisions.

(2) For each Federal electoral division since the close of rolls for the last Federal election: (i) How many names have been deleted due to death notification; (ii) how many names have been deleted following habitation reviews; (iii) how many names were transferred to other divisions.
(3) For each Federal electoral division in the 12 months to December 1980 how many polling places have been changed.

(4) For each Federal electoral division in the 12 months to December 1980: (i) how many employees, full and part time, were involved in habitation reviews, and what total hours were worked in this regard for each month; and (ii) what was the frequency of habitation reviews.
(5) Where an area is selected for more frequent habitation reviews, what is the criteria for such selection.

(6) What is the average length of time that an otherwise eligible voter whose name is deleted from a roll following a habitation review remains ineligible to vote before his/her name is returned to a roll.
(7) How many otherwise eligible voters who have been deleted from the rolls through the habitation review system remain unenrolled indefinitely.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) In the two tables set out below the Australian Electoral Office has provided information in answer to parts (1) (i) and (2) (i).

The Australian Electoral Office does not, however, maintain statistics in a form which would enable precise answers to be given to parts (1) (ii) and (2) (ii). Electors' names are removed from the rolls as a consequence of objection action on the grounds of non-residence within Divisions concerned, pursuant to the provisions of sections 52 to 55 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act and regulations 26 to 31 of the Electoral and Referendum Regulations. The main sources of objection on the grounds of non-residence are habitation reviews and follow-up action in respect of non-voters at elections but the statistics maintained by the Electoral Office do not so differentiate.

The Australian Electoral Office does not maintain statistics which would enable precise answers to be given to parts (1) (iii) and (2) (iii)-electoral rolls are maintained on a sub-divisional basis. To assist the honourable senator transfers out of sub-divisions have been totalled. However, the statistics maintained by the Australian Electoral Office do not differentiate between transfers between sub-subdivisions within a Division and transfers to sub-divisions in other Divisions. The figures supplied therefore must not be interpreted as transfers from Division to Division.

In essence the statistics show that in the year to December 1980 the names of 285,393 electors were removed from the electoral rolls following objection action on the grounds of non-residence. What has to be realised, however, is that during the same period some 1.5 million names were added to the rolls thoughout Australia. Of course, as the honourable senator will appreciate, these were not all new arrivals in Australia or persons turning 18 yeas of age. But this figure clearly takes into account people who have moved from one address to another, whose names have been removed from the first address by the required objection process, and whose names have been re-entered on the roll at their new address-many of them as a result of habitation review work in the area to which they had moved.

(5) The Australian Electoral Office advises that it is not normal practice to review the same areas twice in any one financial year. However, in cases where a review and the follow up work associated with it have been disrupted by, for example, an election the Office may arrange for further reviews.

(6) and (7) Objection procedures are such that Notices of Objection are not forwarded to any elector until at least one month after completion of the Habitation Review process within the sub-division. The elector is then given 20 days to reply to the Notice of Objection.

Therefore if an elector has moved from an address it would be about 60 days before his or her name was removed from the roll on grounds of non-residence. Generally in that time the elector should have established the statutory one month residential qualification in another sub-division and have either re-enrolled of his or her own accord or have been picked up by the Habitation Review in the new sub-division.

Although it is compulsory for an elector to re-enrol at a new address some electors do overlook this requirement until an election is announced or until they are picked up by the Habitation Review process. In this regard it is important to remember that Habitation Reviews are aimed as much at ensuring that all eligible electors are correctly enrolled, i.e. getting electors on the roll, as it is at removing the names of electors who have lost their eligibility for enrolment in respect of a particular address.

In addition to Habitation Reviews the Australian Electoral Office has a continuing electoral enrolment campaign through schools, and the use of posters and displays. In the run up to every Federal election it conducts a concentrated media campaign to ensure that as many eligible electors as possible are given the opportunity to get their names on the rolls. Nevertheless responsibility for enrolment ultimately lies with the individual.
The Australian Electoral Office does not have any information regarding the time or average time taken by eligible electors to enrol.

However, I would again refer the honourable senator to answers to parts (1) and (2) of the question above, where it is shown that in the same period in which some 290,000 electors' names were removed from the rolls in 1980 as a result of the objection process, 1.5 million names were added.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 11 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do the medical officers of the Department of Veterans' affairs, recognise a condition called 'toxic neurosis'; if so, what is the cause, and what are the symptoms.
(2) Can any symptoms be exacerbated by factors such as stress.
(3) Is a pension of any kind payable to sufferers from this condition.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) 'Toxic neurosis' is not a term which appears in the International Classification of Diseases and it is not used by medical officers of the Department of Veterans' Affairs.
While it has no scientific accuracy, the term may be used colloquially, as some medical conditions can be caused by various toxic agents.
As the condition referred to in the question is not apparent, its cause and symptoms cannot be described.
(2) In the absence of definition of the condition, the effect of factors such as stress and its symptoms cannot be defined.
(3) Whether a pension could be payable would depend upon a precise medical diagnosis and the circumstances of an individual case.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 11 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the estimated cost of the Bureau of Industrial Economics study referred to in Question 3 on page 036 of the written replies document submitted by Estimates Committee H in May 1981.
(2) What other studies on the same question of technology are being undertaken by other Departments or Instrumentalities.
(3) What was the cost of the preparation and production of the Bureau of Industrial Economics working paper-Regulation of Services-Retail Trading Hours.
(4) Who was responsible for directing that paper to be prepared.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Bureau of Industry Economics undertakes particular research projects that have priority ranking in terms of their medium to long-term significance for the Australian economy and in consultation with the Council of Advice consisting of representatives from business, the academic community and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The costs of individual projects depend on the number and status of research officers assigned to a project team at any time, the duration of the research task, the requirement for computer-based analysis and field work and the form of publication selected for disseminating the research findings. A large proportion of Bureau operating cost is due to overheads relating to administration, office accommodation and secretarial services and executive functions, thus making it impractical to allocate them to separate projects.

(2) While the Department of Science and Technology and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation have interests in the development and application of technology suitable for service activities, the Bureau's work on the economic impact of technological change in the finance and retailing industries is the only known research on this particular topic. To avoid unnecessary duplication, the Bureau's officers liaise with other Departments and instrumentalities as well as with academic researchers and have widely disseminated their research objectives to industry associations.
(3) As for (1) above.

(4) The Bureau's research priorities are determined by the Director, who reports to the Minister, in consultation with the Department of Industry and Commerce, the Council of Advice and members of the Bureau's senior staff. The Bureau has professional independence in the conduct and reporting of its research. Its working papers contain preliminary findings and are designed to elicit constructive comment and debate. The working paper referred to by the Honourable Senator was prepared as part of the Bureau's research into the Australian service sector. The results of that research were published in February 1981 in Research Report No. 6 Features of the Australian Service Sector.
